ada-chen-rekhi.title: Feeling stuck? Here's how to know when it's time to leave your job | Ada Chen Rekhi
ada-chen-rekhi.summary: Ada Chen Rekhi shares how to make better, more contextual decisions—especially around career moves—by systematically gathering high-quality input from others. Listeners will learn how to structure questions, choose the right people to ask, and avoid vague, low-signal advice by using her “Curiosity Loops” approach.
notable_frameworks: Curiosity Loops

adam-fishman.title: How to build a high-performing growth team | Adam Fishman (Patreon, Lyft, Imperfect Foods)
adam-fishman.summary: Adam Fishman shares how to build and evaluate high-performing growth teams, including a competency model for hiring and developing growth talent. He explains why onboarding is one of the most underleveraged growth levers—because every user experiences it—and how aligning brand promises with the onboarding/product experience prevents disappointment and drives activation. Listeners will also learn a practical framework for choosing which company to join based on growth and product realities.
notable_frameworks: Growth competency model (for hiring and evaluating growth talent)
Brand promise vs. product delivery alignment (brand as promise; product as delivery)
Framework for choosing which company to work at

adam-grenier.title: When to invest in new acquisition channels | Adam Grenier (Uber, MasterClass)
adam-grenier.summary: Adam Grenier shares how to decide when it’s actually time to invest in new acquisition channels versus when the real issue is that your product-market fit has shifted due to changing market conditions. Listeners will learn practical approaches to testing emerging channels, building a growth marketing function, and leading through uncertainty—along with candid lessons on burnout and mental health in high-pressure tech roles.
notable_frameworks: Assume PMF has reset in a new market (re-validate product-market fit before scaling channels)
Improv principles as a collaboration model ("Yes, and…"; "gift of details")

adriel-frederick.title: Humanizing product development | Adriel Frederick (Reddit, Lyft, Facebook)
adriel-frederick.summary: Adriel Frederick shares lessons from leading growth at Facebook, marketplace and pricing at Lyft, and incubating new products at Reddit. Listeners will learn how strong product leaders balance algorithms with human judgment, build and scale growth/marketplace systems responsibly, and develop their own leadership craft while improving diversity and team effectiveness.
notable_frameworks: Human-in-the-loop decision-making for algorithmic products (defining what the algorithm vs. people own)
Marketplace/pricing systems thinking (balancing incentives, matching, and operational controls)
Growth experimentation mindset (iterative acquisition optimization)

aishwarya-naresh-reganti-kiriti-badam.title: Why most AI products fail: Lessons from 50+ AI deployments at OpenAI, Google & Amazon
aishwarya-naresh-reganti-kiriti-badam.summary: Aishwarya Reganti and Kiriti Badam share hard-won lessons from 50+ real AI deployments on why AI products fail and how to build them successfully. Listeners will learn how AI changes the product lifecycle due to non-determinism and the agency/control trade-off, why teams must iterate step-by-step with tighter cross-functional collaboration, and what operating habits and persistence look like in companies that win with AI.
notable_frameworks: Non-determinism as a core product constraint ("non-deterministic API")
Agency vs. control trade-off for agentic systems
Step-by-step / start-small iterative deployment approach
Shared feedback-loop operating model (PM/Eng/Data reviewing agent traces together)
Flywheels for continuous improvement (post-deployment learning loops)
“Pain is the new moat” (persistence through implementation/iteration as defensibility)

albert-cheng.title: Finding hidden growth opportunities in your product | Albert Cheng (Duolingo, Grammarly, Chess.com)
albert-cheng.summary: Albert Cheng shares how top consumer subscription products find and unlock “hidden” growth by systematically connecting users to core product value—especially through retention and experimentation. Listeners will learn practical growth and monetization tactics from Duolingo, Grammarly, and Chess.com, plus how to structure teams and operating cadence to run high-volume, high-quality experiments (increasingly accelerated by AI).
notable_frameworks: Explore vs. exploit framework (for finding and prioritizing growth opportunities)
High-volume experimentation operating model (e.g., goal of ~1,000 experiments/year)
Growth as “connecting users to product value” (anti–metrics-hacking framing)

alex-hardimen.title: An inside look at how the New York Times builds product | Alex Hardiman (CPO, the New York Times)
alex-hardimen.summary: Alex Hardiman shares what it’s like to build and scale products at a mission-driven media company, where business outcomes (like subscriptions and engagement) explicitly serve journalism’s purpose. Listeners will learn how the New York Times approached major platform shifts (mobile-first, paid subscriptions) and how product leaders navigate impact, metrics, and responsibility—contrasted with her experience leading Facebook’s news product in the post-2016-election period.
notable_frameworks: Mission-driven product impact (business goals in service of mission)
Direct-to-consumer subscription model (paywall/subscription strategy)

alex-komoroske.title: Thinking like a gardener, slime mold, the adjacent possible: Product advice from Alex Komoroske
alex-komoroske.summary: Alex Komoroske shares a set of product and strategy mental models for building in complex, fast-changing environments—especially as AI reshapes how software is created and evolves. Listeners will learn how to shift from a "builder" mindset (plan-and-execute) to a "gardener" mindset (cultivate systems that grow), and how structured reflection practices can compound insight and decision quality over time.
notable_frameworks: Builder vs. Gardener mindset
Adjacent possible
Slime mold as an organizational/product metaphor
Organizational kayfabe
Strategy salons
Weekly reflection + note distillation practice (Compendium → Bits and Bobs)
Embeddings-assisted knowledge management (similar-idea retrieval)

alexander-embiricos.title: How to drive word of mouth | Nilan Peiris (CPO of Wise)
alexander-embiricos.summary: Alexander Embiricos, product lead for OpenAI Codex, shares what it’s like to build product inside OpenAI—especially the unusually high speed, ambition, and impact bar—and how that changes how you prioritize and execute. Listeners will learn how Codex is evolving from a code-writing tool into a proactive “software engineering teammate,” why enabling models to use computers via code is a key path to useful agents, and what product bets (like code review and reliability) matter as usage scales rapidly.
notable_frameworks: Human-in-the-loop acceleration (optimize for clarity of what the human should do vs. ambiguity)
Proactive agent roadmap (from reactive assistance to doing work autonomously)
Build agents by building coding agents (code as the interface for models to use computers)

alisa-cohn.title: Scripts for navigating difficult conversations | Alisa Cohn (executive coach)
alisa-cohn.summary: Executive coach Alisa Cohn shares practical scripts and phrasing to make difficult leadership conversations—like delivering tough performance feedback or denying a promotion—clearer, kinder, and more effective. Listeners will learn how to reframe the fear of upsetting people, focus on results over likability, and use simple meeting-closing questions to drive alignment and follow-through. The episode also covers founder relationship diligence via a “founder prenup” set of questions to prevent long-term conflict.
notable_frameworks: Difficult conversation scripts (specific language for feedback/promotion decisions)
Three questions to end every meeting
Founder prenup (questions to align co-founders early)

ami-vora.title: Making an impact through authenticity and curiosity | Ami Vora (CPO at Faire, ex-WhatsApp, FB, IG)
ami-vora.summary: Ami Vora shares how authenticity, curiosity, and ego-management can make you a more effective product and business leader—especially when navigating high-stakes disagreements and ambiguous decisions. Listeners will learn practical ways to choose roles and teams that set them up for success, use metaphors to align teams on product feel, and think about strategy as a journey from local to global optima.
notable_frameworks: Local optimum vs. global optimum ("hill climb" mental model)
Designing via desired user feeling (emotion-first metaphor/analogy alignment)
Ego sublimation to optimize for outcomes over being right

amjad-masad.title: Behind the product: Replit | Amjad Masad (co-founder and CEO)
amjad-masad.summary: Amjad Masad explains Replit’s vision of making software creation dramatically easier by bundling the entire development workflow—coding, runtime setup, dependencies, deployment, and sharing—into a single, accessible platform. Listeners will learn how AI-driven tooling is shifting the bottleneck from “can we build it?” to “can we generate good ideas fast enough?”, and what that implies for product builders and the future of startups (including the possibility of extremely lean, AI-run companies).
notable_frameworks: End-to-end software development lifecycle (SDLC) platform (editor → runtime → dependencies → deployment/sharing)

andrew-wilkinson.title: I’ve run 75+ businesses. Here’s why you’re probably chasing the wrong idea. | Andrew Wilkinson
andrew-wilkinson.summary: Andrew Wilkinson shares hard-won lessons from starting and operating 75+ businesses, emphasizing that most founders chase overly competitive, “sexy” ideas instead of profitable niches with real demand and less competition. He explains how to choose better startup ideas by “fishing where the fish are,” starting with simpler businesses to build entrepreneurial skill, and avoiding business models where many others repeatedly fail. Listeners will learn practical heuristics for idea selection, why niche markets can be advantaged, and how AI may reshape knowledge work into increasingly automated workflows.
notable_frameworks: Fish where the fish are (Charlie Munger heuristic)
Competition → lower margins (competitive intensity heuristic)
Start with “baby weights” (progressive difficulty / skill-building approach for first-time founders)
Avoid models with repeated historical failure (base-rate / track-record heuristic)

andy-johns.title: When enough is enough | Andy Johns (ex-FB, Twitter, Quora)
andy-johns.summary: Andy Johns shares his personal journey from being a high-performing product/growth leader (Facebook, Twitter, Quora, Wealthfront) to confronting severe burnout, panic, and deeper unresolved grief. Listeners will learn how to recognize the “red alarm” signals that something is wrong (sleep, relationships, health), why achievement can become an unhealthy coping mechanism, and what it can look like to step off a prestigious career path to pursue healing and a different life direction.
notable_frameworks: “Flashing red alarm” / core-function disruption check (sleep, relationships, physical health, playfulness, socialization)
“Frog boiling in a pot” gradual-burnout mental model

andy-raskin.title: The power of strategic narrative | Andy Raskin
andy-raskin.summary: Andy Raskin explains why the common “problem/solution” pitch (what he calls the “arrogant doctor”) often fails, and how the best companies instead win by telling a strategic narrative that frames a shift in the world—from an old game to a new game. Listeners will learn how to craft and use this narrative as a CEO-level north star that aligns marketing, sales, product direction, fundraising, and recruiting around a shared movement and set of new rules.
notable_frameworks: Strategic narrative
Arrogant doctor pitch (problem → solution → why better)
Old game → new game shift (movement-based narrative structure)
Screenwriting-inspired story structure applied to business pitching

andy-raskin_.title: The power of strategic narrative | Andy Raskin
andy-raskin_.summary: Andy Raskin explains why the classic “problem → solution → why we’re better” pitch is increasingly ineffective, and how top companies instead win by telling a strategic narrative that frames a major shift in the world (old game → new game). Listeners will learn how to craft a movement-style story that aligns marketing, sales, product strategy, fundraising, and recruiting around a single, compelling narrative.
notable_frameworks: Strategic narrative
Old game → new game (world shift) framing
“Arrogant doctor” pitch anti-pattern (problem/pain → solution/treatment → differentiation)
Movement-based positioning (Salesforce/Benioff-style narrative)

anneka-gupta.title: Becoming more strategic, navigating difficult colleagues, founder mode, more | Anneka Gupta
anneka-gupta.summary: Anneka Gupta shares practical ways to become more strategic by clearly articulating the “why” behind decisions and then actively championing the hard changes required to realize that direction. She also covers leadership tactics for navigating difficult situations by managing energy (not just time), reframing challenges to find learning, and using humor and levity to keep teams resilient through change.
notable_frameworks: Strategy = (1) articulate a compelling, simple “why” + (2) champion hard long-term change
Manage energy vs. manage time (schedule work to match personal energy peaks/troughs)
Reframing challenges: “What can I learn / what positive outcome can I get from this?”
Use humor/levity as a leadership tool to shift team mindset in difficult moments

annie-duke.title: This will make you a better decision maker | Annie Duke (Thinking In Bets, former pro poker player)
annie-duke.summary: Annie Duke shares practical ways to improve decision quality by making implicit assumptions explicit, separating decision quality from outcomes, and using structured disagreement to uncover blind spots. Listeners will learn how to run better meetings (discussion vs. discovery/decision), use pre-mortems effectively by defining kill criteria, and shorten “long” feedback loops by tracking leading indicators correlated with desired outcomes.
notable_frameworks: Thinking in Bets (probabilistic thinking; separating outcome from decision quality)
Make implicit assumptions explicit (assumption surfacing)
Adversarial collaboration (structured disagreement to resolve disputes)
Pre-mortem + kill criteria (commitment to triggers and actions)
Shortening feedback loops via leading indicators (correlated signals)
Meetings as discussion-only (separating discovery, discussion, and decision)

annie-pearl.title: Behind the scenes of Calendly’s rapid growth | Annie Pearl (CPO)
annie-pearl.summary: Annie Pearl (CPO at Calendly) breaks down what strong product strategy looks like—an integrated set of choices about where to play and how to win—and shares practical tactics for making Calendly scheduling feel less awkward and more user-friendly. She also gives concrete guidance for breaking into product management from non-traditional backgrounds, outlining both formal (APM programs, junior PM roles) and informal (shadowing PMs, SME programs) paths listeners can apply immediately.
notable_frameworks: Strategy as an integrated set of choices (winning aspiration, where to play, how to win)
Where to play / How to win (strategy choices)

anton-osika.title: Building Lovable: $10M ARR in 60 days with 15 people | Anton Osika (CEO and co-founder)
anton-osika.summary: Anton Osika, CEO and co-founder of Lovable, explains how Lovable acts as a “personal AI software engineer” that turns plain-English ideas into working software, enabling non-coders and small teams to build products dramatically faster. Listeners learn how Lovable achieved explosive early traction (hundreds of thousands of MAUs and rapid ARR growth) largely via word of mouth, and why the team focuses on building a “minimum lovable product” while operating with a highly generalist, leverage-maximizing team.
notable_frameworks: Minimum Lovable Product (MLP) → Lovable Product → Absolutely Lovable Product
“Build the last piece of software” vision (AI as the final software-creation layer)

anuj-rathi.title: The full-stack PM | Anuj Rathi (Swiggy, Jupiter Money, Flipkart)
anuj-rathi.summary: Anuj Rathi breaks down how product management evolved differently in India versus the US, and what that means for building consumer internet products in a market with distinct user behaviors and organizational expectations. Listeners will learn practical leadership diagnostics (capability vs motivation vs setup), why early Indian product orgs struggled with “software as machinery” thinking, and how modern Indian product teams are maturing toward stronger cross-functional product-building practices.
notable_frameworks: Leadership diagnostic: can’t do vs won’t do vs not set up to do
Ecosystem maturity model (product-building culture lag: US 1970s vs India ~2010)

aparna-chennapragada.title: Microsoft CPO: If you aren’t prototyping with AI you’re doing it wrong | Aparna Chennapragada
aparna-chennapragada.summary: Aparna Chennapragada (Microsoft CPO) explains how AI is changing product development: teams should prototype constantly with AI, and strong product taste is more important than ever to avoid "Frankenstein" experiences. She argues that natural language interfaces ("NLX") are becoming the new UX, requiring intentional design principles even when the UI is conversational. Listeners will learn how enterprise product building differs from consumer—especially the constant tension between frictionless usability and governance/security—and how to operationalize faster iteration loops.
notable_frameworks: NLX (Natural Language Interface) as the new UX
Rapid iteration loops via prototyping ("if you're not prototyping with AI, you're doing it wrong")
Punchline Market Fit (PMF) analogy from stand-up comedy to product iteration

april-dunford.title: A step-by-step guide to crafting a sales pitch that wins | April Dunford (author of Sales Pitch)
april-dunford.summary: April Dunford explains why many B2B deals stall into “no decision” and how a strong sales pitch helps buyers feel confident choosing. She shares a practical approach to turning product positioning into a compelling narrative—moving from feature walkthroughs to value-driven storytelling that clearly differentiates your product and makes the decision easier for prospects.
notable_frameworks: Positioning-to-pitch translation (using positioning as the backbone of the sales story)
Value-first pitching (shifting from feature exposition to outcomes/value delivered)
Competitive alternatives framing (clarifying what customers would do instead and why your approach is different)

april-dunford-20.title: How to nail your product positioning | April Dunford (Obviously Awesome)
april-dunford-20.summary: April Dunford explains why many B2B buying processes end in “no decision” and how stronger positioning and a clearer sales narrative help prospects choose confidently. Listeners learn how to translate positioning into a compelling sales pitch that focuses on value (not feature walkthroughs) and differentiates against real alternatives using a clear story structure.
notable_frameworks: Positioning-to-pitch translation (using positioning as the backbone of the sales story)
Value-based pitching (benefits/value over feature-by-feature demos)
Alternative-based differentiation (framing against the buyer’s real options, including status quo)

archie-abrams.title: How to speak more confidently and persuasively | Matt Abrahams (professor, speaker, author)
archie-abrams.summary: Archie Abrams breaks down how Shopify drives growth at massive scale by aligning product and growth decisions to a long-term mission: increasing entrepreneurship on the internet. Listeners will learn why Shopify is willing to accept (and even "optimize for") churn by lowering barriers to starting a business, how their monetization model changes retention incentives, and how their growth org runs experimentation with long-term measurement to avoid short-term optimization traps.
notable_frameworks: Mission-driven growth (optimize for entrepreneurship attempts vs. minimizing churn)
Funnel-stage optimization trap (local conversion optimization can hurt global outcomes)
Long-term experiment holdouts with 1/2/3-year impact reviews
100-year vision-driven roadmap (CEO-led long-horizon strategy)
KPI-light / taste-and-intuition decision model for core product teams

arielle-jackson.title: The art of building legendary brands | Arielle Jackson (Google, Square, First Round Capital)
arielle-jackson.summary: Arielle Jackson breaks down how to build a strong startup brand—starting with naming, then moving into a practical brand strategy that clarifies why you exist, who you’re for, and how you show up. Listeners will learn how to think about names as only one input into brand equity, how to position products against clear “foils” (alternatives), and how early-stage teams can approach marketing/PR with limited resources.
notable_frameworks: Brand strategy framework: Purpose, Positioning, Personality
Positioning via a clear foil (the alternative you’re replacing) + differentiated benefit

asha-sharma.title: How 80,000 companies build with AI: Products as organisms and the death of org charts | Asha Sharma
asha-sharma.summary: Asha Sharma shares what she’s seeing from the front lines of Microsoft’s AI platform work: products are shifting from static “artifacts” to adaptive “organisms” that continuously learn via post-training loops, reward design, and rigorous experimentation. She explains why agents are the scaling mechanism for an “agentic society,” how this changes roadmapping and org design (org charts becoming “work charts”), and what it takes for teams to build durable moats when models and capabilities evolve rapidly.
notable_frameworks: Product as artifact → product as organism
Post-training as the new pre-training (optimize via feedback loops once models are sufficiently capable)
Seasons of AI development (e.g., prototyping → models/reasoning → agents)
Org chart becomes the work chart (fewer layers as agents take on execution)

austin-hay.title: The ultimate guide to Martech | Austin Hay (Reforge, Ramp, Runway)
austin-hay.summary: Austin Hay breaks down what “MarTech” (marketing technology) actually is: a cross-functional discipline at the intersection of marketing, product, engineering, and operations focused on the systems, tools, and processes that power growth. Listeners learn how MarTech responsibilities evolve with company stage—from a “village” approach at small startups to centralized ownership around ~100–150 employees—and why privacy changes are pushing teams from deterministic attribution to probabilistic decision-making.
notable_frameworks: People + process + platform (systems/tools) view of MarTech
Company stage-based operating model for MarTech ownership ("village" → centralized around ~100–150 employees)
Deterministic vs probabilistic attribution/measurement mental model

ayo-omojola.title: Frameworks for product differentiation, team building, and first principles thinking | Ayo Omojola
ayo-omojola.summary: Ayo Omojola breaks down what made Cash App a rare consumer-product success: not a single silver bullet, but a set of reinforcing advantages like extreme consumer-first focus, high talent density, strong design, and operational excellence (e.g., fraud). He also shares a concrete lens for differentiation—"different" and "better" aren’t enough unless the improvement matters to users in a way competitors can’t match—and touches on scrappy growth lessons from building a side project (Mailform) via SEO and Quora.
notable_frameworks: Differentiation test: different vs. better vs. better-in-a-way-that-matters (user-relevant advantage)

bangaly-kaba.title: Unorthodox frameworks for growing your product, career, and impact | Bangaly Kaba (YT, IG, FB)
bangaly-kaba.summary: Bangaly Kaba shares practical, experience-backed frameworks for driving change and growth across products and organizations, drawing on roles at Facebook, Instagram, Instacart, and YouTube. Listeners learn how to choose roles and projects for maximum impact by separating “environment” constraints from “skills” gaps, and how to avoid biased execution by doing rigorous “understand work” before committing to a solution.
notable_frameworks: Change equation: vision + skills + incentives + resources + action plan (all required for change)
Understand–Identify–Execute (vs. Identify–Justify–Execute)
Environment vs. Skills impact model for choosing where to work/what to work on

barbra-gago.title: Category creation and brand building | Barbra Gago (Pando, Miro, Greenhouse, Culture Amp)
barbra-gago.summary: Barbra Gago breaks down how to decide whether to create a new category or compete in an existing one, drawing on lessons from Miro (expanding from “online whiteboard” to “visual collaboration”) and Greenhouse (attempting to distance from the ATS label). Listeners will learn what signals to look for—budget availability, buyer language, category validation, and competitive dynamics—and why competition is actually necessary to make a category real.
notable_frameworks: Category creation decision criteria (budget existence, buyer language, analyst/directory validation, competitive validation)

ben-horowitz.title: $46B of hard truths: Why founders fail and why you need to run toward fear | Ben Horowitz (a16z)
ben-horowitz.summary: Ben Horowitz shares hard-earned lessons on leadership under extreme uncertainty, arguing that the CEO’s core job is making painful, unpopular decisions quickly rather than hesitating. He explains how success (and failure) often compounds from a sequence of small decisions, and why building the psychological resilience to reject limiting narratives about yourself is essential to enduring the founder journey.
notable_frameworks: Good Product Manager, Bad Product Manager (PM as a leadership role without direct authority)
Series-of-decisions compounding model (success/failure as accumulated small decisions; break the chain by rejecting sunk cost)
Run toward fear / choose the “slightly better” horrible option (leadership in the abyss)

ben-williams.title: How Snyk built a product-led growth juggernaut | Ben Williams (VP of Product at Snyk)
ben-williams.summary: Ben Williams (VP Product at Snyk) breaks down how Snyk built a massive developer-focused security business by combining product-led growth with clear growth loops and an intentional strategy for where to invest each quarter. Listeners will learn how Snyk found its first users, what went wrong with early monetization, how it evolved into product-led sales, and how the team structured growth, freemium boundaries, and go-to-market as the company scaled.
notable_frameworks: Growth loops (micro and macro loops) modeling
Qualitative growth model to create shared understanding
Quantitative prioritization to guide quarter-to-quarter investment focus

benjamin-lauzier.title: How marketplaces win: Liquidity, growth levers, quality, more | Benjamin Lauzier (Lyft, Thumbtack)
benjamin-lauzier.summary: Benjamin Lauzier breaks down what makes marketplaces succeed or fail, emphasizing that pre–product-market-fit teams should stop over-optimizing “marketplace dynamics” and instead validate the core value exchange and a repeatable growth motion for at least one side. He also explains how marketplace operators should set clear quality guardrails, empower participants with tools/coaching, and then selectively add hands-on interventions to close specific gaps in the experience.
notable_frameworks: Core exchange of value (validate the fundamental value transfer before optimizing marketplace mechanics)
One-side-first GTM (go deep on one side; use a temporary “crutch”/hack for the other side early on)
Quality bar + guardrails (set explicit standards for a good marketplace experience)
Empowerment-first operations (tools/coaching for supply, then targeted hands-on tactics to close gaps)
Managed vs. unmanaged marketplace spectrum (degree of intermediary control shaping the transaction)

benjamin-mann.title: How marketplaces win: Liquidity, growth levers, quality, more | Benjamin Lauzier (Lyft, Thumbtack)
benjamin-mann.summary: Benjamin Mann (Anthropic co-founder, former OpenAI GPT-3 architect) discusses how quickly AI capabilities are advancing, why he believes superintelligence could arrive as early as 2028, and why alignment and safety must be treated as urgent, first-order priorities. Listeners will learn how top AI labs think about scaling progress, the talent/compensation arms race for elite researchers, and Mann’s view of the probability range for catastrophic AI outcomes if alignment fails.
notable_frameworks: Scaling laws (and the claim that progress is accelerating, not plateauing)
Mission-oriented recruiting/retention tradeoff (money vs impact framing)
“Keep God in a box” mental model for superintelligence containment
X-risk probability framing (forecasting catastrophic outcome likelihood)

bill-carr.title: Unpacking Amazon’s unique ways of working | Bill Carr (author of Working Backwards)
bill-carr.summary: Bill Carr breaks down how Amazon’s customer-obsessed philosophy translated into a repeatable operating system—especially the “working backwards” approach to building products and making decisions. Listeners will learn why Amazon invested heavily in process innovation (not just product innovation), how key mechanisms like single-threaded leadership, input/output metrics, and disagree-and-commit scale decision-making, and what it takes to implement these practices in other companies.
notable_frameworks: Working Backwards
Customer obsession / start with the customer and work backward
One-way door vs two-way door decisions
Disagree and commit
Input vs output metrics
Narrative memos vs slide decks
Two-pizza teams
Single-threaded leader model
Bar Raiser hiring program
Amazon Leadership Principles (as an operating mechanism)

bob-baxley.title: 35 years of product design wisdom from Apple, Disney, Pinterest and beyond | Bob Baxley
bob-baxley.summary: Bob Baxley shares lessons from decades of product design leadership at Apple and other major tech companies, focusing on design as a discipline for imagining a better future and executing toward it. Listeners will learn how strong company cultures shape product quality and behavior, why “design-led” is not the same as “designer-led,” and how to successfully transition between high-intensity cultures like Apple and other organizations without losing core values.
notable_frameworks: Design as imagining a desired future and taking steps to make it real
Values vs. behaviors when transitioning between company cultures
The “Apple car wash” (cultural indoctrination/deprogramming model)

bob-moesta.title: How to find work you love | Bob Moesta (Jobs-to-be-Done co-creator, author of "Job Moves”)
bob-moesta.summary: Bob Moesta explains Jobs-to-be-Done as a demand-side lens: people “hire” products to make progress in a specific context toward a desired outcome, and what looks irrational becomes rational once you understand the full story. Listeners will learn how to uncover the real competitive set and sources of demand by investigating struggling moments and customer narratives rather than relying on pain/gain checklists or product-category comparisons.
notable_frameworks: Jobs to Be Done (JTBD)
Hire vs. buy framing (products as hired for progress)
Demand-side vs. supply-side competition
Struggling moment as the causal trigger of demand
Context-and-outcome framing (vs. pain/gain)

bob-moesta-20.title: The ultimate guide to JTBD | Bob Moesta (co-creator of the framework)
bob-moesta-20.summary: Bob Moesta shares a Jobs-to-be-Done-driven approach to career changes, arguing that people start looking for a new role when they stop making progress—and that many end up in worse jobs because they don’t understand the underlying “why” behind what they’re seeking. Listeners will learn to distinguish job “features” (salary, title) from the experiences that actually drive satisfaction and retention, plus practical tactics like taking a “jobcation” to reset before making a major move.
notable_frameworks: Jobs-to-be-Done (JTBD)
Job Moves (applying JTBD to career decisions)
Job features vs. job experiences
Jobcation (recovery/reset period between roles)

boz.title: Making Meta | Andrew ‘Boz’ Bosworth (CTO)
boz.summary: Boz shares what it was really like building Facebook in the earliest days—extreme intensity, constant operational anxiety, and learning without experts to lean on—alongside how those conditions shaped Meta’s product and engineering culture. Listeners will learn practical leadership and communication lessons from scaling foundational consumer products like News Feed and ads, plus how Meta approaches major platform bets (AR/VR, hardware) and organizational turnarounds.
notable_frameworks: Algorithmically ranked feed (News Feed) as a product paradigm
Usage vs. sentiment validation (outrage paired with increased engagement) as a launch signal

brandon-chu.title: AI prompt engineering in 2025: What works and what doesn’t | Sander Schulhoff
brandon-chu.summary: Brandon Chu shares his path from finance and bootstrapping a startup to becoming a VP of Product at Shopify, highlighting what actually drives long-term PM career trajectory. The core lesson is that beyond PM “table stakes” (execution, analytics, communication), the biggest accelerators are founder-like skills: storytelling, motivating teams, and making high-conviction decisions under ambiguity with accountability.
notable_frameworks: Table-stakes vs. differentiators (PM hard skills vs. founder skills)
High-conviction decision-making under ambiguity (leap-of-faith decisions + accountability)

brendan-foody.title: Why experts writing AI evals is creating the fastest-growing companies in history | Brendan Foody
brendan-foody.summary: Brendan Foody explains why "evals" (systematic tests of model performance) are becoming the core bottleneck and competitive advantage in AI—functioning like PRDs for models and increasingly like sales/marketing collateral for proving capability. He shares how Mercor built a labor marketplace of expert professionals to create these evals for top AI labs and enterprises, and what it looks like to operationalize measurement so reinforcement learning and iteration can reliably improve real-world workflows.
notable_frameworks: Evals as PRDs ("If the model is the product, the eval is the PRD")
Evals as sales collateral / marketing proof ("Evals = your new marketing")
Value-chain evaluation (build systematic tests for how well AI automates your core value chain)
Iterate via experiments to climb evals (run many small experiments; RL becomes effective once evals exist)

bret-taylor.title: He saved OpenAI, invented the “Like” button, and built Google Maps: Bret Taylor (Sierra)
bret-taylor.summary: Bret Taylor shares lessons from building and scaling iconic products (Google Maps, the Like button, Quip) and leading at the highest levels (Facebook CTO, Salesforce co-CEO, OpenAI board chair). Listeners will learn why the software market is shifting toward AI agents and outcomes-based pricing, plus practical insights on product differentiation, recovering from early product failures, and building products that deliver clear user value.
notable_frameworks: Outcomes-based pricing (pricing software/agents on delivered results vs. seats/usage)
Agent-first product strategy (orienting products around autonomous agents delivering outcomes)
Impact-first prioritization ("What is the most impactful thing I could do today?")
Inverting the product hierarchy (making the map the primary canvas vs. an add-on UI element)

brian-balfour.title: Why ChatGPT will be the next big growth channel (and how to capitalize on it) | Brian Balfour
brian-balfour.summary: Brian Balfour argues that building a great product is necessary but not sufficient—winning increasingly depends on building superior distribution, especially as incumbents copy faster and traditional organic channels (SEO, social referral traffic) decline. He predicts a major new distribution shift is imminent, likely centered around ChatGPT, and explains why new platforms create rare windows where startups can reach escape velocity before incumbents adapt.
notable_frameworks: Escape velocity / 'get distribution before the incumbent can copy' (Alex Rampell framing)
Technology shift vs. distribution shift (Casey Winters framing)
New distribution platform emergence as a startup advantage window

brian-chesky.title: Brian Chesky’s new playbook
brian-chesky.summary: Brian Chesky explains Airbnb’s updated operating model: a tighter, more senior product org that blends traditional PM “inbound” responsibilities with product marketing, while shifting program-management work to dedicated program managers. He also shares his leadership philosophy of staying deeply in the details (without “micromanaging”) to create clarity, alignment, and faster execution—paired with a renewed belief that building and clearly communicating a great product can drive growth without relying heavily on paid channels.
notable_frameworks: Functional org model with influence-based leadership (no direct control)
“Leaders are in the details” vs micromanagement distinction
Combining inbound product management + outbound product marketing responsibilities
Offloading program-management work from PMs to dedicated program managers
Single-company roadmap / centralized product direction (mentioned in intro)

brian-tolkin.title: Lessons from scaling Uber and Opendoor | Brian Tolkin (Head of Product at Opendoor, ex-Uber)
brian-tolkin.summary: Brian Tolkin shares lessons from scaling operationally heavy tech businesses at Uber and Opendoor, emphasizing that the best outcomes come when product and operations function as a tightly coupled system. Listeners will learn how ops experience can make product leaders more effective, how to build strong feedback loops between centralized product teams and distributed field teams, and why “product operations” emerged as a critical bridge function at Uber.
notable_frameworks: Twin-turbine jet plane model (product + ops as dual engines)
Product Operations (as a bidirectional feedback-loop function between product and field ops)

cam-adams.title: Inside Canva: Coaches not managers, giving away your Legos, and embracing AI | Cameron Adams
cam-adams.summary: Cameron Adams (Canva co-founder and CPO) shares how Canva’s culture and operating model—especially “coaches not managers” and “giving away your Lego”—helps the company scale while staying product-obsessed. He also recounts a high-stakes fundraising near-miss that reinforced Canva’s commitment to profitability and independence, and contrasts Canva’s tightly team-embedded approach to product management with more detached PM models.
notable_frameworks: Coaches-not-managers model
Giving away your Lego

camille-fournier.title: The things engineers are desperate for PMs to understand | Camille Fournier (“The Manager’s Path”)
camille-fournier.summary: Camille Fournier breaks down the most common ways product managers unintentionally frustrate engineers—especially hoarding credit, dismissing technical details, acting as a “telephone” between stakeholders and engineers, and excluding engineers from ideation. Listeners will learn practical behaviors that build trust and collaboration between PM and engineering, and why involving engineers in the creative process can reduce counterproductive over-engineering.
notable_frameworks: DORA framework (mentioned in sponsor segment)
SPACE framework (mentioned in sponsor segment)

camille-hearst.title: Monetizing passions, scaling marketplaces, and stories from a creator economy vet | Camille Hearst
camille-hearst.summary: Camille Hearst shares lessons from building and scaling creator monetization products across Spotify, Patreon, YouTube, and iTunes, with a focus on how platforms can help creators turn fan passion into sustainable income. Listeners will learn practical approaches to fan monetization (e.g., merch, exclusives, listening parties), what makes creator businesses hard, and how to think about building creator platforms and marketplaces that work for both sides.
notable_frameworks: Fan monetization loops (rewarding top listeners with exclusives/early access to drive purchases)
Two-sided marketplace thinking (balancing creator supply and fan demand)

camille-ricketts.title: How Notion leveraged community to build a $10B business | Camille Ricketts
camille-ricketts.summary: Camille Ricketts (Notion’s first marketing hire and longtime head of marketing) breaks down how Notion used community-led growth and content to drive early adoption and sustained momentum on the path to becoming a ~$10B company. Listeners will learn how to think about “content-market fit,” when community investment makes sense, and practical ways to build a durable content and community engine that supports product growth.
notable_frameworks: Content-market fit (analogous to product-market fit)
Community-led growth (CLG)

carilu-dietrich.title: How to achieve hypergrowth in your business and career | Carilu Dietrich (Atlassian)
carilu-dietrich.summary: Carilu Dietrich breaks down what drives true hypergrowth in B2B companies—primarily organic/inbound/viral word-of-mouth powered by a product people love—and why paid acquisition alone can’t sustain those growth rates. She also shares career lessons for reaching the executive level, emphasizing deliberate trade-offs, working hard to build real expertise, taking on “white space” responsibilities, and learning to think in CEO/board and revenue terms while hiring leaders ahead of the next growth stage.
notable_frameworks: Organic/inbound/viral word-of-mouth as the foundation of hypergrowth
“Riding the lightning” (anticipating stages of growth and scaling ahead of demand)
Hire 2x/3x leaders (leaders who have seen the next stage of scale)
C-suite readiness checklist (tie work to revenue; think in CEO/board terms; learn finance; cross-functional tours of duty; relationship-building)

carole-robin.title: How to build deeper, more robust relationships | Carole Robin (Stanford professor, “Touchy Feely”)
carole-robin.summary: Carole Robin shares practical, learnable skills for moving relationships along a continuum from “contact/no connection” or dysfunction to robust, functional, and even exceptional relationships. Listeners will learn how to communicate more effectively—especially through clearer feedback, curiosity-driven questions, and vulnerability—and how understanding differing “realities” and underlying emotions reduces defensiveness and strengthens connection at work and at home.
notable_frameworks: Relationship continuum (contact/no connection → functional/robust → exceptional)
Three realities (my experience, what I did, what happened for you)
Feedback model: separate feelings from judgments (e.g., “I feel you don’t care” is not a feeling)
Questioning technique: use what/when/where/how; avoid why
Anger as a secondary emotion (anger distances; primary emotions like fear/hurt connect)
15% more disclosure/vulnerability principle

casey-winters.title: Why most product managers are unprepared for the demands of a real startup | Casey Winters
casey-winters.summary: Casey Winters shares lessons from scaling consumer companies and leading product at Eventbrite, emphasizing how growth often starts with scrappy, non-scalable tactics that unlock scalable “loops” and long-term growth strategies. Listeners will learn how to think about product/growth trade-offs, why many teams under-communicate critical context upward, and how executives can make better decisions when constraints and trade-offs are made explicit.
notable_frameworks: Growth loops (content loops)
Non-scalable hacks to unlock scalable growth

casey-winters_.title: How to sell your ideas and rise within your company | Casey Winters, Eventbrite
casey-winters_.summary: Casey Winters shares hard-won lessons from leading product as CPO at Eventbrite, focusing on how product leaders can sell ideas internally and stay effective as company needs shift. Listeners will learn how to operate as a company executive (not just a product leader), how to diagnose and communicate team/product strengths and gaps, and why rigid “perfect PM” frameworks can reduce risk-taking and impact.
notable_frameworks: Zero interest rate phenomenon product manager
Frameworks as tools in a toolkit (not a coloring book)
Executive-first mindset for CPOs (company exec first, product exec second)

chandra-janakiraman.title: An operator’s guide to product strategy | Chandra Janakiraman (CPO at VRChat, ex-Meta, Headspace)
chandra-janakiraman.summary: Chandra Janakiraman demystifies product strategy and shares an operator-friendly, repeatable approach for creating strategies that drive real alignment and execution. Listeners will learn how to distinguish near-term, problem-solving “present-forward” strategy from longer-horizon, aspirational “big-S” strategy, and how a structured, multi-stage process (typically 8–12 weeks) can produce a clear written strategy that teams understand and rally behind.
notable_frameworks: Five-stage product strategy process (8–12 week strategy cycle; ~2-year “present-forward” horizon)
Present-forward strategy vs. Big-S (5–10 year) aspirational strategy
Good Strategy, Bad Strategy (Rumelt) concepts
Playing to Win strategy cascade
Michael Porter / competitive strategy concepts

chip-conley.title: Mastering product strategy and growing as a PM | Maggie Crowley (Toast, Drift, TripAdvisor)
chip-conley.summary: Chip Conley shares what it was like joining Airbnb at 52—learning tech/product language, leading in a young company, and mentoring Brian Chesky while also reporting to him. Listeners will learn practical lessons on leading across age/experience gaps, translating “product” thinking into real-world hospitality/customer experience, and building cultures that blend speed with wisdom.
notable_frameworks: Modern Elder (being both "wise and curious")
Midlife as chrysalis (reframing midlife transition as transformation, not crisis)

chip-huyen.title: Al Engineering 101 with Chip Huyen (Nvidia, Stanford, Netflix)
chip-huyen.summary: Chip Huyen breaks down why many AI product efforts stall: teams over-index on chasing the latest models, frameworks, and tooling debates instead of doing the fundamentals that actually move outcomes. Listeners learn practical heuristics for prioritizing AI work (e.g., how much “optimal tech choice” really matters, and the switching costs of new tech), plus clear explanations of core AI concepts like pre-training vs. post-training and where fine-tuning fits.
notable_frameworks: “What people think improves AI apps vs what actually improves AI apps” table
Optimization leverage heuristic (optimal vs non-optimal solution impact)
Switching-cost / lock-in heuristic for adopting new AI technologies
Pre-training vs post-training mental model
Supervised fine-tuning (SFT)
Distillation (teacher-student training)

chris-hutchins.title: Launching and growing a podcast | Chris Hutchins (All the Hacks, Wealthfront, Google)
chris-hutchins.summary: Chris Hutchins shares a practical playbook for launching and growing a podcast, emphasizing that consistency alone (e.g., publishing weekly for 10+ episodes) quickly puts you in a small, high-performing minority of active shows. Listeners learn how a product-minded approach—clear positioning, audience understanding, and disciplined execution—can turn a podcast into a scalable creator business, alongside lessons from Chris’s product career (Google, Wealthfront) that inform his strategy.
notable_frameworks: Consistency as a competitive advantage (publish cadence/10-episode threshold to reach the top % of active podcasts)
Product-style discovery for new bets (customer research to define an audacious product vision, e.g., Wealthfront’s “Self-Driving Money”)

christian-idiodi.title: The essence of product management | Christian Idiodi (SVPG)
christian-idiodi.summary: Christian Idiodi explains why product management is often disliked: many teams haven’t experienced competent PMs who deeply understand customers, data, and the business well enough to earn trust and decision rights. Listeners will learn what “good” product management looks like in practice, how PMs can build credibility through humility and accelerated learning, and why strong PMs make cross-functional teams measurably more effective.
notable_frameworks: Competency-based product management (earning decision rights through customer/data/business expertise)
“Certificate of appreciation” framing (value exchange: solve customer problems → receive revenue/engagement/loyalty)

christina-wodtke.title: The ultimate guide to OKRs | Christina Wodtke (Stanford)
christina-wodtke.summary: Christina Wodtke explains how OKRs work best as a “vitamin, not a medicine”: they amplify organizations that already have strong fundamentals like strategy, empowered teams, and psychological safety, but will expose dysfunction in companies that don’t. Listeners will learn the core benefits of OKRs—radical focus, alignment, a quarterly execution cadence, and a built-in learning loop through grading and reflection—plus practical guidance on avoiding common failure modes like too many OKRs.
notable_frameworks: OKRs (Objectives and Key Results)
Radical focus (limiting the number of OKRs)
Quarterly OKR cadence and grading (learning loop)
OKRs as a “vitamin vs. medicine” mental model

christine-itwaru.title: Understanding the role of product ops | Christine Itwaru (Pendo)
christine-itwaru.summary: Christine Itwaru breaks down what “product operations” actually is—both as a set of practices (systems that help product teams thrive) and as a dedicated role/team that partners with PMs and advises product leadership. Listeners will learn why product ops emerged rapidly (especially around 2019), what problems it addresses (voice-of-customer synthesis, alignment, transparency, scaling growth), and how it complements (rather than replaces) product management.
notable_frameworks: Product ops as (1) a practice/system and (2) a dedicated role/team (PM partner + strategic advisor to product leadership)
Voice-of-customer management and synthesis (qualitative + quantitative inputs)

christopher-lochhead.title: How to become a category pirate | Christopher Lochhead (Author of Play Bigger, Niche Down, more)
christopher-lochhead.summary: Christopher Lochhead explains why building a legendary company often requires creating and owning a new category rather than competing to be “better” inside an existing one. Listeners will learn the core ideas behind category design, how to position and communicate a new category, and why common startup concepts like “being the best product” or even traditional product-market fit thinking can be traps.
notable_frameworks: Category Design
Category Pirates (category creation mindset/approach)
The “Better” Trap
Design and Dominate a Category (Play Bigger thesis)

christopher-miller.title: Relentless curiosity, radical accountability, and HubSpot’s winning growth formula | Chris Miller
christopher-miller.summary: Chris Miller shares how he helped shape HubSpot’s early product-led growth motion by taking radical ownership of ambiguous problems, proactively finding leverage points across the business, and pushing for higher-level strategy even without formal authority. Listeners will learn practical lessons on building a growth mindset as a PM, creating cross-functional context (e.g., learning from sales/support), and why curiosity and accountability can unlock outsized opportunities—plus how this connects to his current remit leading both Growth and AI at HubSpot.
notable_frameworks: product-led growth (PLG)
radical accountability / ownership mentality
widening your aperture (operating a level above your scope)

claire-butler.title: An inside look at Figma’s unique GTM motion | Claire Butler (first GTM hire)
claire-butler.summary: Claire Butler, Figma’s first GTM/marketing hire, shares an inside look at how Figma built and scaled its go-to-market from stealth to widespread adoption. Listeners learn how Figma paired strong positioning/branding with a bottom-up adoption motion—winning individual contributors first, then enabling internal spread—plus what early-stage execution really looks like (from naming decisions to hands-on customer support).
notable_frameworks: Two-part bottom-up GTM motion (win ICs first, then enable org-wide spread)
Positioning and messaging alignment process (forcing explicit, word-for-word agreement pre-launch)

claire-hughes-johnson.title: Lessons from scaling Stripe | Claire Hughes Johnson (ex-COO of Stripe)
claire-hughes-johnson.summary: Claire Hughes Johnson (ex-COO of Stripe) shares practical lessons from scaling Stripe and Google, focusing on how to build an effective operating cadence and decision-making culture that preserves momentum as a company grows. Listeners will learn tactical approaches to hiring, onboarding, clarifying ownership, and using principles/processes to make teams move faster without chaos.
notable_frameworks: Operating principles (company and personal)
Company operating system / operational cadence
Decision-maker clarity rule of thumb ("If you're not sure who the decision maker is, it's probably you—ask if unsure")
Hiring process as a system (templates, structured process; "if talent is everything, hiring process is everything")

claire-vo.title: Bending the universe in your favor | Claire Vo (LaunchDarkly, Color, Optimizely, ChatPRD)
claire-vo.summary: Claire Vo shares how she’s accelerated her career from early product roles to becoming a multi-time CPO/CPTO by being explicit about what she wants, proactively creating solutions, and raising organizational “clock speed” without sacrificing quality. Listeners will learn practical tactics for career agency, operating large companies with startup-like speed, and how AI tools like ChatPRD may reshape PM skills and expectations.
notable_frameworks: Increase organizational "clock speed" ("one click faster"; year -> half-year expectations)
Career agency playbook (know what you want, ask clearly, make it easy for your boss with an org chart/JD/rollout plan)
CPTO model (unifying product + engineering + design under one leader; optimize for the organization vs functional debates)

crystal-w.title: How to scrappily hire for, measure, and unlock growth | Crystal Widjaja, Gojek and Kumu
crystal-w.summary: Crystal Widjaja shares lessons from building early data, risk, and growth functions at Gojek (now part of GoTo) and leading product at Kumu, highlighting how to unlock growth in large-scale Southeast Asian consumer businesses. Listeners will learn how foundational analytics and operational problem-solving (e.g., supply acquisition at scale) enable sustainable growth, and what to look for when taking a bet on an early-stage startup.

dalton-caldwell.title: Lessons from 1,000+ YC startups: Resilience, tar pit ideas, pivoting, more | Dalton Caldwell (YC)
dalton-caldwell.summary: Dalton Caldwell shares hard-earned lessons from working with 1,000+ YC startups, emphasizing that the most important founder skill is resilience—continuing through repeated “near-death” moments when rationally it feels like you should quit. Listeners will learn practical heuristics for not running out of money, recognizing when to persist vs. shut down, and how strong pivots often come from returning to a domain where founders have real expertise rather than chasing abstract, popular ideas.
notable_frameworks: How Not To Die ("don't die" / endurance as the core startup strategy)
Tarpit ideas (problems that seem unsolved and attract praise but repeatedly fail for decades)
Pivoting as "going home" (pivots work best when they move closer to founder expertise)

dan-hockenmaier.title: Developing a growth model + marketplace growth strategy | Dan Hockenmaier
dan-hockenmaier.summary: Dan Hockenmaier breaks down how to build and use a “growth model” (often a spreadsheet-based representation of how a business grows) to force clarity on what actually drives outcomes and to evaluate opportunities. He also shares hard-won lessons from scaling marketplaces, emphasizing the need for a light touch when changing incentives because small interventions can create delayed, hard-to-debug ecosystem effects.
notable_frameworks: Growth model (spreadsheet-based analytical representation of how the business grows)
Marketplace-as-a-garden vs SaaS-as-construction mental model

dan-shipper.title: The AI-native startup: 5 products, 7-figure revenue, 100% AI-written code. | Dan Shipper (Every)
dan-shipper.summary: Dan Shipper shares how Every operates as an AI-native company—using AI agents and dedicated AI operations to dramatically increase employee leverage across editorial and product work, including building products with effectively no hand-written code. Listeners will learn practical ways to use agentic tools (e.g., Claude Code/CLI-style agents) for autonomous, multi-step work on large corpuses of files, plus contrarian perspectives on AI’s impact on jobs and organizational productivity.
notable_frameworks: AI operations (dedicated role/function for prompts and workflows)
Agentic workflows (autonomous, multi-step agents; parallel sub-agents via CLI tools)

daniel-lereya.title: Daniel Lereya
daniel-lereya.summary: Daniel Lereya (CPTO at Monday.com) shares how a shocking competitive benchmark—seeing a rival ship 30 major product building blocks while Monday shipped one every four months—forced the team to rethink how they build, prioritize, and execute. Listeners will learn how Monday used radical transparency, impact-focused thinking, and ambitious goals to transform their shipping velocity and repeatedly “platformize” product development (columns, dashboards, automations) to unlock scale.
notable_frameworks: Radical transparency (company-wide information sharing)
Impact orientation (optimize for validated impact vs. output/features)
Competitive benchmarking as a forcing function (using competitors to set belief/possibility bounds)
Ambitious goal-setting to drive constraint-based innovation (e.g., 25 columns in one month)
Platform/building-blocks approach (scaling via reusable primitives like columns, widgets, automations)

david-placek.title: Building a culture of excellence | David Singleton (CTO of Stripe)
david-placek.summary: David Placek, founder of Lexicon Branding, explains why a company or product name is one of the most enduring strategic assets and why teams almost never “know it when they see it.” Listeners learn how strong names often feel uncomfortable at first, why polarization and debate can be a positive signal, and how to push past comfort-seeking instincts to choose bolder, more distinctive names (illustrated with stories like Sonos).
notable_frameworks: Polarization/tension as a positive signal of name strength ("if your team is comfortable with the name, you don't have it yet")
Name selection mindset shift: naming for the marketplace/customer vs. naming for internal comfort
Discomfort principle: avoiding comfort-seeking to achieve distinctiveness ("no power in comfort")

david-singleton.title: Building a culture of excellence | David Singleton (CTO of Stripe)
david-singleton.summary: David Singleton (CTO of Stripe) explains how Stripe builds products by deeply partnering with a small set of early customers to co-create solutions, using Stripe Billing as a key example. Listeners will learn how Stripe’s mission-driven, user-guided approach shapes a highly product-minded engineering organization and influences how they attract and hire top talent.
notable_frameworks: Co-creation with early users (alpha cohort approach)
Developer-centric product development

deb-liu.title: Succeeding as an introvert, building zero-to-one, and PM’ing your career like a product | Deb Liu
deb-liu.summary: Deb Liu shares tactical career advice rooted in a product mindset—treating your career like a product by defining what success looks like, iterating through learning loops, and balancing learning with impact. She also explains how introverts can succeed by reframing “self-promotion” as educating others about their team’s work, and why resilience and strong support at home can be career accelerators. Listeners will learn practical ways to choose roles, grow into jobs they don’t yet fully qualify for, and build influence without changing their personality.
notable_frameworks: PM your career like a product (write a career spec: define success, plan how to get there)
Learning vs. impact balancing loop (alternate mastery/impact with newbie/learning phases)
Reframing self-promotion as education/visibility for team impact and resourcing

dhanji-r-prasanna.title: How Block is becoming the most AI-native enterprise in the world | Dhanji R. Prasanna
dhanji-r-prasanna.summary: Dhanji Prasanna, CTO of Block, shares how Block is pushing to become an AI-native enterprise—shifting culture, operating model, and tooling so AI agents actively build alongside humans. Listeners will learn what adoption looks like at scale (including Block’s internal agent “Goose”), where the biggest productivity gains are showing up (often outside engineering), and what organizational changes help companies ride rapid AI capability improvements rather than treat AI as a one-off tool rollout.
notable_frameworks: AI-native enterprise (operating model where AI agents work continuously and proactively, not just as assistive tools)
Internal open-source agent platform approach ("Goose" as a shared, company-wide capability)

dharmesh-shah.title: Zigging vs. zagging: How HubSpot built a $30B company | Dharmesh Shah (co-founder/CTO)
dharmesh-shah.summary: Dharmesh Shah shares contrarian lessons from building HubSpot into a $30B company, including how and why they intentionally “zigged” against common startup advice and what that meant for product and company strategy. Listeners will learn how he leans hard into strengths (e.g., avoiding people management entirely), how HubSpot approached defining and scaling culture, and how he applies an engineer’s process mindset to communication—down to measuring “laughs per minute” to improve keynote talks.
notable_frameworks: Zigging vs. zagging (contrarian strategy)
Talent vs. skill (talent affects learning slope; skills are acquirable)
Functional decomposition / process-driven skill building (engineering approach to learning)
LPM (laughs per minute) as a talk-quality metric

dmitry-zlokazov.title: How Revolut trains world-class PMs: The “Local CEO” model, raw intellect & building wow products
dmitry-zlokazov.summary: Dmitry Zlokazov, Global Head of Product at Revolut, explains how Revolut develops world-class product leaders by treating PMs as true end-to-end “local CEOs” with real ownership over outcomes and execution. Listeners will learn Revolut’s approach to hiring for raw intellect and builder hunger over domain experience, and why they prioritize shipping fewer features with uncompromising UX quality to reduce uncertainty when testing new ideas.
notable_frameworks: “Local CEO” (PM as end-to-end business owner) model
Dual-management structure (line manager vs functional manager)
Quality-first MVP principle (reduce scope, never compromise UX/quality)
“99% done is closer to 0% than 100%” execution standard

donna-lichaw.title: How to discover your superpowers, own your story, and unlock personal growth | Donna Lichaw
donna-lichaw.summary: Donna Lichaw explains how leadership growth comes from understanding and reshaping the stories we tell ourselves, not just learning external communication techniques. Listeners will learn how to identify their “superpowers” (and “kryptonite”) by mining their past and present stories, then apply those insights to lead with more confidence, influence, and alignment with their mission.
notable_frameworks: Story-driven leadership
The Leader’s Journey (hero’s-journey-inspired leadership framework)
Superpowers and kryptonite (strengths-and-derailers identification via personal stories)

dr-fei-fei-li.title: The Godmother of AI on jobs, robots & why world models are next | Dr. Fei-Fei Li
dr-fei-fei-li.summary: Dr. Fei-Fei Li explains how modern AI’s recent breakthroughs were catalyzed by the shift toward data-driven learning (exemplified by ImageNet) and why AI’s trajectory is ultimately shaped by human choices rather than inevitability. Listeners will learn her human-centered view of AI’s benefits and risks, why “there’s nothing artificial about AI,” and why she believes the next frontier is building “world models” that better capture how the physical world works.
notable_frameworks: Human-centered AI ("there’s nothing artificial about AI"—AI is created by and impacts people)
Technology as a double-edged sword (net-positive potential + societal responsibility)

drew-houston.title: Behind the founder | Drew Houston (Dropbox)
drew-houston.summary: Drew Houston walks through the real, non-linear founder journey of building Dropbox over 18 years—starting with explosive early growth, moving into a brutal competitive era as Apple/Microsoft/Google attacked the category, and arriving at a third phase of rethinking Dropbox’s strategy and identity. Listeners learn how Dropbox found early product-market fit and viral growth, what it feels like to have your business model threatened by platform incumbents, and how hard strategic focus decisions (killing products, going all-in on a new direction) ripple through morale, culture, and leadership.
notable_frameworks: Guerrilla Marketing (doing marketing with little/no budget)
“Focus on one customer (yourself)” as an early product discovery heuristic

dylan-field.title: Figma’s CEO: Why AI makes design, craft, and quality the new moat for startups | Dylan Field
dylan-field.summary: Dylan Field discusses how AI will dramatically increase the amount of software being created, making design, craft, and quality bigger competitive moats for startups and products. He shares how he develops product taste and intuition (as a way to generate and test hypotheses), and how Figma tries to operationalize simplicity while scaling a complex product and community.
notable_frameworks: Intuition as a hypothesis generator (treating intuition as inputs to be tested rather than unquestioned truth)
Design as "art applied to problem solving" (balancing creative expression with user needs)
Simplicity as an operational principle (ongoing simplification as a deliberate, repeatable practice)

dylan-field-20.title: Dylan Field live at Figma's Config: Intuition, simplicity, and the future of design
dylan-field-20.summary: Dylan Field shares lessons from building Figma over 13 years, emphasizing that “good enough” is no longer competitive and that craft and design differentiation are essential to winning in software. He explains how Figma maintained momentum after the Adobe acquisition fell through—through frequent communication, a clear reset moment, and an optional severance “Detach” program—then accelerated execution into major launches. The episode also explores how AI is changing product building (e.g., PMs prototyping directly), what good product taste looks like, and how Figma approaches launching new product lines like FigJam and Figma Make.
notable_frameworks: “Detach” program (optional 3-month severance + reapply later as a post-reset alignment mechanism)
Differentiation through design/craft as a competitive strategy ("good enough is not enough")
Make the product’s “soul”/fun a deliberate differentiator (FigJam positioning decision)

ebi-atawodi.title: Crafting a compelling product vision | Ebi Atawodi (YouTube, Netflix, Uber)
ebi-atawodi.summary: Ebi Atawodi breaks down how to craft a compelling product vision that aligns teams and executives, distinguishing vision from mission and explaining what makes a vision motivating and actionable. Listeners will learn a practical set of criteria for strong visions (lofty yet attainable, unconstrained by today’s limitations, grounded in a clear user problem) and how great product leaders use vision to drive product strategy and culture.
notable_frameworks: Vision vs. Mission distinction
Four-part product vision criteria (lofty, realistic/attainable, unconstrained by today’s limitations, grounded in a clear user problem)

edwin-chen.title: The $1B Al company training ChatGPT, Claude & Gemini on the path to responsible AGI | Edwin Chen
edwin-chen.summary: Edwin Chen explains how Surge AI built a $1B+ revenue business in under four years with a sub-100-person, elite team—bootstrapped and largely invisible on social media—by focusing on product quality and researcher-driven word of mouth rather than the typical Silicon Valley fundraising/PR playbook. He argues that “data quality” is the core bottleneck in frontier AI and that the values embedded in training and evaluation shape model behavior, warning that the industry risks optimizing models for dopamine-driven “AI slop” instead of truth and human progress.
notable_frameworks: Small, elite team model ("fire 90%" to reduce distraction and increase speed)
Bootstrapped, product-first vs. VC/PR-driven Silicon Valley playbook
Model-behavior optimization lens (optimize for user time/productivity vs. endless iteration/engagement)
Values-shape-the-model principle (training/evaluation data encodes organizational values)

eeke-de-milliano.title: How to foster innovation and big thinking | Eeke de Milliano (Retool, Stripe)
eeke-de-milliano.summary: Eeke de Milliano shares lessons from building foundational products at Stripe and leading product at Retool, focusing on how to preserve innovation and “big thinking” as organizations scale. Listeners will learn how to balance process vs. creativity, what Stripe’s culture did to enable high-leverage product bets, and practical approaches to building teams and products in complex domains like marketplaces and fraud.
notable_frameworks: Process as variance reduction (tradeoff: raising the floor vs. lowering the ceiling)

elena-verna.title: 10 growth tactics that never work | Elena Verna (Amplitude, Miro, Dropbox, SurveyMonkey)
elena-verna.summary: Elena Verna breaks down a set of common “growth tactics” that teams repeatedly invest in but that rarely produce meaningful results, explaining why they fail and what to do instead. Listeners will learn how to avoid premature growth hiring, misguided rebrands/redesigns, and unhealthy over-reliance on experimentation, plus how to use practical growth frameworks to diagnose and drive sustainable B2B growth.
notable_frameworks: 10 growth tactics that never work (anti-patterns list)
Growth frameworks for structuring and diagnosing growth (three favorites, unnamed in provided excerpt)

elena-verna-20.title: The ultimate guide to product-led sales | Elena Verna
elena-verna-20.summary: Elena Verna breaks down what product-led sales (PLS) is and how it differs from product-led growth (PLG) and traditional sales-led motions. Listeners learn why PLS requires product to own pipeline creation, how sales and product must collaborate differently, and why trying to “do PLS in marketing” is a common failure mode—especially as self-serve monetization hits limits for larger deal sizes.
notable_frameworks: PLG vs self-serve monetization vs sales-assisted monetization (product-led sales framing)
Product creates pipeline for sales (PLS operating model)

elena-verna-30.title: The ultimate guide to product-led sales | Elena Verna
elena-verna-30.summary: Elena Verna breaks down common “growth tactics” and initiatives that repeatedly fail in B2B SaaS—especially when teams chase trendy hacks, rebrands, or constant experimentation without a clear strategy. Listeners will learn how to avoid premature growth hiring, focus on fundamentals like product-market fit and distribution, and use practical growth frameworks to diagnose where growth is actually coming from and what to do next.
notable_frameworks: Insights per minute (as a communication/meeting effectiveness heuristic)

elena-verna-40.title: The new AI growth playbook for 2026 | How Lovable hit $200M ARR in one year
elena-verna-40.summary: Elena Verna, Head of Growth at Lovable, explains how AI-native companies are forcing a rewrite of the traditional growth playbook—shifting from incremental optimization to constant reinvention of new growth loops. Listeners will learn what’s actually driving Lovable’s hypergrowth to $200M+ ARR in ~1 year, including “building in public,” founder/employee-led distribution, and aggressively lowering barriers to trial by giving the product away to catalyze word-of-mouth.
notable_frameworks: Build in public (as a growth loop)
Founder-led and employee-led social distribution
Remove barrier to entry / give product away to drive trial
Word-of-mouth loop driven by “blow their socks off” product moments
PMF as a recurring recapture cycle ("every ~3 months")

eli-schwartz.title: Rethinking SEO in the age of AI | Eli Schwartz (SEO advisor, author)
eli-schwartz.summary: Eli Schwartz explains how SEO is changing as Google and other search engines increasingly surface AI-generated answers (e.g., AI Overviews), reducing clicks to traditional “blue link” results and forcing teams to rethink what SEO traffic is for. Listeners will learn why SEO should be treated as a product problem (not a content/keyword hack), how to identify search journeys worth targeting, and how to adapt strategy as search engines balance AI answers with monetization and user needs.
notable_frameworks: Product-led SEO (treating SEO as a product discipline)
SEO as a product (PM-led approach to search discovery and positioning)

elizabeth-stone.title: How Netflix builds a culture of excellence | Elizabeth Stone (CTO)
elizabeth-stone.summary: Elizabeth Stone (Netflix CTO) explains how Netflix’s culture is intentionally built on high talent density as the foundation for candor, learning, and “freedom and responsibility.” She also shares how her economics training shapes her leadership—especially around incentives and unintended consequences—and what changed for her moving from VP of Data & Insights to CTO (more context switching, broader technical scope, and higher-consequence decisions).
notable_frameworks: High talent density as a prerequisite for Netflix culture
Freedom & Responsibility (Netflix cultural model)
Incentives and unintended consequences (economic lens for org/strategy decisions)

emilie-gerber.title: The ultimate guide to PR | Emilie Gerber (founder of Six Eastern)
emilie-gerber.summary: Emilie Gerber breaks down how startups can approach PR in a highly tactical way—how to find a compelling “nugget” in your story, choose the right outlets, and pitch reporters effectively. Listeners will learn why press often matters less for immediate signups and more for second-order effects like credibility in sales, recruiting, and partnerships, plus when PR can directly drive growth (especially for low-friction consumer products).
notable_frameworks: Second-order effects of press (credibility flywheel across sales, recruiting, partnerships)
“Nugget”/pattern-matching approach to simplifying startup narratives for media

emily-kramer.title: How to build a powerful marketing machine | Emily Kramer (Asana, Carta, MKT1)
emily-kramer.summary: Emily Kramer breaks down how to build an effective marketing function at B2B startups, focusing on how to think about marketing as a system and how to hire the right early marketing roles. Listeners will learn practical guidance on choosing marketing archetypes based on business model, building the right “engine” to distribute and measure work, and common hiring mistakes founders make when staffing marketing too early or too narrowly.
notable_frameworks: Fuel vs. Engine model for marketing (create value vs. distribute/measure it)
Marketing archetypes (generalist vs. specialist; role selection by business model)

eoghan-mccabe.title: How Intercom rose from the ashes by betting everything on AI | Eoghan McCabe (founder and CEO)
eoghan-mccabe.summary: Eoghan McCabe shares how Intercom reversed a late-stage SaaS growth stall by going “wartime,” rebuilding culture, and betting the company on an AI agent (Fin). Listeners will learn what triggered the pivot, how Intercom executed a rapid AI product build and go-to-market shift, and what tough leadership decisions (including major org turnover) were required to make the transformation stick.
notable_frameworks: Wartime company / wartime CEO mindset
Founder mode (hardcore founder-led turnaround)
Values as an execution tool (rewriting values to drive behavior and remove misalignment)
Benchmarking against public SaaS peers (relative growth percentile as a management yardstick)

eoy-review.title: Countdown of the top 10 episodes of the year
eoy-review.summary: In this year-end countdown episode, Lenny revisits the most popular podcast episodes and highlights the most actionable clips from each. The featured segments focus on how to position products effectively against real competitive alternatives (including the status quo) and why many analytics programs fail by confusing measurement with insight and treating dashboards as “entertainment” instead of decision-changing information. Listeners learn practical, step-by-step approaches to positioning and instrumentation that lead to clearer differentiation and more actionable product decisions.
notable_frameworks: April Dunford’s 5-step positioning process (competitive alternatives  differentiated capabilities  value themes  best-fit customers  market category/context)
Competitive alternatives (including status quo / “no decision” as a primary competitor)
Measurement vs. insight mental model (data as decision-changing “news,” not “entertainment”)

eric-ries.title: Reflections on a movement | Eric Ries (creator of the Lean Startup methodology)
eric-ries.summary: Eric Ries reflects on what the Lean Startup movement got right, what’s been misunderstood, and what he would change if he could redo its rollout. Listeners will learn how to think more clearly about MVPs, experimentation, metrics, and pivots—while also considering founder mental health, values, and governance as core inputs to building enduring companies, especially in an AI-shaped future.
notable_frameworks: Lean Startup methodology
Minimum Viable Product (MVP)
Build-Measure-Learn feedback loop
Pivot (as a structured change in strategy)
Innovation accounting
Vanity metrics vs actionable metrics
Continuous deployment
A/B testing / split testing
Customer development

eric-simons.title: Inside Bolt: From near-death to one of the fastest-growing products in history | Eric Simons
eric-simons.summary: Eric Simons shares how StackBlitz nearly ran out of money, then launched Bolt—an in-browser AI “text-to-app” builder—that exploded from $0 to ~$20M ARR in two months and is tracking toward ~$100M ARR within a year. Listeners will learn what made this hypergrowth possible (team, prior technical bets like WebContainers, and contrarian timing), and what it’s like to scale users, revenue, and support with a very small team.
notable_frameworks: Contrarian conviction / non-consensus decision-making (making judgment calls against the consensus)

ethan-evans.title: Taking control of your career | Ethan Evans (Amazon)
