ethan-evans.summary: Ethan Evans shares practical, repeatable tactics for taking control of your career—especially how to build momentum toward promotions and better opportunities by aligning your work with your manager’s needs. Listeners will learn the “Magic Loop” (a five-step approach to earning trust, expanding scope, and negotiating growth) and why sustained execution matters more than constantly generating new ideas.
notable_frameworks: The Magic Loop (do your job well → ask how to help → do it → align help with your goals → repeat)

ethan-evans-20.title: Taking control of your career | Ethan Evans (Amazon)
ethan-evans-20.summary: Ethan Evans shares practical, manager-tested tactics for taking control of your career growth, centered on building trust and leverage with your manager through a repeatable “Magic Loop.” Listeners will learn how to consistently earn bigger opportunities, align day-to-day work with longer-term goals (like promotions or role changes), and why a small number of strong ideas—well executed over time—can create outsized impact.
notable_frameworks: The Magic Loop (do your job well → ask how to help → do it → align help with your goals → repeat)

ethan-smith.title: The ultimate guide to AEO: How to get ChatGPT to recommend your product | Ethan Smith (Graphite)
ethan-smith.summary: Ethan Smith breaks down Answer Engine Optimization (AEO)—how to get your brand and product recommended inside LLM answers (ChatGPT, Claude, Gemini, Perplexity) as search shifts from blue links to AI summaries. He explains why AEO is more about earning broad, repeated mentions across many sources (not just ranking #1), why early-stage companies can win quickly via new citation surfaces (Reddit, YouTube, blogs), and why LLM-referred traffic can convert significantly better than traditional search traffic.
notable_frameworks: Answer Engine Optimization (AEO) / Generative Engine Optimization (GEO) as LLM visibility optimization
Mention/citation frequency over single-rank positioning (LLM answers as multi-source summaries)

evan-lapointe.title: Improve strategy, influence, and decision-making by understanding your brain | Evan LaPointe
evan-lapointe.summary: Evan LaPointe explains a practical model of how the brain works—different “departments” and three core systems (safety, reward, purpose)—and how these shape the quality of our thinking, creativity, and collaboration. Listeners will learn how to recognize when they (or others) are operating from threat or transactional modes, and how to intentionally shift into more open, creative, and purpose-driven states to improve strategy, influence, meetings, and team relationships.
notable_frameworks: Brain as a college campus (departments: history vs science vs art/humanities)
Three brain systems model: safety system, reward system, purpose system
Pathways and intentional steering (default thought pathways vs deliberate activation)

failure.title: Failure
failure.summary: This compilation episode focuses on what product and design leaders can learn from failure—especially the kind that happens publicly or early in a leadership role. Listeners will learn how trust, listening, and communication determine whether change efforts succeed, and how to recover from high-stakes mistakes while continuing to lead effectively.
notable_frameworks: Trust-building through listening-first leadership ("come in listening, not swinging")
Change management: bringing people along vs. inflicting change

fareed-mosavat.title: How to build trust and grow as a product leader | Fareed Mosavat (Reforge, Slack, Instacart, Pixar)
fareed-mosavat.summary: Fareed Mosavat shares what it actually takes to become a great product leader: doing real work on real products, accelerating your learning loop through more (and better) reps, and building trust by consistently delivering outcomes. Listeners will learn how to think about the IC-to-manager transition, how to expand scope and earn more responsibility, and how to stay anchored on the end customer experience rather than internal artifacts like strategy docs.
notable_frameworks: Learning loop / reps-based skill development (accelerating improvement through real-world execution)
Outcome-over-artifacts mindset (optimize for end user experience vs. perfect internal docs/models)

farhan-thawar.title: How Shopify builds a high-intensity culture | Farhan Thawar (VP and Head of Eng)
farhan-thawar.summary: Farhan Thawar (VP, Head of Engineering at Shopify) shares how Shopify sustains a high-intensity, high-urgency engineering culture at scale—especially in a fully remote environment—through deliberate operating rhythms, meeting discipline, and practices that drive focus and velocity. Listeners will learn why he advocates “choosing the hard path” for compounding learning and career advantage, plus practical approaches to hiring and developing engineers in a demanding, high-performance culture.
notable_frameworks: Choose the hard path (compounding learning mental model)
Delete Code Club (systematic simplification / code deletion practice)
Pair programming (as a leverage mechanism for intensity and quality)

fei-fei.title: The Godmother of AI on jobs, robots & why world models are next | Dr. Fei-Fei Li
fei-fei.summary: Dr. Fei-Fei Li explains how modern AI’s breakthrough moment came from pairing better learning approaches with massive, high-quality labeled data (e.g., ImageNet), and why the field shifted from “AI” being a risky label to becoming central to nearly every company. She argues AI’s impacts on jobs and society are real but not predetermined—outcomes depend on human choices, responsibility, and governance—and previews why “world models” are a key next frontier for AI and robotics.
notable_frameworks: Human-centered AI ("there's nothing artificial about AI"—AI is created by and impacts people)
Data-centric scaling approach (the idea that large, clean labeled datasets unlock capability gains—exemplified by ImageNet)
World models (as a next-step paradigm for building AI that understands and acts in the physical world)

garrett-lord.title: Inside the expert network training every frontier AI model | Garrett Lord
garrett-lord.summary: Garrett Lord explains how frontier AI labs have shifted from pre-training on the open internet to post-training, where most current model gains come from creating high-quality, expert-generated data (e.g., RLHF preference data, trajectories, multimodal tasks, and domain-specific prompt/response pairs). Listeners learn what “data labeling” actually entails in modern model development and why access to specialized expert audiences has become a key advantage in building a fast-growing AI data business.
notable_frameworks: Pre-training vs post-training model development
Scientific method / hypothesis-driven iteration for model improvement (collect small data → validate → scale collection)
RLHF (reinforcement learning with human feedback)
Benchmark-driven capability evaluation (domain benchmarks to track improvements)

gaurav-misra.title: Mastering onboarding | Lauryn Isford (Head of Growth at Airtable)
gaurav-misra.summary: Gaurav Misra shares how a modern AI-first consumer startup can move extremely fast while still building cohesive, marketable product—aiming for every engineer to ship something marketable every week and intentionally taking on technical debt to outpace larger companies. He also explains how Captions thinks about roadmapping in competitive markets (a public roadmap vs. a “secret” roadmap) and what it takes to earn attention and retention in an era where AI makes it easy to build impressive demos but hard to build enduring products.
notable_frameworks: Every engineer ships a marketable product every week
Intentional technical debt as a startup speed advantage
Two-roadmap model: public roadmap (user-requested) vs. secret roadmap (differentiators)

geoff-charles.title: Velocity over everything: How Ramp became the fastest-growing SaaS startup ever | Geoff Charles
geoff-charles.summary: Geoff Charles, VP of Product at Ramp, breaks down how Ramp operationalizes a culture of extreme velocity—shipping quickly, iterating from first principles, and empowering small teams to deliver outsized outcomes. Listeners will learn how Ramp structures product development, planning, strategy, and hiring to maintain speed without sacrificing quality, and how this approach enabled historically fast growth with a lean org.
notable_frameworks: Velocity-first operating model (optimize org/process/incentives for shipping speed)
First-principles thinking (reason from fundamentals vs. precedent)
Small autonomous teams / high ownership model (do more with fewer people)
Low-cost decisions to de-risk via fast iteration (reduce decision stakes by shipping)

geoffrey-moore.title: Geoffrey Moore on finding your beachhead, crossing the chasm, and dominating a market
geoffrey-moore.summary: Geoffrey Moore explains why startups trying to “cross the chasm” must focus on a narrowly defined beachhead market rather than chasing any customer for short-term revenue. Listeners will learn how market leadership in a small segment creates the credibility and ecosystem pull needed for repeatable go-to-market success, and why adjacency-based expansion (the “bowling pin” approach) beats scattered customer acquisition.
notable_frameworks: Crossing the Chasm (technology adoption lifecycle / chasm model)
Beachhead market selection
Bowling pin strategy (adjacent segment expansion)
Lighthouse customer concept
Fish-to-pond ratio (segment sizing for achievable leadership)
Ecosystem-driven market leadership (partners organize around leaders)

gergely.title: Leaving big tech to build the #1 technology newsletter | Gergely Orosz (The Pragmatic Engineer)
gergely.summary: Gergely Orosz shares how he went from a fast-rising engineering management career at Uber to building The Pragmatic Engineer into the #1 technology newsletter on Substack. Listeners learn what the day-to-day of running a paid newsletter business looks like, the tradeoffs versus big tech, and the key drivers behind his growth (including Substack recommendations) and monetization through subscriptions.
notable_frameworks: Substack freemium model (free audience + paid conversion)
Platform-driven growth via recommendations (distribution loop)

gia-laudi.title: Customer-led growth | Georgiana Laudi (Forget The Funnel)
gia-laudi.summary: Gia Laudi explains why traditional funnels and common SaaS metrics (e.g., MQLs/SQLs, even pirate metrics) often mislead teams by centering the business instead of the customer and by ignoring the pre-awareness “problem stage” and post-acquisition growth. Listeners learn a customer-led approach to growth that emphasizes identifying and realigning around an ideal customer, mapping the real customer journey end-to-end (including retention/expansion), and finding high-leverage conversion unlocks in key flows.
notable_frameworks: Customer-led growth (Forget The Funnel approach)
Critique/alternatives to funnels
Pirate metrics (AARRR) critique
MQL/SQL critique

gibson-biddle.title: 35 years of product design wisdom from Apple, Disney, Pinterest and beyond | Bob Baxley
gibson-biddle.summary: Gibson Biddle shares lessons from decades in product leadership (notably as VP Product at Netflix and later at Chegg) and how he’s translated those experiences into clear, teachable strategy and prioritization frameworks. Listeners will learn practical ways to think about product strategy, how to make it memorable and actionable, and how to apply it through real-world case studies from Netflix and beyond.
notable_frameworks: Product strategy framework (delight customers in hard-to-copy, margin-enhancing ways)
SWAG (stupid wild-ass guess)

gina-gotthilf.title: Scaling Duolingo, embracing failure, and insight into Latin America’s tech scene | Gina Gotthilf
gina-gotthilf.summary: Gina Gotthilf shares how Duolingo scaled from ~3M to 200M+ users largely through organic growth, strong brand/PR, and a distinctive product voice that makes users feel something and remember the message. She also unpacks lessons from running large-scale digital marketing (including the Bloomberg campaign), why embracing “B-side” failures is essential to career resilience, and what makes Latin America an increasingly important startup ecosystem.
notable_frameworks: A-side / B-side career narrative (highlights vs. failures as a resilience model)
Unique brand voice as a communication/positioning strategy (optimize for what the listener remembers and feels)

gokul-rajaram.title: Gokul Rajaram on designing your product development process, when and how to hire your first PM, a playbook for hiring leaders, getting ahead in your career, how to get started angel investing, and more
gokul-rajaram.summary: Gokul Rajaram shares how his career was shaped by serendipity, strong day-to-day execution, and proactively building relationships across a company—illustrated by how he discovered and became the PM for what turned into Google AdSense. Listeners will learn practical principles for choosing roles, creating opportunities through curiosity and “paying it forward,” and thinking in terms of problems to solve (and teams/culture) rather than just domains.
notable_frameworks: Serendipity-driven career building (optimize for curiosity, relationships, and seizing unexpected opportunities)
Pay-it-forward / goodwill reservoir (help others to build long-term reciprocal opportunity)
Problem-first orientation (choose work based on the problem and environment, not the domain label)

graham-weaver.title: How to break out of autopilot and create the life you want | Graham Weaver (Stanford GSB professor)
graham-weaver.summary: Graham Weaver shares practical ways to break out of “autopilot” and make more intentional life and career choices by surfacing what you truly want (vs. what you feel you should want). Listeners will learn exercises to clarify direction (e.g., imagining guaranteed success), how to push through the inevitable “worse first” phase of meaningful change, and how to identify and dismantle fears and limiting beliefs that keep them on the safe path.
notable_frameworks: Genie framework (imagining guaranteed success to reveal what you’d choose)
Nine lives exercise
“Everything you want is on the other side of worse first” (embracing short-term discomfort for long-term gains)
Autopilot vs. intentional living (diagnosing unconscious routines and default choices)

grant-lee.title: “Dumbest idea I’ve heard” to $100M ARR: Inside the rise of Gamma | Grant Lee (co-founder)
grant-lee.summary: Grant Lee, co-founder/CEO of Gamma, shares how the company went from being dismissed as a “dumb idea” competing with entrenched incumbents to building a profitable AI product business surpassing $100M ARR with a ~30-person team. Listeners will learn Gamma’s approach to rapidly iterating toward product-market fit through tight experiment loops and user observation, plus the growth playbook that helped them scale—especially a micro-influencer-driven strategy that created compounding word-of-mouth.
notable_frameworks: Rapid build-test-learn loop (morning prototype → afternoon live experiment → next-day fixes)
Micro-influencer seeding (manual onboarding + authentic creator voice vs scripted ads)

guillermo-rauch.title: Everyone’s an engineer now: Inside v0’s mission to create 100 million builders | Guillermo Rauch
guillermo-rauch.summary: Guillermo Rauch explains how AI tools like Vercel’s v0 are expanding who can build and ship software—enabling designers and PMs to become more “full stack” and prototype directly into production. He argues that while some traditional coding tasks become commoditized, understanding how software works under the hood and developing strong product “taste” through high exposure to real user behavior will become key differentiators. Listeners will learn how AI is reshaping product development workflows, what skills will matter most, and why the future is software that builds software.
notable_frameworks: Increasing exposure hours (operating principle for building taste)
AI becomes synonymous with software ("software builds software")
Full-stack-by-default builders (designers/PMs shipping to production)

gustaf-alstromer.title: Lessons from working with 600+ YC startups | Gustaf Alströmer (Y Combinator, Airbnb)
gustaf-alstromer.summary: Gustaf Alströmer shares lessons from working with hundreds of Y Combinator startups, emphasizing that the most common cause of failure is not talking to users—leading to a lack of product-market fit. He also reflects on what made Airbnb uniquely special early on, highlighting how intentional hiring, strong culture alignment, and founder-like teammates shaped decision-making and execution.
notable_frameworks: Make things people want
Culture interviews

gustav-s\u00f6derstr\u00f6m.title: The science of product, big bets, and how AI is impacting the future of music | Gustav Söderström
gustav-s\u00f6derstr\u00f6m.summary: Gustav Söderström, Spotify’s co-president and CPO/CTO, shares how Spotify has repeatedly reinvented its product as the internet shifted from user curation to algorithmic recommendation—and why the next major shift will be toward generation via AI. Listeners will learn how Spotify approaches big product bets, how its org structure has evolved beyond the famous “squads” model, and how AI is already reshaping product strategy and the future of music creation.
notable_frameworks: Curation → Recommendation → Generation (internet/product evolution model)
“Magic trick” principle for great products (products need a core moment of perceived magic)

hamel-husain-shreya-shankar.title: Why AI evals are the hottest new skill for product builders | Hamel Husain & Shreya Shankar
hamel-husain-shreya-shankar.summary: Hamel Husain and Shreya Shankar explain why building strong AI evaluations (“evals”) is the highest-ROI way to systematically improve LLM products beyond ad-hoc “vibe checks.” Listeners learn what evals are in practice, common misconceptions (including why you can’t just have AI evaluate everything), and pragmatic tactics for creating actionable metrics and workflows that help teams iterate confidently without making the process too heavy.
notable_frameworks: Vibe checks vs. systematic evals (progression from ad-hoc testing to measurable quality)
Unit tests as a partial metaphor for evals (non-negotiable behaviors vs. open-ended quality)
Benevolent dictator model for eval design (avoid committee-driven labeling/coding)

hamelshreya.title: Why AI evals are the hottest new skill for product builders | Hamel Husain & Shreya Shankar
hamelshreya.summary: Hamel Husain and Shreya Shankar explain why building strong AI evaluations (“evals”) is one of the highest-ROI skills for shipping reliable LLM products. Listeners learn what evals are in practice (beyond “unit tests”), why teams get misled by vibe checks or poorly designed evals, and how to set up actionable measurement loops that let you iterate on prompts, tools, and system behavior with confidence.
notable_frameworks: Evals as a systematic measurement-and-improvement loop for LLM applications (data analytics + targeted metrics)
Vibe checks vs. scalable evaluation (when informal testing breaks down)
“Benevolent dictator” model for labeling/judgment to avoid committee gridlock
Unit tests as a subset of evals (for non-negotiable behaviors) vs. broader quality measurement for open-ended tasks

hamilton-helmer.title: Business strategy with Hamilton Helmer (author of 7 Powers)
hamilton-helmer.summary: Hamilton Helmer explains how to think about durable competitive advantage (“power”) and why founders should consider strategy much earlier than the traditional “PMF first, strategy later” approach. Listeners will learn how to evaluate whether a startup idea is likely to support a defensible moat, how “power progression” changes what advantages are available at different stages, and why operational excellence alone is rarely a true source of lasting advantage.
notable_frameworks: 7 Powers (benefit + barrier framework for durable competitive advantage)
Power progression (timing/stage-based availability of different powers)
Moats / “economic castle” metaphor (Buffett)

hari-srinivasan.title: LinkedIn’s product evolution and the art of building complex systems | Hari Srinivasan (LinkedIn)
hari-srinivasan.summary: Hari Srinivasan, VP of Product for LinkedIn Talent Solutions, discusses how LinkedIn has evolved its products and ecosystem to better connect members to economic opportunity—especially through shifts in the hiring market during COVID. Listeners will learn about skills-first hiring, how LinkedIn thinks about building and operating complex interconnected systems (like the feed + jobs + learning loop), and practical ways to improve job-search outcomes on LinkedIn.
notable_frameworks: skills-first hiring (skills-based matching vs title-based matching)
ecosystem / systems thinking for interconnected products (feed + network + opportunity)

heidi-helfand.title: The art and wisdom of changing teams | Heidi Helfand (Author of Dynamic Reteaming)
heidi-helfand.summary: Heidi Helfand explains why team change (reorgs/reteaming) is a normal, often beneficial part of building companies—especially in fast-growing startups—and why the “people layer” deserves as much intentional design as product delivery. Listeners will learn how to approach reteaming more transparently, involve teams in the design of org changes, and use change as a lever for better outcomes like reduced silos and stronger career opportunities.
notable_frameworks: Dynamic Reteaming
Five types of reteaming
Forming–Storming–Norming–Performing (Tuckman model)
Participatory reorg design using visualized team structures (whiteboard-based org design)

hila-qu.title: The ultimate guide to adding a PLG motion | Hila Qu (Reforge, GitLab)
hila-qu.summary: Hila Qu breaks down how to add a product-led growth (PLG) motion to a B2B SaaS business, emphasizing that effective PLG is fundamentally data-led growth: you must instrument, analyze, and learn from free-user behavior to drive conversion and retention. Listeners will learn why most companies ultimately need both PLG and sales-led motions, how PLG expands reach via low-friction trials, and why adding PLG later is harder for traditionally sales-led companies.
notable_frameworks: Product-led growth (PLG)
Data-led growth (DLG) as the foundation for PLG
Hybrid GTM: combining PLG and sales-led motions

hilary-gridley.title: How to build a team that can “take a punch” | Hilary Gridley (Head of Core Product, Whoop)
hilary-gridley.summary: Hilary Gridley shares practical leadership tactics for helping product teams build resilience—learning to “take a punch” when projects fail, feedback stings, or uncertainty (like layoffs and AI disruption) creates anxiety. Listeners will learn how to coach people away from rumination and toward concrete actions that reshape narratives, and how to create a culture where taking on hard, high-stakes problems (even with a high chance of failure) is both supported and expected.
notable_frameworks: “Take a punch” (resilience training for handling setbacks and criticism)
“Counter-program the narrative” (shift from litigating perceptions to taking actions that demonstrate who you are)

howie-liu.title: How we restructured Airtable's entire org for AI | Howie Liu (co-founder and CEO)
howie-liu.summary: Howie Liu shares how Airtable is reinventing itself for the AI era, including what it means for CEOs and product teams to become more hands-on and “AI-native” in how they build. Listeners will learn how Airtable restructured its org to accelerate AI execution (including a fast/slow thinking split), what new skills PMs/designers/engineers need, and how to navigate the existential pressure of rethinking a mature product and company in a rapidly changing market.
notable_frameworks: IC CEO (CEO as individual contributor)
Fast-thinking vs slow-thinking org structure (two-speed organization)
“If founding today with AI-native approach” test (rebuild-from-scratch thought experiment)

ian-mcallister.title: What it takes to become a top 1% PM | Ian McAllister (Uber, Amazon, Airbnb)
ian-mcallister.summary: Ian McAllister shares what differentiates top 1% product managers from top 10% PMs, emphasizing impact-first thinking, strong judgment, and clear communication. He also explains Amazon’s “working backwards” approach—how to use PR/FAQ-style writing to clarify customer value, align teams, and make better product decisions faster.
notable_frameworks: Working Backwards (Amazon PR/FAQ process)

inbal-s.title: The future of AI in software development | Inbal Shani (CPO of GitHub)
inbal-s.summary: Inbal Shani (CPO of GitHub) shares how AI coding tools like Copilot are reshaping software development—augmenting, not replacing, engineers—and why developers will need to shift from primarily writing code to thinking more in systems, architecture, and product context. She also highlights what’s overhyped (AI replacing humans) and what’s underhyped (AI-driven testing across the SDLC), and what this implies for junior developer growth and developer productivity.
notable_frameworks: Copilot as “copilot, not pilot” (human-in-the-loop model)

interview-q-compilation.title: I’ve run 75+ businesses. Here’s why you’re probably chasing the wrong idea. | Andrew Wilkinson
interview-q-compilation.summary: This compilation episode curates standout interview questions from past Lenny’s Podcast guests and explains what strong answers reveal about candidates. Listeners will learn practical ways to assess self-awareness, resilience, problem-solving, and decision-making under ambiguity—plus how to design interview prompts that surface signal quickly.
notable_frameworks: Eigenquestion test (identify the 1–2 highest-leverage questions under uncertainty)
Quadrant/2x2 scenario planning (using two key variables to map go-to-market options)

itamar-gilad.title: Becoming evidence-guided | Itamar Gilad (Gmail, YouTube, Microsoft)
itamar-gilad.summary: Itamar Gilad shares how his experience at Google—especially the contrast between the large, opinion-driven push behind Google+ and more evidence-seeking work inside Gmail—shaped his approach to building products under uncertainty. Listeners will learn practical ways to move from “plan-and-execute” and intuition-led decisions to evidence-guided product development using lightweight experiments and clearer decision criteria.
notable_frameworks: Evidence-Guided product development
Fake door tests
Smoke tests
Wizard of Oz tests
Fail fast
Plan-and-execute (as an anti-pattern)
Confidence meter
Metrics trees
GIST
GIST board
ICE prioritization (and common misuses)
OKRs (improving effectiveness)

ivan-zhao.title: Notion's lost years, near collapse during COVID, staying small to move fast, building horizontal
ivan-zhao.summary: Ivan Zhao shares how Notion spent its first 3–4 years in “lost years,” iterating through multiple product directions before finding product-market fit by packaging a deeper vision (end-user software creation) inside a form factor people already want (productivity software—“sugar-coated broccoli”). Listeners will learn how Ivan balances personal taste/values with business fundamentals (users + revenue), and how he thinks about tools as extensions of humans that ultimately shape how we work and think.
notable_frameworks: “Sugar-coated broccoli” (packaging a hard-to-sell vision inside a desirable, familiar product form)
Balance of values/taste vs. business fundamentals (users + revenue) to avoid “art project” vs. “commodity” extremes
Tools-as-extensions-of-humans feedback loop (we shape tools; tools shape us)

jackie-bavaro.title: Bending the universe in your favor | Claire Vo (LaunchDarkly, Color, Optimizely, ChatPRD)
jackie-bavaro.summary: Jackie Bavaro shares hard-won lessons on what strong product strategy actually is, how to tell good strategy from bad, and a practical approach to building strategy that helps you make better decisions and align teams. She also draws on her experience as Asana’s first PM (eventually leading product) and as a longtime interviewer/author to explain how PMs can level up their careers—especially by improving how they communicate, prioritize, and perform in interviews.
notable_frameworks: Structured interview answering (e.g., clear, numbered, top-down responses)
Product design interview framing (identify user/customer first, then needs, then solution)

jackson-shuttleworth.title: Behind the product: Duolingo streaks | Jackson Shuttleworth (Group PM, Retention Team)
jackson-shuttleworth.summary: Jackson Shuttleworth, Duolingo’s Group PM for Retention, breaks down how Duolingo’s streaks became one of the company’s most impactful growth and retention levers, including how it powers DAU and amplifies other systems like notifications. Listeners learn how Duolingo iterates on a deceptively simple habit mechanic through relentless experimentation (600+ tests), careful copy/timing optimization, and layered flexibility (e.g., streak freezes) to keep users coming back.
notable_frameworks: High-velocity A/B experimentation (test-everything approach)
Copy testing infrastructure (systematic CTA/message testing)
Habit formation via streak mechanics (behavioral engagement loop)

jag-duggal.title: Be fundamentally different, not incrementally better | Jag Duggal (Nubank, Facebook, Google)
jag-duggal.summary: Jag Duggal (CPO at Nubank) breaks down how Nubank builds products that customers “love fanatically,” driving extraordinary word-of-mouth growth. Listeners will learn how Nubank anchors on deep customer pain, uses culture and values as an operating system for product decisions, and applies clear strategy and rigorous product expansion criteria (including PMF thresholds) before scaling new lines of business.
notable_frameworks: Sean Ellis score (product-market fit threshold before scaling)
“We may not be right, but at least we are clear” (strategy clarity principle)

jake-knapp-john-zeratsky.title: Making time for what matters | Jake Knapp and John Zeratsky (Authors of Make Time, Character VC)
jake-knapp-john-zeratsky.summary: Jake Knapp and John Zeratsky share practical ways to consistently make time for what matters by redesigning daily defaults—especially around attention, technology, and how work gets structured. Listeners learn how to pick a daily “Highlight,” create conditions for deep focus, and apply lessons from structured team sprints to everyday life and work.
notable_frameworks: Make Time (Highlight-based daily planning framework)
Daily Highlight ("What was the highlight of your day?")
Design Sprint / Sprint methodology

jake-knapp-john-zeratsky-20.title: Making time for what matters | Jake Knapp and John Zeratsky (Authors of Make Time, Character VC)
jake-knapp-john-zeratsky-20.summary: Jake Knapp and John Zeratsky break down the Foundation Sprint—a structured, two-day process to align a team on the core “basics” of a product idea (who it’s for, what it is, why it’s different) and to define a clear, testable hypothesis. Listeners learn why moving fast (especially with AI) can produce generic products and how slowing down briefly to make key decisions and run early tests can dramatically increase speed and odds of success.
notable_frameworks: Foundation Sprint
Design Sprint
Prototype-and-test approach (rapid prototyping to validate assumptions)

janna-bastow.title: Building better roadmaps | Janna Bastow (Mind the Product, ProdPad)
janna-bastow.summary: Janna Bastow explains why roadmaps shouldn’t be treated as fixed plans, but as a “prototype for strategy” used to surface and test assumptions. Listeners will learn to focus on the roadmapping process—sharing early thinking with teammates and customers to validate problem sequencing—along with lessons from building and sustaining a large product community (Mind the Product) through grassroots collaboration and consistency.
notable_frameworks: Now, Next, Later
Roadmap as a prototype for strategy (assumption-testing via roadmapping process)
Lean prototyping mindset applied to strategy

jason-droege.title: Scale AI CEO on Meta's $14B deal, scaling Uber Eats to $80B, & what frontier labs are building next
jason-droege.summary: Jason Droege (new CEO of Scale AI) explains why enterprise AI often feels underwhelming today: turning models into reliable, automatable “doers” takes significant human work—expert data creation, evaluation, and iteration—over 6–12 months per real workflow. Listeners will learn how the AI improvement loop is shifting from simple labeling to high-skill expert tasks (e.g., PhDs, doctors, senior engineers), what Scale sees coming next in agentic systems, and practical lessons from Jason’s startup and Uber experience about negotiating, building new businesses, and setting a high bar for execution.
notable_frameworks: “Models knowing things → models doing things” (shift to agentic decision-making)
“Everything is negotiable” (startup/business negotiation mental model)
Infrastructure analogy for AI adoption (headlines vs. on-the-ground buildout; 6–12 month hardening cycle)

jason-feifer.title: How to get press for your product | Jason Feifer (editor in chief of Entrepreneur magazine)
jason-feifer.summary: Jason Feifer, editor in chief of Entrepreneur, explains how to get meaningful press by understanding that journalists serve their audience—not founders—and tailoring pitches to a publication’s mission and readers. Listeners will learn why most pitches fail, how to cut through inbox noise with targeted outreach, and how to think about press as a strategic tool with clear goals rather than a guaranteed growth lever.
notable_frameworks: Audience-first pitching (journalists serve readers/listeners/viewers, not founders)
Press-as-capital analogy (treat press like fundraising: only pursue it when you know what it’s for)
Signal-vs-noise targeting (avoid mass-blast PR; tailor to the right outlet/person)

jason-fried.title: How to get press for your product | Jason Feifer (editor in chief of Entrepreneur magazine)
jason-fried.summary: Jason Fried explains why bootstrapping can be a more reliable and fulfilling path than venture funding for many software companies, emphasizing profitability, small teams, and sustainable growth. Listeners will learn how constraints can improve decision-making and execution, why focusing on profit (not vanity metrics) changes how you build, and when raising capital actually makes sense.
notable_frameworks: Bootstrapping vs. venture-scale model ("your startup is probably not venture-scale")
Profit-first / "make more than you spend" operating model
Constraints-driven execution (small teams, limited cash as a feature)

jason-m-lemkin.title: We replaced our sales team with 20 AI agents—here’s what happened next | Jason Lemkin (SaaStr)
jason-m-lemkin.summary: Jason Lemkin breaks down how B2B SaaS companies should think about sales as problem-solving (not “selling”), and why founders must be honest about whether their early customers require a sales-led motion versus true self-serve. Listeners will learn how to decide if they need a sales team, how to sequence PLG vs enterprise sales over time, and the risks of abandoning a sales motion when customers still need high-touch guidance.
notable_frameworks: Sales-as-problem-solving (consultative selling vs commodity selling)
Sequencing GTM motions (self-serve/PLG first, enterprise sales later; hybrid models)
“First 10–50 unaffiliated customers predict the next 100–1,000” heuristic

jason-shah.title: Building a meaningful career | Jason Shah (Airbnb, Amazon, Microsoft, Alchemy)
jason-shah.summary: Jason Shah shares lessons from building products across startups and big tech (Yammer/Microsoft, Amazon, Airbnb) and now leading product in Web3 at Alchemy. Listeners will learn practical approaches to leadership and communication—especially how to disagree effectively (“push back”)—plus career-building principles and how to navigate volatile environments like crypto/Web3 while keeping teams focused.
notable_frameworks: Reframing “pushback” as goal/issue alignment (disagree by aligning on outcomes rather than saying no)
Working backwards (mentioned as a topic covered in the episode)

jeanne-grosser.title: What world-class GTM looks like in 2026 | Jeanne DeWitt Grosser (Vercel, Stripe, Google)
jeanne-grosser.summary: Jeanne DeWitt Grosser breaks down what “go-to-market” (GTM) really means in modern B2B—beyond just sales and marketing—and why it should be treated like an integrated, end-to-end product experience from awareness to long-term expansion. Listeners will learn how AI-driven competition is raising the bar for differentiation, why most buyers are motivated by risk reduction, and how to build GTM teams and motions that resonate with technical audiences (especially engineers).
notable_frameworks: GTM as a product (designing and orchestrating the customer buying journey end-to-end)
Lifecycle / jobs-to-be-done view of GTM (awareness → purchase → adoption → expansion → long-term LTV)
Venn diagram misalignment model (marketing/sales/support pursuing overlapping but inconsistent strategies like segmentation)
Risk-reduction positioning heuristic (most customers buy to avoid pain/reduce risk vs. pursue upside)
Engineer-facing sales litmus test (AEs should be indistinguishable from PMs to engineers in a short conversation)

jeff-weinstein.title: Building product at Stripe: craft, metrics, and customer obsession | Jeff Weinstein (Product lead)
jeff-weinstein.summary: Jeff Weinstein shares how he built and scaled products at Stripe by combining deep customer empathy with rigorous, customer-perspective metrics. Listeners will learn practical ways to create direct customer signal loops (even 1:1), evaluate product-market fit using both quantitative and qualitative evidence, and operationalize product craft/quality through repeatable team practices like Stripe “study groups.”
notable_frameworks: Customer-perspective metrics selection (measure value from the customer’s point of view)
PMF validation via dual evidence: quantitative trends (“up and to the right”) + qualitative signal (e.g., customer tweets)
Stripe Study Groups (role-play customer scenarios; rules: participants aren’t Stripe employees; no solving—practice empathy)
High-cadence direct customer feedback loop (maintain a small set of customers you can text/DM for fast signal)

jeffrey-pfeffer.title: The paths to power: How to grow your influence and advance your career | Jeffrey Pfeffer (Stanford)
jeffrey-pfeffer.summary: Jeffrey Pfeffer explains why building power and political skill is a learnable set of behaviors that strongly correlates with career outcomes like promotions, compensation, job satisfaction, and lower stress. He argues that discomfort around “power” often comes from confusing the tool with its misuse, and that underrepresented or disadvantaged groups especially benefit from understanding how power actually works. Listeners will learn the core rules and mindsets behind acquiring and using influence effectively, even when it clashes with how we wish the world worked.
notable_frameworks: The Seven Rules of Power
Political Skill (Gerald Ferris) scale/research

jen-abel.title: The ultimate guide to founder-led sales | Jen Abel (co-founder of JJELLYFISH)
jen-abel.summary: Jen Abel breaks down why founder-led sales is a critical early-stage advantage: when there’s no brand, marketing engine, or mature product, the founder’s vision and domain insight are what customers actually buy into. Listeners learn how founder-led sales is less about immediate revenue and more about rapid learning—using early conversations to align the founder’s vision with market reality and uncover the “budding moments” that lead to product-market fit and a repeatable sales motion.
notable_frameworks: Founder-led sales (founder as the product / founder as the primary GTM advantage)
Earn the right to sell (learning-first discovery before pitching)

jen-abel-20.title: $1M to $10M: The enterprise sales playbook with Jen Abel
jen-abel-20.summary: Jen Abel breaks down how to scale from ~$1M to ~$10M ARR by treating enterprise sales as a distinct motion (not an extension of SMB) and focusing on differentiation, relationship-building, and “selling to the gap” (an opportunity) rather than pitching a problem. Listeners will learn why “mid-market” is often a misleading category, how to avoid commoditization and discount-driven false positives, and how to craft enterprise deals through creative, human-led outbound and trust-based execution.
notable_frameworks: Sell to the gap (sell an opportunity, not a problem)
Vision casting (future-state selling)
Differentiation over comparison (avoid being “one of three”)
Enterprise sales as deal crafting (sales as an art/relationship motion)
Segmenting as SMB vs enterprise ("mid-market" as a misleading construct)

jeremy-henrickson.title: Moving fast and navigating uncertainty | Jeremy Henrickson (Rippling, Coinbase)
jeremy-henrickson.summary: Jeremy Henrickson shares lessons from scaling Coinbase through extreme hypergrowth and uncertainty, emphasizing how to keep teams moving fast without sacrificing security or clarity. Listeners will learn how strong product leadership stays close to the work, makes high-velocity decisions amid ambiguity, and keeps organizations aligned on a clear point of view even when opinions differ.

jerry-colonna.title: How have I been complicit in creating the conditions I say I don’t want? | Jerry Colonna
jerry-colonna.summary: Jerry Colonna explores how leaders often deceive themselves (and others) about “crushing it,” and how that avoidance fuels burnout, dysfunction, and poor leadership. Listeners will learn how to use radical self-inquiry—especially the question “How have I been complicit in creating the conditions I say I don’t want?”—to reclaim agency, build healthier teams, and develop resilience alongside practical leadership skills.
notable_frameworks: How have I been complicit in creating the conditions I say I don’t want? (agency-evoking self-inquiry question)
Reboot equation: Practical skills + Radical self-inquiry + Shared experiences = Enhanced leadership + Greater resiliency
Radical self-inquiry (methodology)

jess-lachs.title: Building a world-class data org | Jessica Lachs (VP of Analytics and Data Science at DoorDash)
jess-lachs.summary: Jessica Lachs shares how DoorDash built a highly impactful analytics and data science organization by treating analytics as a business-driving partner (answering “so what?”), not a ticket-taking service. Listeners will learn why she strongly prefers a centralized “center of excellence” reporting model paired with embedded pods aligned to business goals, and how this structure improves decision quality, incentives, and team effectiveness in a complex marketplace business.
notable_frameworks: Centralized data org / Center of Excellence model
Pod-based alignment model (central reporting with embedded cross-functional pods)
“So what?” analytics (insight-to-action orientation vs. service/ticket model)

jessica-hische.title: How to see like a designer: The hidden power of typography and logos | Jessica Hische
jessica-hische.summary: Jessica Hische breaks down how typography and logo details shape the feelings people have about a brand—and how even non-designers can learn to “see” what’s working or not. Using Lenny’s own logo/brand refresh as a case study, she explains when a “good enough” logo is the right move for early-stage companies, when it’s worth investing in a refresh, and how to approach brand work pragmatically in a world where startups often pivot.
notable_frameworks: Good-enough branding early (optimize for speed/flexibility until direction stabilizes)
Brand as expectation-setting (cover should accurately signal what’s inside)
Typography-feelings audit (ask what emotion a font/logo evokes and why)

jessica-livingston.title: The social radar: Y Combinator’s secret weapon | Jessica Livingston (co-founder of YC, author)
jessica-livingston.summary: Jessica Livingston (YC co-founder) explains how her “Social Radar” became a key advantage in Y Combinator’s early founder evaluations—spotting commitment, co-founder dynamics, and subtle interpersonal cues in short interviews. Listeners learn what signals she looked for (and which red flags mattered most), why hustle and “burn the boat” commitment can outweigh a flawed initial idea, and how these judgments shaped iconic YC decisions like Airbnb.
notable_frameworks: Social Radar (evaluating founders via interpersonal cues and commitment signals)
Reading the Mind in the Eyes test (emotion-reading assessment referenced as a proxy for social perception)

jiaona-zhang.title: Building minimum lovable products, stories from WeWork & Airbnb, and thriving as a PM | Jiaona Zhang
jiaona-zhang.summary: Jiaona Zhang shares practical lessons from teaching and leading product teams on how to avoid common early-PM pitfalls—especially jumping to solutions instead of deeply understanding user problems. She also breaks down a major product misstep from Airbnb (Airbnb Plus), highlighting the risks of solution-first thinking, competitor-driven roadmaps, and building outside a company’s operational strengths.
notable_frameworks: Minimum Lovable Product (MLP) vs. Minimum Viable Product (MVP)
Problem-first (user-problem) discovery vs. solution-first product development
Influence-without-authority model of product leadership

joe-hudson.title: How embracing your emotions will accelerate your career | Joe Hudson (Art of Accomplishment)
joe-hudson.summary: Joe Hudson explains why many high-achieving leaders remain unhappy despite external success: they’re stuck in an unhelpful relationship with their inner critical voice and in avoidance or mismanagement of emotions. Listeners will learn practical ways to relate differently to self-criticism (without trying to “stop” it), embrace and express emotions, and use joy and gratitude as levers for better performance, decision-making, and leadership.
notable_frameworks: Daily experimentation with the inner critical voice (choose a new response each day)
Reframing self-criticism as fear and responding with compassion ("I’m right here with you")
Joy-as-productivity lever (increase enjoyment to increase efficiency and quality)
Seven-minute daily gratitude practice

john-cutler.title: What differentiates the highest-performing product teams | John Cutler (The Beautiful Mess)
john-cutler.summary: John Cutler shares patterns he’s observed across hundreds of product teams through his unique “product evangelist” role at Amplitude—what high-performing teams consistently do differently, and why underperforming teams tend to fail in similar ways. Listeners will learn how leadership self-awareness, coherent operating beliefs, and practical approaches to metrics and product change efforts shape team effectiveness, plus why to be skeptical of one-size-fits-all frameworks.
notable_frameworks: North Star Metric / North Star Framework (North Star Playbook)
Skepticism toward rigid frameworks (context-first application of tools)

john-mark-nickels.title: Conscious leadership: Unlocking vision, strategy and purpose | JM Nickels (Uber, Waymo, DoorDash)
john-mark-nickels.summary: J.M. Nickels explores “conscious leadership” as becoming aware of your internal drivers (biases, inherited beliefs, power dynamics) and taking responsibility for the influence you have—regardless of title. Listeners will learn practical ways to lead with more intention (especially as they gain seniority), create space for others’ voices, and align day-to-day actions with long-term priorities and purpose.
notable_frameworks: Conscious leadership (leadership = influence + awareness + responsibility)
Objective function framing (clarifying priorities by imagining “future me” and end-of-life perspective)
Power dynamics awareness (seniority amplifies impact; intentionally create space for others)

jonathan-becker.title: The crazy story of landing Uber as a client | Jonathan Becker (Thrive Digital)
jonathan-becker.summary: Jonathan Becker shares how paid growth teams are evolving as AI automates much of the manual “trench work,” shifting humans toward strategy, modeling, validation, and asking better questions. He also tells the origin story of how he landed Uber—after exploiting a loophole in Uber’s referral program via paid search—and how that moment reshaped his agency’s trajectory. Listeners will learn how modern paid acquisition is changing (especially around creative iteration and AI-enabled workflows) and what high-leverage work remains for humans.
notable_frameworks: AI-assisted creative prototyping/iteration (rapid mockups as rough drafts for decision-making)
Human-in-the-loop marketing workflow (AI generates, humans validate/model/ask questions)

jonathan-lowenhar.title: How a great founder becomes a great CEO | Jonathan Lowenhar (co-founder of Enjoy The Work)
jonathan-lowenhar.summary: Jonathan Lowenhar explains why being a founder (a mindset) is different from being a CEO (a learnable craft), and how many founders struggle because nobody teaches the core CEO skills. Listeners will learn how to recognize common founder/CEO failure modes, how to build the operating rhythm of a well-run company after product-market fit, and a counterintuitive approach to acquisitions where you’re “never for sale” but instead create a buyer’s conviction through the Magic Box paradigm.
notable_frameworks: Founder vs. CEO (founder as a state of being; CEO as a craft)
Two phases of the startup journey (build something people want; then build a company around it)
Magic Box paradigm (seduce the acquirer; you’re never explicitly for sale)
Company operating rhythm (the repeatable cadence/pattern of a well-run business)

jonny-miller.title: Managing nerves, anxiety, and burnout | Jonny Miller (Nervous Systems Mastery)
jonny-miller.summary: Jonny Miller shares a practical, body-first (“bottom-up”) approach to managing nerves, anxiety, and burnout—especially in high-pressure work situations. Listeners learn why shifting physiological state (primarily through breath) is often faster and more effective than trying to think their way into calm, plus how to notice early burnout signals before they escalate.
notable_frameworks: Feather–Brick–Dump Truck phenomenon (early burnout warning system)
Top-down vs. bottom-up regulation (mind-first vs. body-first state change)
Nervous System Mastery (set of tools for calm, resilience, and aliveness)
APE practice (Awareness, Posture, Emotions)

josh-miller.title: Competing with giants: An inside look at how The Browser Company builds product | Josh Miller (CEO)
josh-miller.summary: Josh Miller shares how The Browser Company thinks about building Arc by prioritizing an exceptional user experience and a highly motivated team. He explains their north-star metric (D5/D7—using Arc at least 5 days per week) and why it effectively bundles retention, engagement, and growth, plus how they focus on week-over-week improvement rather than vanity absolutes.
notable_frameworks: D5/D7 (L5/L7) north-star metric: users active 5+ days per week
Week-over-week growth rate as the primary growth lens (vs. absolute numbers)
Cohort-by-cohort retention improvement tracking

judd-antin.title: The UX Research reckoning is here | Judd Antin (Airbnb, Meta)
judd-antin.summary: Judd Antin argues that UX research is in a “reckoning” moment, highlighted by disproportionate layoffs, because research is often not delivering clear business impact. Listeners will learn how “user-centered performance” (research done to signal customer obsession rather than change decisions) undermines value, and why researchers and product teams need to shift toward more decision-relevant, business-aware research.
notable_frameworks: User-centered performance
Validate vs. falsify mantra ("We don't validate, we falsify")
Macro / middle-range / micro research framework

jules-walter.title: Leveraging mentors to uplevel your career | Jules Walter (YouTube, Slack)
jules-walter.summary: Jules Walter shares how he accelerated his product career—breaking into PM via startups, then scaling impact at Slack and leading products at YouTube—by deliberately building skills through feedback and mentorship. Listeners will learn practical approaches to finding and leveraging mentors, adopting a learning mindset in unfamiliar roles (like growth), and using measurable product changes to drive career progression.
notable_frameworks: Growth frameworks (general, applied to activation/onboarding improvements)
Learning mindset / deliberate skill-building via feedback loops

julia-schottenstein.title: M&A, competition, pricing, and investing | Julia Schottenstein (dbt Labs)
julia-schottenstein.summary: Julia Schottenstein (dbt Labs) shares how to think about M&A as a way to preserve optionality—creating “plan Bs” by staying open with potential acquirers while still building meaningful competitive leverage. She also explains how her investing background shaped her approach to joining dbt and offers a practical lens for evaluating early-stage companies through people, market, product, and distribution.
notable_frameworks: M&A as creating plan Bs (optionality)
Identify your competitive advantage and "inflict pain" on strategic buyers (get noticed while staying friendly/open)
Early-stage evaluation framework: people, market, product, distribution

julian-shapiro.title: From managing people to managing AI: The leadership skills everyone needs now | Julie Zhuo
julian-shapiro.summary: Julian Shapiro breaks down how to build an audience and distribution engine by prioritizing original thinking over “content labor,” and explains why most creators stall before reaching their best ideas. Listeners will learn how to think about follower quality, why longer-form content (e.g., threads) can accelerate trust, and how to push through bad ideas to reliably generate novel, high-signal insights.
notable_frameworks: Product-led acquisition
Creativity Faucet
Mind followers vs. labor followers (follower quality model)

julie-zhuo.title: From managing people to managing AI: The leadership skills everyone needs now | Julie Zhuo
julie-zhuo.summary: Julie Zhuo and Lenny discuss how the core skills of good management—setting direction, allocating resources, and navigating change—are increasingly transferable to “managing” AI tools and models as teammates. Listeners will learn why orgs may flatten as AI expands individual scope, how to balance sturdiness with flexibility amid rapid change, and how to pair data-driven diagnosis with design-led solutions when building products and teams.
notable_frameworks: Be sturdy while being flexible (willow tree metaphor)
Diagnose with data, treat with design
Assemble the Avengers (use the right models/tools for the right jobs)
Dissolve role boundaries; think of everyone as builders

julie-zhuo-20.title: How To Win Friends & Influence Decisions (Julie Zhuo) | Lenny & Friends Summit 2024
julie-zhuo-20.summary: Julie Zhuo and Lenny discuss how management is evolving in an AI-driven, flatter-org world—where leaders must "manage change" faster, stay "sturdy while flexible," and orchestrate the right mix of humans and AI tools. They also cover Julie’s perspective on using data to diagnose problems (without letting metrics dictate what to build), and how timeless management fundamentals still apply even as roles and workflows shift.
notable_frameworks: “Diagnose with data, treat with design”
Willow tree metaphor (be sturdy while flexible)
“Assemble the Avengers” (orchestrating specialized AI models/tools for different strengths)
Managers manage change (management as change management)

karina-nguyen.title: OpenAI researcher on why soft skills are the future of work | Karina Nguyen
karina-nguyen.summary: Karina Nguyen shares an inside look at how frontier LLMs are trained and debugged, emphasizing that model training is often more art than science and heavily driven by data quality. She explains how conflicting training signals (e.g., teaching a model it has no body while also training it on “set an alarm” tool-use examples) can create confusing behaviors, and what that implies for building helpful yet safe systems. Listeners will learn how researchers think about robustness, helpfulness-vs-harm tradeoffs, and why synthetic data is emerging as a key lever as internet-scale data becomes constrained.
notable_frameworks: Model training as "debugging" (treating model behavior issues like software bugs)
Helpfulness vs. harm tradeoff (balancing utility with safety/robustness)
Data quality-first approach to shaping model behavior

karri-saarinen.title: Inside Linear: Building with taste, craft, and focus | Karri Saarinen (co-founder, designer, CEO)
karri-saarinen.summary: Karri Saarinen shares how Linear builds a beloved B2B SaaS product by prioritizing taste, craft, and focus over metrics-driven optimization. Listeners will learn how Linear makes product trade-offs, ships iteratively (internal-first, then small customer cohorts), and designs its team structure and hiring process to sustain high-quality execution while scaling a profitable business.
notable_frameworks: The Linear method of building product
Opinionated software (strong product point of view as a strategy)
Cycle-based product development (working in consistent cycles)
Internal-first shipping (dogfooding in production before broad release)
Opt-in / small-cohort rollouts for new features
Paid work trial hiring (work alongside the team instead of interviews)

katie-dill.title: Building beautiful products with Stripe’s Head of Design | Katie Dill (Stripe, Airbnb, Lyft)
katie-dill.summary: Katie Dill, Head of Design at Stripe (formerly Airbnb and Lyft), shares practical lessons on building and scaling high-quality design organizations and why “beauty” is a functional business advantage that increases usability and trust. Listeners will learn how to operationalize design quality, connect design work to measurable growth outcomes, and lead change effectively by earning trust—illustrated by a pivotal early leadership moment at Airbnb where her team staged a candid feedback intervention.
notable_frameworks: Trust-first change leadership (listen-first vs. “coming in swinging”; bring the team along rather than inflicting change)
Beauty-as-functionality mental model (beauty enhances usability and increases trust)

kayvon-beykpour.title: Twitter’s ex-Head of Product on Elon, consumer products, culture, more | Kayvon Beykpour
kayvon-beykpour.summary: Kayvon Beykpour shares behind-the-scenes stories from leading Twitter’s consumer product org through a major cultural shift—from risk-averse and stagnant to shipping frequently—and the tactics they used to challenge “sacred cows” and increase ambition. He also recounts his early interactions with Elon Musk during the acquisition transition (including a surreal meeting with Walter Isaacson present) and what it felt like to be fired during parental leave. Listeners will learn practical lessons on rebuilding product culture, driving execution in large consumer companies, and navigating leadership change during high-chaos transitions.
notable_frameworks: sacred cows as a roadmap (identify “untouchable” areas first, then systematically challenge them)
jobs-to-be-done

keith-coleman-jay-baxter.title: An inside look at X’s Community Notes | Keith Coleman & Jay Baxter
keith-coleman-jay-baxter.summary: Keith Coleman and Jay Baxter explain how X’s Community Notes works: users propose context notes on potentially misleading posts, and the system only shows notes that are rated helpful by people who historically disagree with each other. They unpack the core algorithmic idea—bridging-based agreement—and why it produces more neutral, accurate notes and is harder to manipulate than simple majority voting or immediate publishing.
notable_frameworks: Bridging-based agreement (finding note helpfulness via agreement among historically disagreeing raters)

keith-yandell.title: Leading with empathy | Keith Yandell (DoorDash, Uber)
keith-yandell.summary: Keith Yandell shares lessons from DoorDash’s near-death fundraising moments and what it takes to persist as a founder-led company when everyone says no. He also breaks down how DoorDash maintains a “no politics, no assholes” culture through direct feedback, high culture standards in hiring, and deep customer obsession practices like requiring employees to do deliveries.
notable_frameworks: “No politics, no assholes” culture bar
Direct feedback as a hiring signal (testing coachability via candid confrontation)
WeDash (employee-required customer immersion via doing deliveries)

ken-norton.title: How to unlock your product leadership skills | Ken Norton, Ex-Google
ken-norton.summary: Ken Norton explains why product managers are leaders from day one despite lacking formal authority, and how the most effective PMs operate with a creative, exploratory mindset rather than a purely reactive one. Drawing on his experience at Google and as an executive coach, he shares how coaching differs from advice-giving, what common leadership blind spots look like, and practical ways product leaders can overcome imposter syndrome and grow their influence.
notable_frameworks: Servant leadership ("bring the donuts" metaphor)
Coaching vs. advice/mentoring ("cotton candy" advice metaphor)
Creative vs. reactive mindset

kenneth-berger.title: Why not asking for what you want is holding you back | Kenneth Berger (exec coach, first PM @Slack)
kenneth-berger.summary: Kenneth Berger argues that many career and life problems stem from not clearly asking for what you want—or asking in ineffective ways (people-pleasing avoidance vs. controlling demands). Listeners will learn how to identify what they actually want, make specific requests with integrity, and use the response (including “no”) as critical feedback to iterate rather than stay stuck in frustration or conflict.
notable_frameworks: Ask for what you want (request → hear response → iterate)
Complaints imply dreams (use complaints to surface desired outcomes)
Stuckness as a diagnostic signal (repeating patterns without new data)

kevin-aluwi.title: Taxi mafias, cash vaults & 100% MoM growth: The story of SEA’s biggest startup | Kevin Aluwi (Gojek)
kevin-aluwi.summary: Kevin Aluwi, co-founder of Gojek, shares how Gojek scaled from an Indonesian motorcycle-taxi dispatch service into one of Southeast Asia’s largest consumer platforms, operating at Uber-like scale. Listeners learn the gritty operational realities of building in emerging markets (e.g., driver safety, cash logistics), why doing “hard things” early can be a competitive advantage, and how Gojek’s approach to brand and the “super app” strategy evolved over time.
notable_frameworks: Super app strategy (multi-service bundling under one consumer app)

kevin-weil.title: OpenAI’s CPO on how AI changes must-have skills, moats, coding, startup playbooks, more | Kevin Weil
kevin-weil.summary: Kevin Weil (CPO at OpenAI) explains how the rapid, compounding improvement of AI models changes how teams should build products—assuming today’s constraints will soon disappear and that products on the edge of model capability can quickly become great. He also shares what it feels like inside OpenAI during major launches (e.g., the new image model) and why internal adoption/virality is a strong signal for confidence in social/creative products. Listeners learn how to think about building in an environment where the underlying platform shifts every few months and how to spot products that will “sing” as models improve.
notable_frameworks: “The model you’re using today is the worst you’ll ever use” (build with accelerating capability in mind)
“Build on the edge of capability” heuristic (if it barely works now, it may be right as models improve)
Internal dogfooding + internal virality as a launch-readiness signal (especially for social products)

kevin-yien.title: Unorthodox PM tips: Automating user insights, unselling candidates, decision logs, more | Kevin Yien
kevin-yien.summary: Kevin Yien shares unorthodox, highly practical product management tactics for staying customer-driven, making better decisions with imperfect information, and building stronger cross-functional teams. Listeners will learn concrete approaches like keeping decision logs, “unselling” candidates at offer stage to improve hiring quality, and using AI/automation to scale user insights and research workflows.
notable_frameworks: Potential-to-kinetic energy model of product management (converting team potential into realized customer value)
Decision log (document decisions, rationale, and outcomes to build product sense through reps)
“Unsell” email at offer stage (explicitly list downsides/risks to validate candidate conviction)

kim-scott.title: Inside Devin: The AI engineer that's set to write 50% of its company’s code this year | Scott Wu
kim-scott.summary: Kim Scott breaks down Radical Candor as the practice of “caring personally” while “challenging directly,” and explains why most teams fail by being too nice (ruinous empathy) rather than too harsh. Listeners will learn practical language for soliciting real feedback (e.g., asking what to do or stop doing to be easier to work with) and how to avoid slipping into obnoxious aggression or manipulative insincerity.
notable_frameworks: Radical Candor (Care Personally × Challenge Directly 2x2)
Obnoxious Aggression / Ruinous Empathy / Manipulative Insincerity quadrants

kristen-berman.title: Using behavioral science to improve your product | Kristen Berman (Irrational Labs)
kristen-berman.summary: Kristen Berman explains how behavioral economics (psychology + economics) can be applied to product design to predictably change user behavior. Listeners will learn how to diagnose the real steps and frictions behind a target behavior, why “requested features” (like budgeting) often don’t move outcomes, and how to design and run experiments that validate whether a behavioral intervention actually works.
notable_frameworks: Behavioral economics (psychology + economics applied to decision-making)
Behavioral design (applying behavioral science insights to product problems)
Behavioral diagnosis (mapping each step required to achieve a target behavior)

krithika-shankarraman.title: Growth tactics from OpenAI and Stripe’s first marketer | Krithika Shankarraman
krithika-shankarraman.summary: Krithika Shankarraman explains what marketing looks like when awareness isn’t the bottleneck—using OpenAI/ChatGPT as the core example—where the real job is creating “use case epiphanies” so customers understand what the product can do and why it matters. She emphasizes a diagnostic, customer-understanding-first approach over copying playbooks or chasing vanity metrics, and highlights how marketing and product should operate as partners from the start. Listeners will learn how to identify the true constraint in the funnel, align product and marketing, and apply consumer-style tactics and operational problem-solving to B2B/enterprise growth.
notable_frameworks: Four-step diagnostic approach to marketing (mentioned as a process she uses; details not included in provided excerpt)
Use-case epiphany positioning (marketing focused on helping users discover concrete jobs-to-be-done rather than top-of-funnel awareness)

kunal-shah.title: Kunal Shah on winning in India, second-order thinking, the philosophy of startups, and more
kunal-shah.summary: Kunal Shah shares how to think about building products and companies—especially in India—through the lenses of trust, incentives, and second-order thinking. Listeners will learn a practical way to judge whether a product is meaningfully better (his “Delta 4” framework), plus how India’s unique market dynamics shape growth, monetization, and startup strategy.
notable_frameworks: Delta 4 (product efficiency delta >= 4 leading to irreversibility, higher failure tolerance, and a Unique Brag-worthy Proposition/UBP)
second-order thinking

lane-shackleton.title: What sets great teams apart | Lane Shackleton (CPO of Coda)
lane-shackleton.summary: Lane Shackleton (CPO of Coda) shares how great product teams and product leaders distinguish themselves through deliberate principles and repeatable team rituals. Listeners will learn practical ways to build strong product culture, lead through high-stakes moments with calm and preparation, and assess career growth by seeking out “oh shit” stretch moments rather than vague notions of progress.
notable_frameworks: "Oh shit moments" as a career-growth diagnostic (count and reflect on recent stretch moments)
Checklist-driven preparation and redundancy (borrowed from mountaineering/expedition practice)
Stay calm → assess → prioritize → act (crisis-response decision loop)

laura-modi.title: Career frameworks, A/B testing, onboarding tips, selling to engineers |  Laura Schaffer (Amplitude)
laura-modi.summary: Laura Modi (ex-Airbnb leader, now founder/CEO of Bobbie) shares lessons from scaling Airbnb and applying them to building a mission-driven consumer company. Listeners will learn how prioritizing the true “product” in a marketplace (the supply side), building culture as an operating system, and using vision/storytelling and organizational energy can drive sustainable growth—even when that means intentionally slowing or pausing growth to protect customers.
notable_frameworks: Supply-as-the-product (marketplace mental model)
Culture as an operating system / energy as organizational currency
Vision-led storytelling to align cross-functional teams

laura-schaffer.title: Career frameworks, A/B testing, onboarding tips, selling to engineers |  Laura Schaffer (Amplitude)
laura-schaffer.summary: Laura Schaffer (new Head of Growth at Amplitude, formerly growth leader at Twilio) shares practical lessons on building and scaling growth programs—especially experimentation and developer-focused go-to-market. Listeners will learn how to run effective A/B tests (including counterintuitive wins), when to trust data vs. gut, how to improve onboarding and activation, and a career-growth approach focused on creating opportunities rather than waiting for promotions.
notable_frameworks: Career growth framework: create your own path vs. relying on manager/company promotion tracks
Experimentation/AB testing methodology (rapid testing, small-group rollouts, learning-oriented framing)

lauren-ipsen.title: Lessons from one of the world’s top executive recruiters | Lauren Ipsen (Daversa Partners, GC)
lauren-ipsen.summary: Lauren Ipsen, a top executive recruiter, shares tactical guidance on how founders and product leaders can consistently hire great product talent by staying close to the market even before there’s an open role. Listeners will learn how to benchmark “what good looks like,” build relationships with high-performing candidates early, and use ongoing market awareness to make better hiring and career decisions.
notable_frameworks: Keeping a pulse on the market (continuous market sensing for talent)
Benchmarking “what good looks like” (calibrating candidate profiles ahead of hiring)
Pre-need relationship building (engage top talent as advisors before a formal role exists)

lauryn-isford.title: Mastering onboarding | Lauryn Isford (Head of Growth at Airtable)
lauryn-isford.summary: Lauryn Isford shares a contrarian, experience-driven view on when growth teams should (and shouldn’t) rely on A/B testing, arguing that experimentation is often overused and can be an expensive substitute for strong product thinking. Listeners will learn how to decide when experiments are truly necessary (primarily for risk mitigation), and how to build a growth culture that values customer impact and rigor beyond narrowly attributing wins to experiment deltas.
notable_frameworks: Experimentation as (1) metric-precision vs (2) risk-mitigation

logan-kilpatrick.title: Inside OpenAI | Logan Kilpatrick (head of developer relations)
logan-kilpatrick.summary: Logan Kilpatrick, head of developer relations at OpenAI, shares what it was like inside OpenAI during the board/Sam Altman weekend and why the company rebounded so quickly. Listeners will learn what OpenAI values in its culture (especially high-agency, urgent execution), and get a window into how the team stays mission-focused while supporting a fast-growing developer ecosystem and exploring new AI interaction paradigms beyond chat.
notable_frameworks: High-agency + urgency (as core hiring/operating principles)

luc-levesque.title: Leveraging growth advisors, mastering SEO, and honing your craft | Luc Levesque (Shopify, Meta)
luc-levesque.summary: Luc Levesque (Chief Growth Officer at Shopify; former growth leader at Meta) explains how elite growth advisors can create outsized, company-changing impact—sometimes from a single key insight applied at the right moment. He also shares what it’s like operating in high-execution cultures like Facebook/Meta, where the central operating principle is a relentless focus on measurable impact over activity.
notable_frameworks: Impact-first operating model (optimize for outcomes over activity)

lulu-cheng-meservey.title: Gain attention as an underdog with this framework | Lulu Cheng Meservey
lulu-cheng-meservey.summary: Lulu Cheng Meservey breaks down how to make ideas spread by shaping messages to fit what an audience already cares about, rather than trying to change their worldview. She shares practical tactics for making messages memorable and repeatable—using jokes, vivid imagery, analogies, and simple phrasing—and warns that the same “stickiness” can backfire if a phrase becomes a negative meme.
notable_frameworks: Cultural erogenous zones (identify what an audience already cares about)
Bridge/API from X to Y (connect audience passion to your offering)
Make it spread: memorable + people want to repeat it (identity/joy/humor/interest)
Put the pill in the cheese (package a hard message in an appealing wrapper)
Second-grader test (simplify to minimize cognitive burden)
Avoid adjectives; use stories/anecdotes (concrete, repeatable narratives)

madhavan-ramanujam.title: Pricing your AI product: Lessons from 400+ companies and 50 unicorns | Madhavan Ramanujam
madhavan-ramanujam.summary: Madhavan Ramanujam breaks down how AI companies should think about monetization from day one, warning that early pricing anchors can permanently cap willingness-to-pay. Listeners will learn how to architect a durable business by balancing market share and wallet share, and how to choose pricing models—ideally moving toward outcome-based pricing where autonomy and attribution are high.
notable_frameworks: Market share vs. wallet share (dual-engine growth model)
Acquisition–Monetization–Retention loop (get customers, monetize initially, monetize ongoing/referrals)
Pricing model 2x2: autonomy vs. attribution (outcome-based pricing in the top-right quadrant)
80/20 willingness-to-pay heuristic (20% of features drive 80% of willingness to pay)
Price anchoring / customer price training (early low price points create long-term constraints)

madhavan-ramanujam-20.title: The art and science of pricing | Madhavan Ramanujam (Monetizing Innovation, Simon-Kucher)
madhavan-ramanujam-20.summary: Madhavan Ramanujam breaks down how founders can architect for durable, profitable growth by mastering both market share (acquisition) and wallet share (monetization and expansion). He explains why pricing and monetization must be designed from day one—especially for AI products where early price anchors can permanently cap willingness to pay—and shares practical guidance on choosing pricing models, including when and how to pursue outcome-based pricing.
notable_frameworks: Market share vs. wallet share (dual-engine growth model)
Acquisition–Monetization–Retention loop (get customers, monetize initially, monetize ongoing/expand + referrals)
Pricing model 2x2: autonomy vs. attribution (with outcome-based pricing as the top-right quadrant)
80/20 willingness-to-pay heuristic (20% of product drives 80% of WTP)

maggie-crowley.title: Mastering product strategy and growing as a PM | Maggie Crowley (Toast, Drift, TripAdvisor)
maggie-crowley.summary: Maggie Crowley shares what consistently separates top product managers across startups and large companies: the ability to simplify complexity into the single most important priority, sustain momentum long enough to ship, and rigorously follow up on outcomes. Listeners will learn practical ways to think about prioritization beyond one-time decisions, how to build credibility through results tracking, and what strong product leadership looks like day-to-day.
notable_frameworks: Simplify to the single most important thing (focus as a prioritization approach)
Follow-up on results (closed-loop product work: define metric → ship → measure → report back)

manik-gupta.title: Becoming more strategic, navigating difficult colleagues, founder mode, more | Anneka Gupta
manik-gupta.summary: Manik Gupta reflects on the biggest drivers of his career trajectory—from leading Google Maps and serving as Uber’s CPO to his current role at Microsoft—emphasizing how much success is shaped by both deliberate choices and luck/risk. Listeners will learn two core career principles: deliberately surrounding yourself with exceptional people over the long term, and leaning into technology optimism by choosing problems where tech can meaningfully improve human lives at scale.
notable_frameworks: Luck vs. risk (from The Psychology of Money)

marc-benioff.title: Behind the founder: Marc Benioff
marc-benioff.summary: Marc Benioff shares lessons from building and scaling Salesforce over 25 years, focusing on how to keep a founder mindset while continuously adapting strategy, marketing, and leadership as the company grows. Listeners will learn how he approached early attention-getting launches through rapid experimentation, why he avoids stock-price fixation, and how he thinks about major platform shifts like AI and “agents” as the next wave of enterprise software.
notable_frameworks: throw everything against the wall (rapid tactic testing → strategy)
stock isn’t the goal (focus on mission/operating fundamentals over market noise)
beginner’s mind / embrace the next thing (continuous reinvention mindset)
platform thinking: build an application economy (ecosystem-first strategy)

marily-nika.title: AI and product management | Marily Nika (Meta, Google)
marily-nika.summary: Marily Nika explains how product managers can stay current in AI/ML, avoid the “shiny object trap,” and focus on real user pain points before choosing AI as a solution. She shares practical ways PMs can use tools like ChatGPT today (e.g., improving mission statements, generating user segments/personas) and argues that AI will become a default layer in most products, pushing PMs toward AI-fluent product thinking.
notable_frameworks: shiny object trap (don’t do AI for AI’s sake; start from a real problem/pain point)

marty-cagan.title: Product management theater | Marty Cagan (Silicon Valley Product Group)
marty-cagan.summary: Marty Cagan argues that many companies—especially after pandemic overhiring—have drifted into “product management theater,” where PM-adjacent roles and output-focused processes masquerade as real product work. Listeners will learn how to distinguish outcome-driven product teams from project/feature teams, why much mainstream PM advice can be misleading, and what it takes to build empowered teams and strong product leadership (including in an AI-shaped future).
