notable_frameworks: Product management theater
Output vs outcomes
Feature teams vs empowered product teams
Product model (SVPG)

marty-cagan-20.title: The disease of process people | Marty Cagan
marty-cagan-20.summary: Marty Cagan argues that many companies overhired during the pandemic and created “product management theater,” where roles like product owners, agile coaches, and product ops often function as overpaid project/output managers rather than outcome-focused product leaders. He explains why he’s become more direct about these trends, what distinguishes real product management from process-heavy output delivery, and previews his new book’s focus on helping PMs move from feature teams to empowered teams instead of feeling stuck.
notable_frameworks: Product management theater
Output vs. outcomes
Feature teams vs. empowered teams
SVPG heuristic: validate practices by observing consistent use in top, consistently-innovating product companies

matt-abrahams.title: How to speak more confidently and persuasively | Matt Abrahams (professor, speaker, author)
matt-abrahams.summary: Matt Abrahams shares practical, research-backed techniques to reduce public-speaking anxiety and to communicate more confidently in high-pressure moments. Listeners will learn how to use visualization and other tactics to calm nerves, and how to “prepare to be spontaneous” for common on-the-spot speaking situations like Q&A, feedback, toasts, and apologies.
notable_frameworks: Visualization for desensitization (mental rehearsal / exposure-style practice)
Prepare to be spontaneous (practice for improvisational speaking)
Connection over perfection ("dare to be dull")

matt-dixon.title: The surprising truth about what closes deals: Insights from 2.5m sales conversations | Matt Dixon
matt-dixon.summary: Matt Dixon shares findings from analyzing 2.5 million sales conversations, showing that most deals are lost to customer indecision (fear of making the wrong choice) rather than direct competition. Listeners learn how to diagnose indecision and move buyers forward using the JOLT method, plus how Challenger-style selling reframes risk to create urgency without triggering backlash.
notable_frameworks: JOLT Method (Judge indecision, Offer recommendation, Limit exploration, Take risk off the table)
The Challenger Sale (teach/tailor/take control; reframing customer risk)

matt-lemay.title: The one question that saves product careers | Matt LeMay
matt-lemay.summary: Matt LeMay argues that product teams survive and thrive by relentlessly tying their work to business-critical outcomes, not “work around the work” like process theater, cosmetic improvements, or over-cascaded OKRs. Listeners will learn how teams fall into a low-impact “death spiral,” and practical steps to set goals close to company goals, push back on exec-driven busywork, and continuously justify why their team deserves investment—especially in layoff-prone environments.
notable_frameworks: Low impact PM Death Spiral
Impact-first product teams
The 'If you were the CEO, would you fully fund your own team?' question
Goals no more than one step away from company goals (anti-cascading OKRs)

matt-macinnis.title: "I deliberately understaff every project" | Leadership lessons from Rippling's $16B journey
matt-macinnis.summary: Matt MacInnis (Rippling’s longtime COO turned CPO) argues that exceptional company outcomes require sustained, uncomfortable levels of effort—and that leaders must actively preserve intensity as organizations scale. He explains why Rippling deliberately understaffs projects to avoid politics and waste, and why fast, direct escalation and feedback are essential to keeping teams aligned on true priorities and execution speed.
notable_frameworks: Extraordinary results require extraordinary efforts (99th-percentile outcomes demand sustained discomfort)
Deliberate understaffing to force prioritization and reduce politics/cruft
Escalation as an operating system (surface issues fast; don’t optimize for local comfort)
Feedback withholding is selfish (optimize for company outcomes over personal comfort)
Intensity preservation across management layers (prevent order-of-magnitude drop in urgency away from founder CEO)

matt-mochary.title: Are your fears giving you terrible advice? | Matt Mochary
matt-mochary.summary: Matt Mochary shares hard-earned leadership lessons from coaching top founders and executives, focusing on how fear and anger can distort decision-making and lead leaders to avoid necessary but difficult actions. Listeners will learn practical guidance for handling high-stakes people moments—especially layoffs and firings—more humanely and effectively, including why one-on-one communication is critical.
notable_frameworks: Fear gives bad advice (inversion: predict the opposite outcome when acting from fear)
Prediction-and-bet method to test fear-based assumptions

matt-mullenweg.title: The one question that saves product careers | Matt LeMay
matt-mullenweg.summary: Matt Mullenweg shares his perspective on the recent WordPress controversy involving WP Engine, explaining how trademark use, hosting distributions, and private-equity incentives can create tension with open-source stewardship. He also walks through his long-term approach to building WordPress and Automattic around open web principles, including how he thinks about “real” vs “fake” open source in the AI era and why distributed, asynchronous work has been a durable advantage for Automattic.
notable_frameworks: “Real open source” vs “fake open source” (as applied to AI models and licensing)

matthew-dicks.title: How to tell better stories | Matthew Dicks (Storyworthy)
matthew-dicks.summary: Matthew Dicks breaks down storytelling into a practical, repeatable skill, arguing that audiences remember stories (imagery and emotion) far more than facts, charts, or platitudes. Listeners learn how to identify the core of any compelling story—a brief moment of transformation or realization—and how to build the right context so that moment lands clearly and memorably in business and life.
notable_frameworks: The "five-second moment" (a single moment of transformation or realization as the core of every good story)
Story as context-building: ~98% setup to deliver maximum clarity on the core moment

maya-prohovnik.title: Building Anchor, selling to Spotify, and lessons learned | Maya Prohovnik (Head of Podcast Product)
maya-prohovnik.summary: Maya Prohovnik shares how Anchor (now Spotify for Podcasters) won hosting market share by obsessing over reducing creator friction—so much so that early “automation” was powered by interns manually submitting shows to Apple Podcasts to make distribution feel like one click. She also explains why she’s deeply committed to dogfooding, including creating multiple podcasts herself, as a way to build empathy for creators and make better product decisions.
notable_frameworks: dogfooding
friction reduction (one-click/low-friction onboarding)

mayur-kamat.title: Unconventional product lessons from Binance, N26, Google, more | Mayur Kamat (CPO at N26)
mayur-kamat.summary: Mayur Kamat shares unconventional product lessons from leading teams at Google (including the early Hangouts effort), Binance, and now N26—especially why speed from hypothesis to data matters more than traditional “strategy.” Listeners will learn how extreme execution cultures (like Binance’s daily leadership cadence and radical ownership) can accelerate decision-making, how experimentation makes product work more scientific, and what pitfalls can derail even well-resourced teams.
notable_frameworks: Hypothesis-to-data loop (strategy as speed to validated learning)
Experimentation as the scientific method for product
Running products via daily meeting (daily leadership cadence + single-threaded ownership for urgent bets)
Extreme ownership model (high accountability regardless of title)

megan-cook.title: Lessons from Atlassian | Megan Cook (Head of Product, Jira)
megan-cook.summary: Megan Cook (Head of Product for Jira at Atlassian) shares practical ways to build high-performing product teams by increasing psychological safety, encouraging “play” to reduce fear, and creating structured spaces for early, candid feedback. Listeners will learn concrete rituals (like peer feedback groups and a weekly leadership conflict slot) that help teams surface issues sooner, improve collaboration across product/design/engineering, and unlock bolder, less incremental thinking—especially in remote and high-ambiguity environments.
notable_frameworks: Fight Club (weekly scheduled conflict-resolution meeting)
Play vs. Fear (mindset model: the opposite of play is fear)
Peer feedback groups (small-group critique ritual for early drafts)

melanie-perkins.title: She turned 100+ rejections into a $42B company | Melanie Perkins
melanie-perkins.summary: Melanie Perkins shares how Canva was built by starting from an ambitious vision of the future (“Column B thinking”) and working backward, rather than planning from current constraints. She also explains how repeated investor rejections became a feedback loop to sharpen Canva’s narrative, positioning, and strategy—turning “no” into iterative improvement.
notable_frameworks: Column A vs Column B thinking (vision-first planning vs constraint-first planning)
Crazy Big Goals
Chaos to Clarity

melissa.title: Building high-performing teams | Melissa Tan (Webflow, Dropbox, Canva)
melissa.summary: Melissa Perri shares patterns she’s seen across thousands of product managers and dozens of companies, emphasizing that most “people problems” are actually strategy and goal-setting problems. Listeners will learn how product org challenges change as companies move from product-market fit into scale, especially the need to build a coherent, prioritized strategy and deploy it effectively across a growing organization.
notable_frameworks: Build Trap (concept from Escaping the Build Trap)

melissa-perri.title: Everything you’ve ever wanted to know about SAFe and the product owner role | Melissa Perri
melissa-perri.summary: Melissa Perri breaks down where SAFe and the Scrum “product owner” role came from, why large (often non-software-native) enterprises adopt these frameworks, and what tends to go wrong when they become overly dogmatic. Listeners will learn how the product owner role differs from modern product management, why “scaling Scrum” often turns into process theater, and what leaders and practitioners can do to evolve toward outcomes, customer value, and better decision-making.
notable_frameworks: SAFe (Scaled Agile Framework)
Scrum
Agile methodologies
Lean UX

melissa-perri-denise-tilles.title: The ultimate guide to product operations | Melissa Perri and Denise Tilles
melissa-perri-denise-tilles.summary: Melissa Perri and Denise Tilles explain what Product Operations (Product Ops) is, why it has rapidly become common in scaling tech companies, and how it differs from product management and project management. Listeners will learn when to introduce Product Ops, what problems it solves (freeing PMs to focus on strategic work), and practical guidance for making an initial Product Ops hire and rolling out the function effectively.
notable_frameworks: Product Operations as shared systems/infrastructure to enable PM strategic work (operating model concept)

melissa-tan.title: Building high-performing teams | Melissa Tan (Webflow, Dropbox, Canva)
melissa-tan.summary: Melissa Tan shares lessons from leading growth at Dropbox and Webflow and advising companies like Canva and Grammarly on how to build high-performing teams—especially growth teams. Listeners will learn how to hire and develop first-principles thinkers, align go-to-market choices (product-led vs. sales-led), and structure growth work across the funnel (activation, monetization, retention) to scale after product-market fit.
notable_frameworks: first principles thinking
funnel-based growth optimization (activation, monetization, engagement, retention)
product-led growth vs. sales-led motion (go-to-market choice)

meltem-kuran.title: An inside look at Deel’s unprecedented growth | Meltem Kuran Berkowitz (Head of Growth)
meltem-kuran.summary: Meltem Kuran Berkowitz breaks down how Deel scaled from under $1M ARR to nearly $300M ARR in ~3 years while staying EBITDA positive, emphasizing a “back to basics” approach before scaling spend. Listeners will learn how to prioritize foundational web/SEO hygiene, leverage low-cost channels (SEO/content, Reddit/communities, partnerships) to answer real buyer questions, and then layer in paid growth only once the core experience and discoverability are strong.
notable_frameworks: Back-to-basics growth sequencing (website speed/indexing → discoverability via content/SEO → then paid acquisition)
Problem-first/value-add distribution (answer questions where buyers already seek help: Reddit/Quora/communities)

merci-grace.title: How to work through fear, give hard feedback, and doing layoffs with grace | Matt Mochary
merci-grace.summary: Merci Grace shares lessons from her unconventional path (founder → product/growth at Slack → VC → founder again), emphasizing how curiosity and understanding human decision-making shaped her career. She explains what she learned in venture about how subjective fundraising can be and why founder storytelling and narrative control often outweigh purely “objective” business fundamentals. Listeners will learn practical guidance for pitching—especially how to open with a compelling founder insight rather than a generic market overview—and get a glimpse into early Slack positioning and internal debates about its social dynamics.
notable_frameworks: Start in the action (in medias res) pitch structure
Narrative/arc outlining for pitches and talks (story-first outlining)

michael-truell.title: The rise of Cursor: The $300M ARR AI tool that engineers can’t stop using | Michael Truell
michael-truell.summary: Michael Truell shares Cursor’s vision for “what comes after code”: a new programming paradigm where engineers specify intent in a more human-readable, pseudocode-like representation while retaining precise control. He explains why neither “nothing changes” (traditional code editors forever) nor “just chat with a bot” is the right end state, and why Cursor’s biggest breakthroughs increasingly depend on custom model development. Listeners will learn how Cursor thinks about the future workflow of software creation and what skills (like taste and intent specification) become more valuable as AI raises the abstraction level of programming.
notable_frameworks: “After code” / intent-driven programming (evolution from formal code to pseudocode-like, human-readable logic)
Human-in-the-driver’s-seat model (high control + fast iteration loop vs. slow autonomous agent)
Critique of two end-state visions (status-quo coding vs. chatbot-as-engineering-department)

mihika-kapoor.title: Vision, conviction, and hype: How to build 0 to 1 inside a company | Mihika Kapoor (Product, Figma)
mihika-kapoor.summary: Mihika Kapoor (Figma) breaks down how to build and launch 0→1 products inside an established company by crafting a clear vision, building conviction, and earning buy-in across a messy, change-filled product development process. Listeners will learn practical approaches to using prototyping and design to make ideas tangible early, creating internal momentum through mechanisms like hack weeks, and leading teams through pivots while keeping the “flame” of the vision alive.
notable_frameworks: Maker Week (internal hackathon as an innovation mechanism)
Vision-led product development (anchoring teams through highs/lows and pivots)
Prototype-first pitching (designing/prototyping before a project is greenlit)

mike-krieger.title: Anthropic's CPO on what comes next | Mike Krieger (co-founder of Instagram)
mike-krieger.summary: Mike Krieger (CPO at Anthropic, co-founder of Instagram) shares how working at the frontier of AI has changed his beliefs about both the pace of progress and what models can do—especially their ability to contribute genuinely novel, strategic thinking. Listeners will learn how AI-native product and engineering workflows are reshaping development bottlenecks (e.g., merge queues) when the majority of code and PRs are AI-generated, and how Anthropic thinks about building toward a “goes well” human–AI future amid accelerating timelines.
notable_frameworks: SWE-Bench (coding capability benchmark)
AI 2027 (future scenario / forecasting narrative)

mike-maples-jr.title: Pattern Breakers: How to find a breakthrough startup idea | Mike Maples, Jr. (Partner at Floodgate)
mike-maples-jr.summary: Mike Maples Jr. shares a practical lens for generating breakthrough startup ideas, arguing that the best companies win by proposing a radically different future rather than out-executing incumbents. Listeners will learn how to spot “inflections,” develop unique “insights/secrets,” and assess “founder–future fit,” plus why pivots are often the path to the biggest outcomes and how to think about early evidence before product-market fit is obvious.
notable_frameworks: Pattern Breakers: Inflections + Insights ("secrets") + Founder–Future Fit
Asymmetric warfare vs. incumbents (David vs. Goliath: inflection as the rock, insight as the slingshot)
Living in the future / noticing what’s missing ("secrets" as invention fuel)
Pivot-driven outcomes (the idea that many top returns come from pivots)

molly-graham.title: “I like being scared”: Molly Graham’s frameworks for rapid career growth | Molly Graham
molly-graham.summary: Molly Graham shares practical frameworks for growing your career and leadership capacity as fast as your company scales, drawing on her experiences at Google, Facebook, Quip, and the Chan Zuckerberg Initiative. Listeners will learn how to pursue “J-curve” career moves, let go of responsibilities they’ve mastered (“give away your Legos”), and navigate rapid change by aligning culture, goals, and decision-making in high-growth environments.
notable_frameworks: Give away your Legos
J-curve vs. stairs (career growth model)
Waterline model
Snorkel before you scuba
Six rules for creating goals and building alignment (mentioned)

nabeel-s-qureshi.title: How Palantir built the ultimate founder factory | Nabeel S. Qureshi (founder, writer, ex-Palantir)
nabeel-s-qureshi.summary: Nabeel Qureshi explains how Palantir operates and why it consistently produces unusually strong product leaders and founders. Listeners learn what Palantir actually sells (a data platform delivered through outcome-focused deployments), how the forward-deployed engineer model shapes product thinking, and what Palantir looks for in hiring and culture to create independent, high-agency builders.
notable_frameworks: Forward Deployed Engineer (FDE) model (field-embedded engineering as the proving ground for PMs)
Outcome-driven delivery (shipping by achieving customer outcomes vs. feature output)
Two-tier engineering model (core product engineers vs. forward-deployed engineers)

nan-yu.title: Linear’s secret to building beloved B2B products | Nan Yu (Head of Product)
nan-yu.summary: Nan Yu (Head of Product at Linear) breaks down how Linear builds a beloved B2B product by pairing high craft with high velocity—arguing that “speed vs. quality” is a false trade-off when teams are truly competent and focused. Listeners will learn how Linear avoids product bloat through disciplined “no” decisions, how Nan runs customer conversations to uncover the underlying emotions and jobs-to-be-done, and practical career tactics for landing top product roles (including how Nan got hired at Linear).
notable_frameworks: Speed-with-quality as a competency model (reframing the “speed vs. quality” trade-off)
10% time-budget prototype / early hypothesis test (have something working very early to validate a key assumption)
Emotion-first customer interviewing (digging to identify the feeling users want to avoid and designing to remove it)
Anti-bloat feature triage (explicitly identifying request types that must be declined to preserve product simplicity)

nancy-duarte.title: Storytelling with Nancy Duarte: How to craft compelling presentations and tell a story that sticks
nancy-duarte.summary: Nancy Duarte shares practical, repeatable ways to craft presentations and everyday messages that persuade—by structuring communication as a contrast between “what is” and “what could be.” Listeners will learn how high-impact talks (like Al Gore’s) are built through disciplined storytelling, iteration, and audience-focused clarity, and how these same techniques apply in meetings, 1:1s, and any moment of influence.
notable_frameworks: Contrast framework: “what is” vs. “what could be” (current state vs. future state)

naomi-gleit.title: Meta’s head of product on working with Mark Zuckerberg, early growth tactics, and more | Naomi Gleit
naomi-gleit.summary: Naomi Gleit, Meta’s head of product and one of its earliest employees, shares lessons from scaling Facebook from its earliest days—especially around early growth tactics, product clarity, and operating effectively at massive scale. Listeners will learn practical approaches to simplifying complex problems, creating alignment through strong documentation, and leadership/product-management principles shaped by years working closely with Mark Zuckerberg and Meta’s growth culture.
notable_frameworks: Canonical doc (single source of truth for a project)
Framework-driven clarity (using explicit frameworks to simplify and align teams)

naomi-ionita.title: How to price your product | Naomi Ionita (Menlo Ventures)
naomi-ionita.summary: Naomi Ionita shares practical guidance on how to think about pricing and monetization as an evolving product strategy—something you revisit regularly rather than “set and forget.” Listeners will learn how pricing ties into product-led growth (especially the shift from single-player to multiplayer/team use cases) and get introduced to Naomi’s “Modern Growth Stack” lens for the tools and capabilities that drive scalable growth.
notable_frameworks: Modern Growth Stack
Single-player → multiplayer/team/enterprise chasm (bottom-up SaaS transition)

nick-turley.title: Inside ChatGPT: The fastest growing product in history | Nick Turley (OpenAI)
nick-turley.summary: Nick Turley, Head of ChatGPT at OpenAI, shares how ChatGPT went from a hackathon-style experiment (“Chat with GPT-3.5”) to a global consumer product used weekly by a meaningful share of the world. Listeners learn how OpenAI thinks about shipping and polishing AI products (you often can’t know what to refine until after launch), what makes GPT-5 feel like a step-change (speed, dynamic “thinking,” coding/writing quality, and “taste”), and how product leadership sets pace and responsibility at massive scale.
notable_frameworks: “Ship first, polish after” (you won’t know what to polish until after you ship)
“Maximally accelerated” principle (ask: why can’t we do this now?)
MS-DOS → Windows analogy for product evolution (chat as early UI; richer interface to come)

nickey-skarstad.title: Nickey Skarstad (Airbnb, Etsy, Shopify, Duolingo) on translating vision into goals, operationalizing product quality, second-order decisions, brainstorming, influence, and much more
nickey-skarstad.summary: Nickey Skarstad shares how she’s built products across Etsy, Airbnb, and Duolingo by grounding strategy in a clear vision, translating that vision into concrete goals, and keeping teams aligned through strong operating rhythms. Listeners will learn practical approaches to operationalizing product quality (including using customer reviews as a balancing metric), making better second-order decisions, running effective brainstorming and product reviews, and building influence as a product leader.
notable_frameworks: Vision-to-goals translation (making strategy actionable via goals and execution plans)
Balancing metrics for quality (e.g., review rate as a top-line quality bar)
Second-order decision-making (considering downstream effects and tradeoffs)
Structured product review sessions (cadences and critique mechanisms to maintain quality)
Brainstorming systems (repeatable ideation processes rather than ad-hoc creativity)

nicole-forsgren.title: How to measure AI developer productivity in 2025 | Nicole Forsgren
nicole-forsgren.summary: Nicole Forsgren argues that most traditional engineering productivity metrics are easily gamed—especially in an AI-assisted world—and that teams should instead measure outcomes and reduce developer friction (DevEx) to sustainably move faster. Listeners will learn how AI shifts work from writing code to reviewing and evaluating reliability, and why improving workflows, tooling, and cognitive load is key to real productivity gains without burnout.
notable_frameworks: DORA
SPACE

nicole-forsgren-20.title: How to measure AI developer productivity in 2025 | Nicole Forsgren
nicole-forsgren-20.summary: Nicole Forsgren argues that most traditional engineering productivity metrics are misleading—especially in an AI-assisted world where output (e.g., lines of code) is easy to game. Listeners will learn how to think about developer productivity through the lens of developer experience (DevEx), why speed without strategy can just mean “shipping trash faster,” and why AI shifts effort from writing code to evaluating, reviewing, and rebuilding trust in generated code.
notable_frameworks: DORA
SPACE

nikhyl-singhal.title: Building a long and meaningful career | Nikhyl Singhal (Meta, Google)
nikhyl-singhal.summary: Nikhyl Singhal shares a long-term approach to building a meaningful product career, warning against short-term, reactive job moves and encouraging listeners to plan by working backward from an end-state. He discusses how to think about the “job after next,” navigate career forks, and sustain motivation over decades—especially as you reach senior levels where promotions, leadership blind spots, and mental health challenges become more common.
notable_frameworks: Work backward from your end state (career as a product: v1/v2/v3 planning)
The Skip (optimize for the job after next, not the next job)
“911 calls” (coaching framework for high-stakes career inflection points)
Dog-track “fake rabbit” metaphor (goal achievement without a next chapter leads to demotivation)

nikita-bier.title: Driving alignment within teams, work-life balance, and the changing PM landscape | Nikita Miller
nikita-bier.summary: Nikita Bier breaks down how he repeatedly built consumer apps that hit the top of the App Store by spotting “latent demand” and translating it into simple, high-signal product experiences. Listeners will learn how to identify distorted user workarounds, why execution in the “pixels” (design/flows) matters more than process-heavy PM work in big companies, and what it really takes operationally to survive hypergrowth when an app goes viral.
notable_frameworks: Latent demand (identify distorted workarounds and crystallize the underlying motivation)

nikita-miller.title: Driving alignment within teams, work-life balance, and the changing PM landscape | Nikita Miller
nikita-miller.summary: Nikita Miller shares practical lessons from leading product and growth teams (notably at Trello and The Knot Worldwide), emphasizing how to balance outcome-focused thinking with the need to ship meaningful output. Listeners will learn how to drive alignment in cross-functional teams, operate effectively in remote/distributed environments, and navigate the evolving expectations of product management roles.
notable_frameworks: Outcomes vs. outputs (balancing outcome orientation with shipping velocity)
Progressive disclosure (start simple, reveal complexity as users mature)
Cross-functional roles & responsibilities alignment framework (teased in intro)

nilan-peiris.title: How to drive word of mouth | Nilan Peiris (CPO of Wise)
nilan-peiris.summary: Nilan Peiris (CPO of Wise) breaks down how Wise engineered word-of-mouth into its primary growth engine—driving roughly 70% of new-user discovery—by focusing on delivering a meaningfully better product experience rather than incremental conversion-rate tweaks. Listeners learn practical ways to measure word of mouth (including simple in-flow attribution via “how did you hear about us?”), and why Wise prioritized WOM given the economics and constraints of cross-border money movement.
notable_frameworks: Word-of-mouth measurement via in-product 'How did you hear about us?' surveys + attribution overlay (cookies/referrers + direct traffic calibration)

nir-eyal.title: Strategies for becoming less distractible and improving focus | Nir Eyal
nir-eyal.summary: Nir Eyal explains why most distraction isn’t caused by technology but by an attempt to escape internal discomfort ("it’s not the pings, dings, and rings—it’s the feelings"). Listeners learn a more empowering approach to focus: identify the internal triggers behind distraction and use practical tools to stay aligned with what they intend to do (traction) rather than reacting impulsively.
notable_frameworks: Distraction vs. Traction (reframing distraction as an action; traction as actions taken with intent)
Internal Triggers (discomfort/emotions as the primary driver of distraction)

noah-weiss.title: The 10 traits of great PMs, AI, and Slack’s approach to product | Noah Weiss (Slack, Google)
noah-weiss.summary: Noah Weiss (CPO at Slack, former product leader at Foursquare and PM at Google) breaks down what makes great product managers, how Slack approaches building and evolving products, and how to navigate strongly opinionated, product-minded leadership. Listeners will learn practical methods Slack uses to surface customer pain (e.g., “Complaint Storms”), how to make bigger strategic bets (“next hill” / “boulder bets”), and how to think about applying AI capabilities in a customer-driven way.
notable_frameworks: The 10 traits of great PMs
Take bigger boulder bets / “get to the next hill” (portfolio of bigger strategic bets)
Complaint Storms (structured customer-complaint review process)
Incubate-and-pilot teams (small teams prototyping/piloting before scaling)

noam-lovinsky.title: The happiness and pain of product management | Noam Lovinsky (Grammarly, FB, Thumbtack, YT)
noam-lovinsky.summary: Noam Lovinsky shares how he’s built and rebuilt products across very different contexts—early YouTube, a growth turnaround at Thumbtack, 0→1 incubation inside Facebook, and scaling Grammarly. Listeners will learn how to choose work that fits their strengths, how to structure innovation inside large orgs without killing it via incentives, and how to think about product time horizons and career moves through the lens of impact and learning.
notable_frameworks: 0-to-1 vs 1-to-100 product building
“startup within a startup” incubation model
Time-horizon alignment (incubation vs performance-management cadence)

oji-udezue.title: Picking sharp problems, increasing virality, and unique product frameworks | Oji Udezue (Typeform)
oji-udezue.summary: Oji Udezue breaks down what actually drives sustainable product-led growth and virality: solving a sharp, high-value problem with a genuinely great product rather than chasing “synthetic” viral tactics. He also shares a practical framework for evaluating B2B SaaS startup ideas by mapping workflows based on how broadly they apply across an organization and how frequently they’re performed—helping founders and investors predict where unicorn outcomes are more likely.
notable_frameworks: Synthetic virality vs. organic virality ("bedrock of virality" = great product solving a sharp problem)
"Where do you fish to find a unicorn" (workflow quadrant: breadth across departments × frequency/intensity)
High frequency niche ("high ni") vs. everyone workflows categorization

paige-costello.title: How to ask the right questions, project confidence, and win over skeptics | Paige Costello (Asana)
paige-costello.summary: Paige Costello shares practical tactics for building trust and credibility—especially when you’re the youngest or least experienced person in the room—by bringing strong customer, market, competitive, and product insights. She also discusses how Asana’s product org and planning process evolved as the company scaled, including shifting from annual planning to a rolling 12-month plan updated every six months, and introducing clearer ownership layers (pillars → areas → teams) with nested metrics.
notable_frameworks: Know thy customer / market / competitors / numbers / product (credibility-through-insight)
"How might the opposite be true?" (reframing to escape scarcity mindset)
Pillars → Areas → Teams (organizational and strategy nesting model)
Nested metrics by level (R&D → pillar → area → team)
Rolling 12-month planning with 6-month re-plans (dual-horizon planning)

patrick-campbell.title: 10 lessons on bootstrapping a $200m business | Patrick Campbell (ProfitWell)
patrick-campbell.summary: Patrick Campbell, founder of ProfitWell (bootstrapped and sold for $200M+), shares highly tactical lessons on building and scaling a SaaS business without funding. Listeners will learn contrarian, execution-focused guidance on leadership and team building (especially alignment and shipping tempo), plus practical insights across pricing, retention, research, and competitive strategy.
notable_frameworks: Tempo framework (shipping cadence/alignment as a core operating system)
Values require trade-offs (values-as-tradeoffs approach to culture)
Most charitable interpretation (conflict-resolution norm)

paul-adams.title: What AI means for your product strategy | Paul Adams (CPO of Intercom)
paul-adams.summary: Paul Adams (CPO of Intercom) explains how AI will reshape product strategy and why teams need to revisit their product’s core premise to determine what AI can replace versus where it can augment users. He shares lessons from high-stakes failures (freezing during a major keynote, working on unsuccessful social products at Google) and how those experiences shaped his approach to leadership, decision-making, and building AI-first products at Intercom.
notable_frameworks: Back-to-basics product premise audit (identify the core job/problem, then ask: can AI do it now/partially/later?)
Replacement vs. augmentation lens for AI product strategy

paul-millerd.title: Redefining success, money, and belonging | Paul Millerd (The Pathless Path)
paul-millerd.summary: Paul Millerd unpacks the “default path” script many people follow (school → career ladder → stability) and introduces the “pathless path” as a more conscious, self-directed approach to work and life. Listeners will learn practical ways to notice inherited beliefs about work (e.g., guilt about taking time off), evaluate trade-offs they’re implicitly accepting, and experiment with small actions to reconnect with what energizes them and redesign their relationship to work.
notable_frameworks: The Default Path
The Pathless Path
“Fire the manager in your head” (identity/scripts decoupling from work)
Three-hour workday walk/childhood activity experiment (create space to notice beliefs and energy)
Trade-off / “costs of your game” analysis (making implicit contracts explicit)

pete-kazanjy.title: Founder-led sales | Pete Kazanjy (Founding Sales, Atrium)
pete-kazanjy.summary: Pete Kazanjy breaks down why founders should personally lead sales early on, and how to approach selling as a learnable, measurable craft rather than a “born salesperson” trait. Listeners will learn what “modern sales” looks like (data-driven, operational, and behavior-focused), plus practical guidance on when and how to hire the first salesperson and avoid common early go-to-market mistakes.
notable_frameworks: Founder-led sales (founder as initial seller before first sales hire)
Modern sales / Moneyball-for-sales (instrument, measure, and improve sales behaviors using CRM + activity data)
Sales as market-making (sellers as microeconomic agents matching supply to demand)

peter-deng.title: Peter Deng
peter-deng.summary: Peter Deng shares hard-won lessons from building and scaling products at Facebook, Instagram, Uber, Airtable, and OpenAI—especially what it takes to go from an idea to products used by billions. Key takeaways include thinking several moves ahead (building systems to move faster sustainably), recognizing when “the product” is actually the holistic experience (e.g., price + ETA at Uber), and how AI will meaningfully reshape education and learning behaviors. He also explains what he looks for in hires—people who quickly become the ones directing what should be done rather than waiting for instructions.
notable_frameworks: Chess-move planning (thinking multiple moves ahead; building systems to go faster sustainably)
Holistic product definition (the product as the full user-perceived experience, e.g., price + ETA)

petra-wille.title: How to be the best coach to product people | Petra Wille (Strong Product People)
petra-wille.summary: Petra Wille shares how product leaders and PM managers can become better coaches—especially when they didn’t come up through product—by building empathy for the PM role and actively curating their team’s learning and development. The episode also emphasizes storytelling and public speaking as critical career accelerators for product people, and highlights the value of finding (or building) a PM community to grow faster through shared practices and support.
notable_frameworks: T-shaped skills (contrasted with an "eight-legged creature" model for PM skill breadth)

phyl-terry.title: Land your dream job in today’s market: negotiation tactics, job search councils, more | Phyl Terry
phyl-terry.summary: Phyl Terry shares a product-inspired approach to job searching, arguing that most people fail by “spraying and praying” instead of focusing on a clear target—like finding product-market fit. Listeners will learn how Job Search Councils (small peer support groups) reduce anxiety, increase accountability, and help candidates define their “candidate market fit” so they can lead interviews and negotiations with confidence.
notable_frameworks: Never Search Alone (job search methodology)
Job Search Councils (peer-based job search support group model)
Candidate Market Fit (applying product-market-fit thinking to job search)
Spear vs. net (focused targeting vs. broad “spray and pray” applications)
Play to win vs. play not to lose (assertive mindset for interviewing/negotiation)

raaz-herzberg.title: Building Wiz: the fastest-growing startup in history | Raaz Herzberg (CMO and VP Product Strategy)
raaz-herzberg.summary: Raaz Herzberg shares how Wiz went from an unclear early direction (and an initial idea that didn’t work) to extreme product-market fit, including the specific customer-conversation signals that indicated when they were on the wrong track vs. the right one. Listeners will learn how to use high-volume customer discovery to drive pivots, what “real” buying intent sounds like in B2B security, and how Raaz’s shift from product leadership to CMO changed her perspective on what great marketing (and great product leadership) actually requires.
notable_frameworks: Dummy explanation
Pay attention to where the heat is within the organization

rachel-lockett.title: A guide to difficult conversations, building high-trust teams, and designing a life you love
rachel-lockett.summary: Rachel Lockett shares practical coaching insights for technical leaders on shifting from being the “answer person” to empowering teams to solve hard problems themselves. She explains why difficult conversations are emotional (not purely logical) and how reframing conflict toward mutual understanding builds trust and reduces friction. Listeners will also learn how to prevent burnout by aligning work with strengths and taking ownership of career navigation rather than expecting managers to make work inherently fulfilling.
notable_frameworks: Conflict as mutual understanding (vs. winning/being right)
Leader-as-coach mindset (empowerment over advice-giving)
Strengths/gifts alignment to increase energy and reduce burnout

rahul-vohra.title: Superhuman's secret to success | Rahul Vohra (CEO and founder)
rahul-vohra.summary: Rahul Vohra shares lessons from selling Rapportive to LinkedIn and how that experience reshaped his thinking about growth. The core insight: sustained “virality” rarely comes from viral mechanics (invites, address book import) and instead comes from hard-to-measure word of mouth—people spontaneously recommending a product because it’s genuinely great.
notable_frameworks: Viral factor (K-factor) as a metric for viral mechanics vs. word-of-mouth growth

ramesh-johari.title: Marketplace lessons from Uber, Airbnb, Bumble, and more | Ramesh Johari (Stanford professor)
ramesh-johari.summary: Ramesh Johari breaks down what marketplaces actually sell—reducing transaction costs (friction) for both sides of the market—and why that framing changes how founders should design and operate their businesses. Listeners learn how marketplace changes often create shifting winners and losers (“whac-a-mole”), why data science and experimentation are central to managing those tradeoffs, and how to think about core marketplace mechanisms like matching and reviews.
notable_frameworks: Marketplaces as transaction-cost reducers (platform sells friction removal, not the underlying good/service)
Two-sided customers model (both supply and demand are the platform’s customers)
Marketplace “whac-a-mole” / winner-loser tradeoff model (changes reallocate attention and inventory, creating shifting outcomes)

ravi-mehta.title: How to build your product strategy stack | Ravi Mehta (Tinder, Facebook, Tripadvisor, Outpace)
ravi-mehta.summary: Ravi Mehta shares how product leaders can drive teams effectively by balancing scalable leadership (clear direction + autonomy) with tactical, temporary micromanagement when alignment is off. He also outlines his career path across Microsoft/Xbox, Tripadvisor, Facebook, and Tinder, and explains why he started Outpace to make high-quality coaching more accessible using structured systems and AI.
notable_frameworks: Scalable leadership vs. selective micromanagement (temporary, tactical micromanagement to correct direction)

ray-cao.title: Product management theater | Marty Cagan (Silicon Valley Product Group)
ray-cao.summary: Ray Cao shares an inside look at how TikTok operates—especially its culture of “context, not control,” high ownership, and rapid experimentation—and contrasts it with Google’s more engineering-lab, tech-driven approach. Listeners will learn how TikTok thinks about global product prioritization, customer-centric innovation (users, creators, and advertisers), and the operating principles that enable speed and execution at scale.
notable_frameworks: Context, not control (high-context leadership/ownership model)
Operate like a business owner (ownership mindset)
“Run the second half of the marathon faster than the first” (continuous acceleration/growth mindset)

richard-rumelt.title: Good Strategy, Bad Strategy | Richard Rumelt
richard-rumelt.summary: Richard Rumelt reframes strategy as practical problem-solving: a design for overcoming a high-stakes challenge through coherent policy and action. Listeners will learn why “strategy” is often confused with goals, vision/mission statements, or analytical tools, and how to start instead with a clear diagnosis of the real challenge and an actionable, coordinated response.
notable_frameworks: Rumelt’s “kernel” of good strategy (diagnosis, guiding policy, coherent actions)
Strategy as an “action agenda” (reframing strategy away from vision/values boilerplate)
Strategy as problem solving / overcoming a high-stakes challenge

robby-stein.title: Inside Google's AI turnaround: AI Mode, AI Overviews, and vision for AI-powered search | Robby Stein
robby-stein.summary: Robby Stein shares how Google Search is evolving in the AI era—without abandoning the core utility of search—and why AI is "expansionary," increasing the range and volume of questions people ask. He explains what’s driving Google’s recent momentum (focus, urgency, tight collaboration with research/DeepMind, and compounding iteration) and distills product-building lessons from leading major consumer launches like Instagram Stories/Reels and Google’s AI search experiences.
notable_frameworks: Relentless improvement (relentlessness + continuous making-things-better)
Compounding iteration leading to a tipping point (continuous monthly/daily improvements)

roger-martin.title: 5 essential questions to craft a winning strategy | Roger Martin (author, advisor, speaker)
roger-martin.summary: Roger Martin breaks down why strategy is so difficult in practice—it's an integrative set of reinforcing choices, emotionally intimidating because it forces trade-offs, and poorly taught/trained in many schools and companies. He teaches a practical way to craft strategy using his “strategy choice cascade,” helping listeners (including non-execs) make clear choices about where to play, how to win, and what capabilities and systems are required to execute.
notable_frameworks: Strategy Choice Cascade (five questions: winning aspiration, where to play, how to win, required capabilities, enabling management systems)
Playing to Win (differentiation vs low-cost as the two defensible routes to winning)

ronny-kohavi.title: The ultimate guide to A/B testing | Ronny Kohavi (Airbnb, Microsoft, Amazon)
ronny-kohavi.summary: Ronny Kohavi shares a highly tactical guide to building an experimentation (A/B testing) practice, emphasizing a “test everything” mindset because even tiny changes and bug fixes can have large, unexpected effects. Listeners learn how to prioritize and evaluate experiments, why most bold ideas should be expected to fail, and how to build trust in experiment results through strong metrics, guardrails, and validation practices.
notable_frameworks: Test everything (experiment-driven development)
High-risk/high-reward experimentation portfolio (expect most to fail)
Guardrail metrics (protect user experience while optimizing outcomes)
P-value (statistical significance in controlled experiments)
Twyman’s law (skepticism of results that seem too good to be true)

ryan-hoover.title: A better way to plan, build, and ship products | Ryan Singer (creator of “Shape Up")
ryan-hoover.summary: Ryan Hoover shares a candid look at the emotional reality of being a founder/CEO—managing anxiety while projecting confidence—and how public visibility changes your behavior and energy, especially as an introvert. He also discusses making intentional lifestyle decisions (e.g., relocating) by evaluating cities like products, weighing costs and benefits to match personal priorities.
notable_frameworks: Treating cities like products (cost/benefit tradeoff model)

ryan-j-salva.title: The role of AI in new product development | Ryan J. Salva (VP of Product at GitHub)
ryan-j-salva.summary: Ryan J. Salva (VP of Product at GitHub) shares how GitHub’s Copilot emerged from an internal R&D effort that leveraged large language models trained on public code, and what it takes to incubate and scale a “big bet” product inside a large organization. Listeners will learn how he thinks about creativity as the core of developer tooling, why GitHub became the center of gravity for developer innovation post-acquisition, and how product leaders navigate building new products (V1s) across the developer lifecycle.

ryan-singer.title: A better way to plan, build, and ship products | Ryan Singer (creator of “Shape Up")
ryan-singer.summary: Ryan Singer explains the core ideas behind the Shape Up method for building software: start by collaboratively “shaping” work so teams can see the end from the beginning, and use fixed time budgets (“appetites”) instead of estimates and deadlines. Listeners will learn why many teams struggle to ship under common Agile/Scrum approaches, how Shape Up aligns product, design, and engineering early, and what it takes to adapt the method beyond Basecamp to different company contexts.
notable_frameworks: Shape Up
Appetites (time budgets) vs deadlines/estimates
Shaping sessions (cross-functional pre-work to de-risk and define the solution)

sachin-monga.title: Building Substack | Sachin Monga (Substack, Facebook)
sachin-monga.summary: Sachin Monga, Head of Product at Substack, explains how Substack’s subscription-based model enables a “golden era” for independent writers by aligning incentives around quality rather than attention and ads. Listeners learn how Substack has been evolving from a founder-led build process into a more product-driven organization, including how the product org is structured and why that shift matters.
notable_frameworks: Subscription-first business model (direct reader-to-writer subscriptions vs ad-supported attention model)
User-segmented team structure (writer team, reader team, growth team, plus systems/infra)

sahil-mansuri.title: How to hit revenue targets in a recession | Sahil Mansuri (Bravado)
sahil-mansuri.summary: Sahil Mansuri shares how founders and sales leaders should adjust planning and revenue execution during a downturn: build a conservative base plan, then use short-term milestones to "earn the right" to reinvest in growth. Listeners will learn practical guidance on quotas, forecasting, comp plans, and why doubling down on retention and existing customers becomes especially critical in a recession.
notable_frameworks: Conservative base plan + milestone-based unlocks for incremental spend/growth

sam-schillace.title: How to be more innovative | Sam Schillace (Microsoft deputy CTO, creator of Google Docs)
sam-schillace.summary: Sam Schillace (creator of Writely/Google Docs and Microsoft deputy CTO) breaks down how disruptive innovation actually happens: new ideas feel threatening at first, so people rationalize “why not” stories that later look obviously wrong in hindsight. Listeners will learn practical ways to generate and evaluate original ideas, stay optimistic through skepticism, and shape a career around the work that feels unusually easy and enjoyable—then execute it with intensity.
notable_frameworks: “Why-not questions” (skepticism patterns people use to dismiss disruptive ideas)
“Obvious in retrospect” lens (recognizing hindsight bias in innovation evaluation)
“Do the thing you feel guilty getting paid for” career heuristic

sanchan-saxena.title: Why Uber’s CPO delivers food on weekends | Sachin Kansal
sanchan-saxena.summary: Sachin Kansal (Uber CPO) shares how he stays close to customers and operations—famously delivering food on weekends—and how that hands-on approach shapes better product decisions. Listeners will learn practical lessons on product leadership at scale, building strong product culture and processes, and making high-quality decisions under real-world constraints.
notable_frameworks: Customer empathy via direct operational immersion ("do the job" / deliver-on-weekends practice)
Data-informed decision-making (balancing qualitative signals with metrics)
Rapid iteration and learning loops (test → learn → ship)

sander-schulhoff.title: AI prompt engineering in 2025: What works and what doesn’t | Sander Schulhoff
sander-schulhoff.summary: Sander argues that prompt engineering remains highly impactful in 2025: poor prompts can drive performance to near-zero while well-designed prompts can unlock large gains. Listeners will learn practical prompting techniques (e.g., self-criticism/self-checking loops), why “artificial social intelligence” matters for working effectively with LLMs, and how prompt injection/red teaming shape the security limits of AI systems and agents.
notable_frameworks: Self-criticism (self-checking / critique-and-improve prompting loop)
Artificial social intelligence
Prompt injection
Red teaming (e.g., HackAPrompt-style adversarial testing)

sander-schulhoff-20.title: Why securing AI is harder than anyone expected and guardrails are failing | HackAPrompt CEO
sander-schulhoff-20.summary: Sander Schulhoff argues that today’s AI security “guardrails” (often LLM-based input/output filters) are fundamentally unreliable against determined attackers, especially for prompt injection and jailbreaks. Listeners will learn why securing LLMs is qualitatively different from patching traditional software, how real-world attacks work (direct jailbreaks vs. prompt injection in apps/agents), and why risk will spike as AI systems gain more autonomy and access to tools and data.
notable_frameworks: AI red teaming (competition-driven adversarial testing)
Prompt injection vs. jailbreak taxonomy
Indirect prompt injection (attack via third-party content/tools)

sarah-tavel.title: The hierarchy of engagement | Sarah Tavel (Benchmark, Greylock, Pinterest)
sarah-tavel.summary: Sarah Tavel shares two practical frameworks for building and scaling consumer and marketplace startups, emphasizing that durable growth comes from deep engagement rather than vanity metrics like downloads or MAUs. Listeners will learn how to define a product’s “core action” (the behavior that signals true activation/retention) and how to think about market momentum (“currents”) and marketplace dynamics to guide product and growth decisions.
notable_frameworks: Hierarchy of Engagement
Hierarchy of Marketplaces
Markets as currents (momentum-driven market selection)
Core action metric (engagement/activation anchor)

scott-belsky.title: Lessons on product sense, AI, the first mile experience, and the messy middle | Scott Belsky (Adobe)
scott-belsky.summary: Scott Belsky shares lessons from building and scaling products as a founder (Behance) and as an executive at Adobe, focusing on how to develop strong product sense and make better product decisions. Listeners will learn how to navigate the “messy middle” of building companies/products, how to think about experience quality (especially early onboarding/first-mile), and how AI is reshaping product strategy and emerging product development.
notable_frameworks: The Messy Middle
Conviction test (more vs. less conviction over time to decide persist vs. quit/pivot)
First-mile experience (early user journey/onboarding focus)

scott-wu.title: Inside Devin: The AI engineer that's set to write 50% of its company’s code this year | Scott Wu
scott-wu.summary: Scott Wu, CEO of Cognition, explains how Devin—an autonomous AI software engineer—fits into real engineering workflows (Slack/Linear/GitHub) and how Cognition’s own 15-person engineering team uses multiple Devins per engineer to ship code. Listeners learn what “agentic” software development looks like in practice, why Cognition expects Devin-authored pull requests to rise from ~25% to >50% within the year, and how the engineer’s role shifts from writing code to architecting, delegating, and reviewing.
notable_frameworks: Autonomous agent / asynchronous workflow model (AI engineer that takes issues end-to-end)
“Jagged intelligence” (capabilities are uneven vs. humans across tasks)
Engineer-as-architect shift (humans move from coding to specifying/reviewing/structuring work)

sean-ellis.title: The original growth hacker reveals his secrets | Sean Ellis (author of “Hacking Growth”)
sean-ellis.summary: Sean Ellis breaks down how to assess product-market fit early using the “Sean Ellis test” (the ‘very disappointed’ question) as a leading indicator, and why true confirmation ultimately comes from retention. He explains how to interpret results (including why to focus on ‘must-have’ users and avoid over-optimizing for ‘nice-to-have’ feedback) and connects this to what to do next to unlock sustainable growth.
notable_frameworks: Sean Ellis test (Product-Market Fit survey: 'How would you feel if you could no longer use this product?')
ICE prioritization framework

seth-godin.title: Seth Godin's best tactics for building remarkable products, strategies, brands and more
seth-godin.summary: Seth Godin argues that as AI becomes table stakes, differentiation will come from making a clear, difficult, “remarkable” promise to users—and consistently keeping it. He explains how great strategy and innovation create productive tension (between the imagined better future and whether the product delivers), and how strong product work comes from raising the spec in service of customer delight rather than perfectionism or boss-pleasing.
notable_frameworks: AI as electricity (AI becomes non-differentiating infrastructure, not a feature)
Remarkable promise: define a difficult promise to the user and keep it
Strategy requires tension (between aspiration/possibility and delivery/truth)
Quality = meeting spec (raise the spec vs. perfectionism)
Good taste = knowing what other people will want just before they do

shaun-clowes.title: Why great AI products are all about the data | Shaun Clowes (CPO at Confluent)
shaun-clowes.summary: Shaun Clowes argues that product management is still an underdeveloped discipline, with outcomes that are too random because many PMs get pulled into internal politics and delivery execution instead of anchoring decisions in the customer, market, and competitive context. He explains why AI’s biggest impact on product work will be through better data management—LLMs are only as useful as the quality and recency of the data they can synthesize. Listeners will learn what separates great PMs from average ones, why data is the core ingredient for AI-powered products and PM workflows, and how to think about defensibility in a world where SaaS features can be cloned.
notable_frameworks: 10x PM leverage model (PM impact as multiplicative leverage on teams)
Customer/market/competitor-first framing (external orientation as a PM operating model)
LLM-as-synthesis-machine mental model (AI value constrained by data quality and recency)
Career 'Bingo card' approach (indexing toward varied roles to build a broad skill portfolio)

shishir-mehrotra.title: The rituals of great teams | Shishir Mehrotra, Coda, YouTube, Microsoft
shishir-mehrotra.summary: Shishir Mehrotra (CEO of Coda, former YouTube leader) shares how high-performing teams and products are built through repeatable rituals and clear thinking frameworks. Listeners will learn practical approaches to growth strategy (including his Blue Loops/Black Loops model), how to evaluate and hire strong product talent (with an emphasis on reference checks), and how structured questions and writing can improve decision-making and team alignment.
notable_frameworks: Blue Loops and Black Loops
Eigenquestions
Reference-check-driven hiring evaluation

shreyas-doshi.title: The art of product management | Shreyas Doshi (Stripe, Twitter, Google, Yahoo)
shreyas-doshi.summary: Shreyas Doshi shares practical, experience-backed lessons on the craft of product management, focusing on how PMs can make better decisions, spend their time effectively, and reduce team tension. Listeners will learn concrete frameworks like pre-mortems, the “three levels of product work,” and why many execution issues are actually strategy problems, plus a common prioritization pitfall to avoid.
notable_frameworks: Pre-mortems
Three levels of product work
Execution problems are strategy problems (reframing)

shreyas-doshi-live.title: The art of product management | Shreyas Doshi (Stripe, Twitter, Google, Yahoo)
shreyas-doshi-live.summary: Shreyas Doshi shares a set of career-defining questions he wishes he’d asked earlier—starting with why product leaders feel perpetually busy and stressed even when they’re performing well. Listeners will learn how increasing scope eventually overwhelms productivity hacks, why PM leadership can feel uniquely frustrating, and what to focus on instead (including building “taste” and improving how well you listen).
notable_frameworks: LNO framework (prioritization/time management)

shweta-shriva.title: Product lessons from Waymo | Shweta Shrivastava (Waymo, Amazon, Cisco)
shweta-shriva.summary: Shweta Shrivastava shares what it’s like to build and scale product at Waymo, including how autonomous driving differs from traditional software product development in technical depth, uncertainty, and time horizons. Listeners learn how Waymo thinks about vehicle behavior that feels “human” (without inheriting bad human driving), how simulation is used to validate safety and performance, and why proactively challenging assumptions and encouraging constructive conflict are critical for strong product leadership.
notable_frameworks: Assumption-challenging / deliberate conflict as a product leadership practice
Human-in-the-loop learning from human driving data (filtering out undesirable behavior)
Simulation-driven validation for safety/performance

sri-batchu.title: Lessons from scaling Ramp | Sri Batchu (Ramp, Instacart, Opendoor)
sri-batchu.summary: Sri Batchu breaks down how high-performing B2B companies typically scale go-to-market, starting with founder-led sales and progressing through increasingly expensive channels as customer understanding improves. He also shares how Ramp’s early growth was accelerated by strong product-market fit plus a deliberate “cap table as a growth strategy,” recruiting influential founders/operators as investors who became early customers and advocates.
notable_frameworks: B2B growth channel progression: founder-led sales → early sales hires → low-cost targeted marketing (content/community/events) → PR → paid + brand → SEO
Cap table as a growth strategy

sriram-and-aarthi.title: Hot takes and techno-optimism from tech’s top power couple | Sriram and Aarthi
sriram-and-aarthi.summary: Sriram and Aarthi share contrarian product and growth perspectives drawn from their experience across major consumer tech companies, including how network effects products are built and scaled through deliberate onboarding and activation tactics. They also discuss how creating content and building relationships online can compound into career opportunities (including high-leverage “cold DM” outreach), and close with a pointed critique of the Jobs-to-be-Done framework as a misleading lens for building successful products.
notable_frameworks: Jobs-to-be-Done (JTBD)
Activation metric/thresholds (e.g., Facebook’s “10 friends in 14 days”)
Network effects (implicit mental model)

stewart-butterfield.title: Mental models for building products people love ft. Stewart Butterfield
stewart-butterfield.summary: Stewart Butterfield shares hard-earned mental models from building and pivoting Flickr and Slack, emphasizing that long-term success comes from creating real customer value—not performative work or polished narratives. He explains why teams should obsess over user comprehension (not just “reducing friction”), stay coldly rational when deciding whether to pivot, and use utility curves to judge when additional investment in a feature meaningfully increases value versus just adding complexity.
notable_frameworks: Utility curves (S-curve of effort/cost vs value/convenience)
Comprehension-over-friction principle (optimize for not making users think)
Coldly rational pivot decision (create distance from emotion/humiliation)
Customer value as the ultimate success metric ("no substitute for actually having created it")

tamar-yehoshua.title: Lessons in product leadership and AI strategy from Glean, Google, Amazon, and Slack | Tamar Yehoshua
tamar-yehoshua.summary: Tamar Yehoshua shares practical lessons from leading product and engineering at Google Search, Amazon, Slack, and now Glean, focusing on what actually drives career acceleration and effective product leadership. Key takeaways include excelling at your current role, developing strong intuition grounded in deep customer understanding (not just metrics), and learning to read and motivate people to build better products and teams. The episode also covers leadership alignment with engineering partners and how AI is changing work and product-building, especially with non-deterministic systems.
notable_frameworks: Beginner's mind (Benioff)
Balancing metrics with product intuition
Engineering-partner alignment (clear roles/responsibilities; avoid "mom vs dad" decisions)

tanguy-crusson.title: Hard-won lessons building 0 to 1 inside Atlassian | Tanguy Crusson (Head of Jira Product Discovery)
tanguy-crusson.summary: Tanguy Crusson shares hard-won lessons from a decade at Atlassian building (and sometimes shutting down) zero-to-one products, culminating in the successful launch of Jira Product Discovery. Listeners will learn why innovation is uniquely difficult inside large companies, how to create “startup-like” scarcity and autonomy, and how to protect early bets with clear test plans, customer evidence, and visible velocity.
notable_frameworks: 0-to-1 product development inside large companies
Creating scarcity/constraints to avoid over-investment
Siloed/autonomous incubation teams to enable rapid testing
Test-and-learn framing (explicitly defining what is being tested)
Using qualitative customer stories + quantitative data to sustain internal conviction
“High-speed train” momentum/velocity as an internal protection mechanism
Internal incubator model (Atlassian’s Point A)

teaser_2021.title: Teaser_2021 | Lenny's Podcast
teaser_2021.summary: Greg Isenberg and Sahil Bloom introduce “The Room Where it Happens,” a podcast-plus-community designed to open up the behind-the-scenes conversations where startup ideas, opportunities, and relationships are formed. Listeners will learn why proximity to high-signal rooms and networks can compound career outcomes, and why the real work of building is the “messy middle” that most media glosses over. They also outline a more participatory model of podcasting that invites the audience into ongoing discussion and collaboration via community channels.
notable_frameworks: The messy middle (Scott Belsky)

teresa-torres.title: Build better products with continuous product discovery | Teresa Torres
teresa-torres.summary: Teresa Torres explains how to shift product teams from shipping outputs to driving outcomes by using the Opportunity Solution Tree to structure the messy work of deciding what to build. Listeners learn how to define and map “opportunities” (unmet needs) without jumping to solutions, and how to build a repeatable system for continuous customer discovery through regular customer conversations and lightweight research operations.
notable_frameworks: Opportunity Solution Tree
Continuous Discovery Habits
Outcome-focused product development (outputs vs outcomes)
Experience mapping (to structure the opportunity space)
Assumption testing (as a branch from solutions)

tim-holley.title: Inside Etsy’s product, growth, and marketplace evolution | Tim Holley (VP of Product)
tim-holley.summary: Tim Holley, VP of Product at Etsy, shares how Etsy evolved from a slower, consensus-driven culture into a faster, more execution- and metrics-oriented organization—while preserving its mission of empowering independent sellers. Listeners will learn practical lessons about scaling a two-sided marketplace (balancing supply and demand), driving predictable growth via product changes and experimentation, and navigating major cultural transitions during pivotal moments like COVID’s mask surge.
notable_frameworks: North Star metric (Etsy: GMS/GMV as the primary KPI)
Supply–demand marketplace balancing (two-sided marketplace dynamics)
Consensus-based decision-making vs. faster execution model (cultural operating model shift)

timothy-davis.title: The ultimate guide to paid growth | Timothy Davis (Shopify)
timothy-davis.summary: Timothy Davis shares a highly tactical playbook for performance marketing (paid growth), drawing on his experience leading paid at Shopify and advising major tech companies. Listeners learn why paid—especially paid search—is increasingly essential, how to think about platform differences and measurement, and how to approach experimentation without "ego marketing" (e.g., obsessing over being #1) in favor of reaching the right users efficiently.
notable_frameworks: Paid search as "user-driven" demand capture vs. other channels as "disruptive media"
Avoiding "ego marketing" (optimize for efficient reach to the right audience vs. always being #1 / always-on presence)
Learning mindset for channel testing ("we're either winning or we're learning")

tobi-lutke.title: Tobi Lütke's leadership playbook: First principles, infinite games, and maximizing human potential
tobi-lutke.summary: Tobi Lütke shares how he leads Shopify by thinking from first principles, optimizing for long-term mission over short-term optics, and making fast, decisive calls when work isn’t aligned—what employees call the “Tobi tornado.” Listeners will learn how he uses direct feedback and rapid change management to avoid wasted effort, raise the bar, and help people realize far more of their potential than they think is possible.
notable_frameworks: first principles thinking
working backwards from the future (long-term/100-year vision)
time compression in decision-making (rapid change management)
infinite games / mission-first orientation (implied by long-horizon framing)
high-candor feedback to maximize human potential

todd-jackson.title: A framework for finding product-market fit | Todd Jackson (First Round Capital)
todd-jackson.summary: Todd Jackson shares a practical, staged framework for finding product-market fit, based on patterns First Round Capital observed across hundreds of startups. Listeners learn how to diagnose which PMF “level” they’re in, why most companies stall before reaching strong PMF, and how to get unstuck by systematically changing one or more of the “four Ps” (persona, problem, promise, product).
notable_frameworks: Four levels of product-market fit (nascent, developing, strong, extreme)
Three PMF patterns: demand, satisfaction, efficiency
The Four Ps for PMF iteration: persona, problem, promise, product
Superhuman PMF method (Rahul Vohra’s approach, referenced)

tom-conrad.title: Billion dollar failures, and billion dollar success | Tom Conrad (Quibi, Pandora, Pets.com, Zero)
tom-conrad.summary: Tom Conrad shares hard-earned lessons from both massive wins (helping scale Pandora to tens of millions of users) and high-profile failures (Pets.com, Quibi), focusing on how to choose the right problems and business models. Listeners will learn how to evaluate opportunities by the underlying “math” of a business, what tends to go wrong in product strategy and execution at scale, and how leadership and career choices compound over time.
notable_frameworks: Business model "math" / unit economics as a decision filter (choosing problems with a formula that wins)

tomer-cohen.title: Why AI is disrupting traditional product management | Tomer Cohen (LinkedIn CPO)
tomer-cohen.summary: Tomer Cohen (LinkedIn CPO) shares how LinkedIn’s product turnaround—especially the feed—came from resetting the product’s purpose and driving clarity in both problem definition and execution. He explains how an “AI-first” mindset is less about bolting on new tech and more about revisiting core objectives and re-solving them with new capabilities. Listeners will learn practical leadership and decision-making principles for aligning teams, forming strong product opinions, and avoiding organizational confusion while moving fast.
notable_frameworks: “We might be wrong, but we are not confused” (clarity of thought + clarity of execution)
AI-first product development (start from objectives, not technology)
First-principles thinking (principles with explicit tradeoffs / “teeth”)
Deep problem definition before solutioning (specific audience + use case + success criteria)

tomer-cohen-20.title: Why AI is disrupting traditional product management | Tomer Cohen (LinkedIn CPO)
tomer-cohen-20.summary: Tomer Cohen explains why AI is forcing a fundamental rethink of how products are built: change is happening faster than organizations can respond, and the skills required for most jobs will shift dramatically by 2030. He shares LinkedIn’s emerging “Full Stack Builder” approach—pairing humans with AI tools/agents to reduce process and organizational complexity, empower individuals to take ideas from concept to launch, and redesign incentives and change management so adoption actually sticks.
notable_frameworks: Full Stack Builder model / Full Stack Builder Program
Human + AI (human-machine) product team model
First-principles rebuilding of the product development process
Time constant of change > time constant of response (organizational adaptation framing)
Process complexity → organizational complexity → microspecialization (causal chain)

tristan-de-montebello.title: Why most public speaking advice is wrong—and how to finally overcome anxiety | Tristan de Montebello
tristan-de-montebello.summary: Tristan de Montebello explains why most public speaking advice backfires by pushing people into a fake “public speaking voice” and performance mode, increasing self-consciousness and anxiety. He argues speaking is a meta-skill that upgrades many areas of life, and that progress comes from “debugging” learned mental/software bugs and returning to natural, conversational speech—often by making the process more enjoyable and less evaluative.
notable_frameworks: Speaking as a meta-skill (analogous to fitness as a meta-skill)
Hardware vs. software model (innate speaking ability vs. learned 'bugs' and the need for debugging/upgrading)
Conversational speaking vs. 'public speaking voice' (authenticity over performance)

upasna-gautam.title: An inside look at how CNN builds product | Upasna Gautam
upasna-gautam.summary: Upasna Gautam shares what it’s like to build product inside a breaking-news organization, where priorities can change instantly and product teams must design their processes around constant disruption. Listeners will learn how CNN’s product team collaborates with journalists (their primary users), plans research and onboarding with buffers and backups, and how mindfulness—especially equanimity—helps leaders stay effective and non-reactive amid chaos.
notable_frameworks: Equanimity (pause-before-reacting mental model)
Buffers and backups planning (operational resilience for breaking-news interruptions)

uri-levine.title: A founder’s guide to crisis management | Uri Levine (Waze co-founder, serial entrepreneur)
uri-levine.summary: Uri Levine shares a founder-focused playbook for building successful startups by anchoring everything in a real, meaningful customer problem rather than a clever solution. Listeners will learn how problem-first thinking sharpens strategy, improves storytelling and pitches, and increases the odds of product-market fit—plus tactical advice on hiring decisions and fundraising presentation structure.
notable_frameworks: Fall in love with the problem, not the solution (problem-as-North-Star)
Problem-first narrative framing (start with: problem / value to user vs. solution)
30-day re-hire test for new hires ("Knowing what I know today, would I hire them?")
Pitch deck emphasis model (first slide most important; last slide second most important)

varun-mohan.title: Building a magical AI code editor used by over 1m developers in 4 months: Inside Windsurf
varun-mohan.summary: Varun Mohan shares how his team pivoted from GPU infrastructure to building Codeium, then forked VS Code to create Windsurf—an AI-native code editor that reached 1M+ users in four months. Listeners will learn how Windsurf differentiates with agentic workflows and enterprise-grade security/personalization, plus Varun’s operating principles around rapid product reinvention, hiring discipline, and why AI increases (not decreases) the ROI of engineering.
notable_frameworks: Cannibalize your product every 6–12 months (continuous self-disruption)
“Dehydrated company” hiring heuristic (hire only when the org is truly stretched)
Vertical integration up the stack (from infrastructure to application layer)

varun-parmar.title: An inside look at how Miro builds product | Varun Parmar (CPO of Miro)
varun-parmar.summary: Varun Parmar (CPO of Miro) shares how Miro’s product organization operates—especially how a Europe-based product team stays tightly aligned with a globally distributed go-to-market org. Listeners will learn how Miro uses empathy-driven questioning and cross-functional teamwork to turn customer and internal insights into product decisions, and how they think about the impact of every release in a competitive market.
notable_frameworks: Every release is a competitive "chess move" (products never stay the same; each ship makes you better or worse)
Empathy-driven product reviews via systematic questioning (trace decisions back to insights)

vijay.title: An inside look at Mixpanel’s product journey | Vijay Iyengar
vijay.summary: Vijay Iyengar shares lessons from Mixpanel’s evolution from a focused product analytics tool into a broader suite (e.g., messaging, data infrastructure) and the hard-earned realization that expanding beyond the core can create distraction and vulnerability to competitors. Listeners will learn how to evaluate when to say yes/no to new product ideas, why "protecting the core" matters, and how Mixpanel’s product strategy and org decisions were shaped by churn, focus, and reinvestment discipline.
notable_frameworks: Start with "yes" then earn the "no" (try to make the idea work before rejecting it)
Protect and out-invest in the core; fund adjacencies with profits, not by reallocating core team headcount ("invest profits, not people")

vikrama-dhiman.title: A framework for PM skill development | Vikrama Dhiman (Gojek)
vikrama-dhiman.summary: Vikrama Dhiman shares a practical framework for accelerating product manager growth, emphasizing that career progression isn’t just about working on a “cool” product or chasing impact metrics early. Listeners will learn how to develop by balancing strong execution artifacts (outputs), ownership of outcomes, and an effective operating model—while avoiding common mindset traps that stall growth.
notable_frameworks: Three W’s PM Career Growth Framework: what you produce, what you bring to the table, and what your operating model is
Outputs → Outcomes → Direction/Leadership progression (while continuing to maintain output craft)

wes-kao.title: Persuasive communication and managing up | Wes Kao (Maven, altMBA, Section4)
wes-kao.summary: Wes Kao breaks down how to communicate more persuasively by taking responsibility for confusion or lack of buy-in and improving clarity, structure, and anticipation of questions. Listeners will learn practical tactics for writing and speaking more effectively—especially in high-stakes settings—by proactively addressing objections and treating everyday communication as practice for "game day" moments with executives.
notable_frameworks: MOO (Most Obvious Objection)
Practice like it's game day / Play like it's game day

wes-kao-20.title: Persuasive communication and managing up | Wes Kao (Maven, altMBA, Section4)
wes-kao-20.summary: Wes Kao breaks down how to become a more persuasive, executive-level communicator by taking responsibility for confusion or skepticism and improving clarity, structure, and anticipation of questions. Listeners will learn practical tactics to write and speak more concisely, reduce back-and-forth, and increase buy-in—especially by proactively addressing the “Most Obvious Objections.”
notable_frameworks: MOO (Most Obvious Objection)
“Communication is the job” (principle)
“Practice like it’s game day” (principle)

will-larson.title: The engineering mindset | Will Larson (Carta, Stripe, Uber, Calm, Digg)
will-larson.summary: Will Larson and Lenny discuss how the engineering landscape has shifted from the zero-interest-rate “growth at all costs” era to a tighter market where hiring slows, teams consolidate, and leaders must focus more on execution, allocation, and accountability. Will argues that treating engineers as true peers—giving them real responsibility and holding them accountable—enables stronger engineering leadership and unlocks senior IC growth paths (e.g., Staff+ roles). Listeners learn how expectations for engineering managers and directors are changing and why this moment can be an opportunity for engineers to take on more meaningful leadership.
notable_frameworks: systems-thinking
Staff Engineer career ladder / Staff+ engineering archetypes

yamashata.title: An inside look at how Figma builds product | Yuhki Yamashita (CPO of Figma)
yamashata.summary: Yuhki Yamashita (CPO of Figma) shares how Figma approaches building product, including the philosophy behind collaborative design and how a strong product vision can turn initial controversy into customer advocacy. Listeners will learn about Yuhki’s career path across Microsoft, YouTube, and Uber (including a stint leading design), and how those experiences shaped his views on product development, cross-functional collaboration, and culture change.
notable_frameworks: Vision-led product narrative (customers championing a new way of working, not just a tool)
Transparency-by-default collaboration model (multiple people working in the same file)

yuhki-yamashata.title: An inside look at how Figma builds product | Yuhki Yamashita (CPO of Figma)
yuhki-yamashata.summary: Yuhki Yamashita, CPO of Figma, shares how Figma approaches building product—emphasizing a clear point of view about a new way of working (multiplayer, transparent design) and translating that into product decisions customers can champion. Listeners will learn how his cross-functional background (PM and design leadership) shaped his product philosophy, and how Figma’s culture and product-led approach influence how teams build, collaborate, and ship.
notable_frameworks: Product-led growth (PLG)
Vision-led product narrative (customers championing a new way of working)

yuriy-timen.title: How to grow a subscription business | Yuriy Timen (Grammarly, Canva, Airtable)
yuriy-timen.summary: Yuriy Timen shares a highly tactical playbook for growing subscription products, drawing on his experience leading growth at Grammarly and advising companies like Canva and Airtable. Listeners will learn how to choose and properly test growth channels (e.g., YouTube, SEO, paid), avoid common failure modes where teams under-invest or mis-execute, and build a repeatable growth strategy grounded in disciplined experimentation.
notable_frameworks: Give channels an "appropriate shot" (avoid premature conclusions from underpowered tests)
Channel evaluation via execution quality review (audit what was actually tried before judging a channel)

zoelle-egner.title: Lessons from Airtable’s unconventional growth strategy | Zoelle Egner
zoelle-egner.summary: Zoelle Egner (early Airtable employee) shares how Airtable grew by punching above its weight with unusually high-quality marketing, strong brand trust, and scrappy but thoughtful execution. Listeners will learn practical, high-leverage growth and go-to-market tactics for early-stage startups, plus lessons from building a volunteer-driven public-good product (VaccinateCA) that scaled via simple systems, data quality, and partnerships.
notable_frameworks: Punch above your weight (high-craft, high-trust marketing for small teams)
Brand trust via polish (details-as-signal: copy, visuals, sample content)
